titleStmt.title: Huon d'Auvergne, Kupferstichkabinett 78 D 8 (olim Hamilton 337) Annotations

div.note: 1] Holtus ("Considerazioni") published lines 1-109; his edition is a diplomatic one (45-48), with abbreviations reproduced and word divisions as in the manuscript. Tobler ("Berliner") published lines 1-111 (pp. 617-19); he reproduces the text without punctuation other than the final periods and the lines that mark caesura here at the beginning of the poem, and without distinguishing u/v.
12] MS: une (final -e is expunctuated)

21] The initial here is very faded; the external background is gold, the internal illustration is red with a figure inside, so the original would seem to be blue, though it is currently faded and purplish.

55] MS: quilens or quueus with "il" or second 'u' expunctuated (the second stroke is a bit longer than the first); the line is one syllable too long, with the hemistich divider after ferté; if instead it were after plus, the conjunction could elide with the final vowel of ferté according to Italian sinalepha rules.

76] Tobler omits the superscript after ".iiii."; Holtus seems to have a small "m" over the roman numeral. This MS abbreviation appears only with ".iiii." (six times) and would seem to be validated by line 6271, when in a prayer Christ arose after 4 days; and in line 11057, where four men are chosen as electors for the king to replace Charles Martel, and listed immediately thereafter. Furthermore, the "m" in lines 9334 and 11496 has no final upstroke.
86] ster: seems to here be a conjugated verb. Cf forms stent and ster (these last as infinitives) in the poem.
97] sorage: 'brother-in-law' (T-L serorge)
106] MS: Une hostel; T 106 reads una chasa che Ynida la vite de longo [that Ynide saw from afar], a similar original might be the reason for the agreement error.
109] End of Holtus's diplomatic transcription ("Considerazioni").
111] End of Tobler's edited selection ("Berliner").
136] All text that is written above the line in the original is enclosed in parentheses in this transcription.

139] MS is missing a word for "horse"; since the phrase is a fixed formula (see lines 1182, 7290, 7297), here we insert "civals" to accord with two of the other three uses of "crenu" and its forms. "Destrer" would be another possibility.

167]There seems to be a problem with this line. In B "lou" normally means either 'place' (MSF lieu) or 'the' (MSF le). Here, however, a verb seems to be missing; perhaps, similarly T 168: luy et Ugon, this should be "lu o," 'he with'. For modern readers, the sentence has been reordered: qui = there; ou = with; lou = when (col. 14); literally, it would be "There with Bernard, the son of John the warrior, Held court when Huon the knight...".

168]timbre: this is a psaltery, not what one normally expects for a call to fight, is the first definition (Matsumura). However, one also finds 'drum' and 'tamburine' (T-L, col. 307). Perhaps there is a metathesis of the "r" for "t[r]ombe"; T 169: el feze i lifante e le cinbale sonare
185] chacer: the first 'c' has a red x within the loop.
200] This line is problematic for sense; the Turin version is also unclear.
231] pis: the reading is clear in the MS; yet see T 230: fora solamente quando el vole dal re lo presio [except when he saw the valor of the king].
234] T 233 does not include this wording: anzé se fereno de coro e de fede [they hit each other spiritedly and in good faith]; pis: T-L piz, "Brust des Menschen" [human chest]).
245] reuser: reculer (Matsumura). Cf. GdA, 'rovesciare, respingere' [to knock over, push back]

262] Laisse 10: the metrics of this laisse seem to required that the final -re be counted as an atonic syllable as in Italian, or a unstressed -e in a "lyric" caesura, which makes almost all lines regular. We have therefore counted it consistently so. This is like unstressed feminine -e endings elsewhere in the poem, as in the following laisse. See Introduction, part D, Versification.

302] de Costance: this is consistently the form of a proper noun in Franco-Italian, referring to either a person or a place; of 13 appearances in this spelling in RIALFrI, 4 are a place ("de Costance") and 4 are a woman's name (the other five are all from Brunetto Latini's Trésor, a moralizing work); all four of the forms "Costançe" are a place name ("de Costançe") (consulted 7 December 2021). All are objects or people from a place (l'elme de...; cité de ...; neç de...; l'or de...; paile de...; Ervi de...). Repertoires of place names in chansons de geste suggest either Coutances (Manche, Normandy) or the German town of Konstanz (in Baden Württemberg, southern Germany). There is also a Constanţa in eastern Romania, worth mentioning here given the extent of Huon's travels and Scythia's fame for horses. There are only two uses here and they are in rhyme for the origin of a horse both times; cf. 8606 below.
320] engoler: Cf. Holtus Aliscans v. 7560.
321] tornoier: cf. Gambino, "Code-mixing nel Bovo d'Antona," p. 79, tornier.

339] engajer: engage, as security, in case of misbehavior; cf. Guiron, https://www.rialfri.eu/rialfriPHP/public/testo/testo/ordinata/ot|rialfri|guironMarciano|001|12229/query/l#mark, 15 August 2022; EE, engajés, engajees, also RIALFrI, 15 August 2022.

343] MS: nolōns. Cf. T 340 che da nesun homo no[n] abiamo nula y[m]pazo [so that we have no hindrance from anyone (lit., any man)]. The use of -on(s) for first person plural is typical in F-I; cf. AdB, vol. 3, pp. 154-55, thus ons for avoir. Cf. Rohlfs ¶ 541 for northeastern Italy.
393] enmue: sight rhyme; T-L enmüir (= amüir), 'verstummen' [to become silent, fall silent]
402] vancel: see T-L vanerie; cf. Petit Robert vanne (dated 1274).
405] For the forms glese, glesse, glesie, see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 341).
415] MS: ia belist. belist is a hapax. Elsewhere in the text, we find abellir; abelist; abelli, e.g., 4168, 6320, etc.
419] Cf. T 416 saludò ley dizendo: "Quel magno Redentore [he greeted her saying, "That great Redeemer..."]

439-440] These two lines have a special handle at the start, a sort of manicule, in red before 439, in blue before 440 (see Clemens and Graham, Manuscript Studies, p. 44-45). There is a note in the left margin before them, between the two, that reads .not. with a line above that has a little hump in it just past the middle (folio 4R, to the left, 10-11 lines from the bottom of the written column): "notat", commenting on the proverbial expression (Capelli, Dizionario, p. 240, for "not" with an abbreviation line).

498] gamentoit: Cf. EE, gaumenter (T-L gaimenter), but also 9746 here, "gamenta de soit" [he complained of thirst]. It is possible that this is a combination of "gemere" (to weep, lament) that DELI dates before Dante, before 1321, plus "lamentare," or possibly with a frequentative created on "gemito," the past participle of "gemere."
508]There is a "+" in the right margin in light brown ink, perhaps inserted by a nineteenth-century reader? See also note to v. 545.
533] MS: hastivement: there seems to be a problem with the tradition at this point; T reads (according to Rajna) "studevelmente."
542] MS: gamēt, with a side-ways "u" over "g" toward the "m"
542] There is an "X" to the left of the beginning of this line. It is not clear whether that refers to this line, or to the line in the previous column, v. 508.

549] atent: this has been one of the most discussed lexical items between French and Italian speakers. In Italian "attenere" (DELI, intransitive, beg. 14th century) is defined as 'spettare, concernere', and is clearly the meaning here: 'belong to you, concern you'

565] de lor (MS le lor): While le lor does appear in the MS, it is generally as a possessive pronoun or adjective, and never appears elsewhere after afor/afors or related preposition/adverb. Cf. T560: e possa guardò avante, luy no[n] li vite afora lor [and then he looked forward, he didn't seen anyone there except them]. While T is not always the best guide, nor always exactly consonant with B, it offers a good possibility in this line. It also works with the versification.
610] Alternate reading: si l'afier spiera, "if they suspect the affair/event"; cf. T 605: se l'afar spiarà [if he hears of the affair/event].
616] a Deu plest: cf. T 611 se a Dio piaze bon [con]seio se trovarà [if it pleases God, good advice will be found]. The line is short one syllable, so the emendation is logical.
660] loër: T-L col 566, gewähren [grant, accord]
669] MS missing the abbreviation mark here in acoplir; cf. Vv. 1271, 1282, etc.
674] The MS is difficult to read: 'r' of complira is unclear. It would seem that there is something above the line, but the section is faded. T 669: acompirà [will fulfill].

701] le jugor: T 696 vuy dovite esere signore lo mazore [and you should be the greatest lord]. The B line seems an odd form; vigor would not make sense in this section, though at first glance that seems to be the reading. Elsewhere vigor clearly paired with force in a synonymic pair (vv. 936, 1838, 11743, 11929) or used after a preposition to indicate strength (vv. 6897, 9094).

704] These lines are difficult to understand. In T 699, the verb is in the second plural, and "vuy" is the subject: a drito dovite esere vuy de lor suo pastore [by right you should be their pastor/lord]. Perhaps it can be best understood as an aside to the councillors present. See the note in the translation.
715] la added for sense and syllable count; cf. T: 709 lizeramente la porite vuy possa avere.

751] pregant: the "g" has an unusual form; it looks more like a "y." The syllable count is 7+6; T 745 devotamente pregando Dio ch'el guarde da torme[n]to [devotedly praying [to] God that He guard him from torment], one might omit mal (torment being bad by definition) to reduce to 7+5.

752] e hescïant: Turin reads a bona fede e yntenzione, "with good faith and intention"; other appearances of a (h)esiant/ (h)esient here are a preposition with a noun, "knowingly, with good intention." One is tempted to suggest an oral interference here, and if there were no h-, we could render 'ê scïant' to indicate elision.
759] MS: alot; probably missing the abbreviation for "n"; cf. lines 1013, 7909, for forms of "aler" plus the present participle; so here would read alon t devisant, 'as they were setting up'.
779] This is an extremely long line (6+10 or 11+5), though equal in meaning and form to that in Turin (773). It seems almost to be two lines run together; the hemistich divider is after tëre.

782] habit': this is the only appearance of the abbreviation after t in this MS. It is difficult to know how to resolve the abbreviation; the apostrophe is a generic sort of abbreviation (see list in the introduction). The line is quite long, 4+8 without resolving it. The only form of habit* as a noun that appears within a line (that is, not in rhyme) is habitance, which appears 8 times, 3 not in rhyme and 5 in rhyme. Habite only appears as the 'clerical habit' so we resolve habit[ance], though not without hesitation, making the line 4+10 syllables, or 4+9 if synalepha between qi en is presumed.

790] MS: empial. Cf. vv. 47, 73, 373, etc., where we see emp[er]ial. However, see empir in the PP (v. 4970) and the many other variants. As one of the most frequent words in epic vocabulary, it is greatly varied in rhyme. Furthermore, in Italian, "empio" means "irreligioso, sacrilego, profanatore" and "spietato, crudele" (Zingarelli) so while there is the hint of emperor, there is also the sense of merciless, sacrilegious ruler.
802] seinté: this seems to be a combination of "seinté" and "è," 'holiness is'.

810] m'en: the n is very evidently effaced, while all the other letters around it are clear; it is not evident whether or not the effacement is deliberate or the result of moisture, thus we include it.
818] MS: abosdivoir. Cf. EE: bosdeor; GdA: bosder, bosdeor, bosdera, bosdie, etc.; Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 237-38).
843] MS: lencline; T 837 Lo [con]te s'enclina e baso-ly li pedy alora [The count bowed and then kissed his [the king's] feet]
888] MS: confortas ɾoe
923] Tutore: cf. www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/tuttora_(Enciclopedia-Dantesca)/. Typical of Old Italian, found in Dante, the Fiore, etc. Consulted Nov. 26, 2016.

947] T 940-41 Sì de zò molto pasa el zorno el sol devala /se questo derite, a le mie man morerite. [If about this much passes the day, the sun goes down / if you tell this, you will die at my hands.] MS: peust le ior. This seems to be a case of a missing abbreviation mark on the downstroke of the p; parue, paruit, parut each appear in the MS twice and four of those times with a designation of day (l'aube (v. 6051); le jor serin (12219); le dis (7141); en cil jorner (11714)), making this verb, 'to appear', the most logical emendation. The only time peusent appears (6586) is as a modal verb, a form of pouvoir. The section was clearly problematic also for T.
941] baor: cf. T-L "baudor" (col. 887), with lenition of the intervocalic occlusive.

9452] hor cf. T-L "or, ëur," cols. 1163-64; Matsumura "or2, eur"; but T 945: che cosa'l era, no[n] l'averia fato p[er] l'or d'una tore [what he was, not for the gold of a tower], that is, not for anything would the servant have gone toward (what seemed to be) the beggar.
954] MS: il che. Alternate reading: ch'e il diable traïtor. / Le ont... (that he is the traitor devil. / They chased him out...).
960] Note the Italianate construction of definite article + possessive.
977] haïr: this could be haïr, anger, but we are interpreting it as "air" to go with the Turin reading and also the sense here: out the window and into the air, the sky.

1019] biendir appears in the Modern Italian "benedire" (documented before 1321, Dante, DELI), 'invocare la protezione divina su qc. o su q.c.' [to invoke divine protection on something or someone] ; and (documented before 1306 in Jacopone, DELI), 'lodare, esaltare' [to praise, exalt]. This appears a total of nine times in the MS; elsewhere, one finds 'to speak well' or a similar construction (see vv. 2196, 2674, 4244, 7392, 7274, 8173, 8483, 8727), which we distinguish by representing as two separate words.
1032] amaistra; cf. Roques, CR Wunderli, 'amaistrer', p. 538.
1041] Ni anch portant: 'anch' inserted in "neportant" (T-L col. 593; cf. Matsumura "néanmoins").

1062] This laisse is included in Tobler, p. 615. He does not always resolve abbreviations as here, always using "n" for the titulus indicating a nasal. There are no substantial differences in transcription.

1092] Caton: here refers to the Distichs of Cato, Disticha catonis: Quote from Catonis distichorum, Book 1, 8: Nil temere uxori de servis crede querenti; Saepe enim mulier, quem coniux diligit, odit [Believe nothing blindly of a wife complaining about the servants; For often a wife hates the one the husband likes]. Text and translation provided by Jim Marchand at http://faculty.georgetown.edu/jod/texts/distich.trans.html.

1149] la between quāt and non is almost unreadable in the manuscript. The deletion seems to be intentional, with something painted over those letters, similar to a spot on the left side of the page of a chocolate or cafeaulait color.
1152] Catchword at the bottom of the page, almost entirely washed out:si
1159] There are three other forms (aflicions twice, aflicion once), all in rhyme position. Therefore I here presume aflicion as the base form, here elided with the preposition a.

1171] This line differs from T 1159-60: che y[n]nverso Ongaria cavalcha forte /doloroso e pensava, "zà no[n] fo sỳ prodomo" [who rode toward Hungary very sad and thought, "there was never a good man so [sad]"].

1174] Vulgate Psalm 118, v. 133: "Gressus meos dirige." All translations of the Bible are taken from The New Oxford Annotated Bible with Apocrypha (Expanded version), Revised Standard Version (NY: Oxford UP, 1977). There it is Psalm 119, p. 753, with translation given in this translation.
1180] Transcribed by Tobler, lines 1180-1220 (pp. 615-16). We note any substantial differences here. As noted above, his resolution of abbreviations differs; thus, "Par moy" for line 1218, etc.

1183] Ongrie: in the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries, the Anjou cultivated an aura of holiness, and that included their Hungarian branch. Charles I of Anjou's second wife, Marguerite of Burgundy-Tonnerre, retired to Tonnerre in 1285 at her husband's death and founded a hospital there, where she, with two relatives, did works of charity and participated in prayer. Marie of Hungary (1257-1323), the wife of Charles I's son, Charles II (the Lame), also had a reputation for religious devotion, contributing to convents and churches. Her daughter Margaret married Charles of Valois and thus co-founded the Valois dynasty; the French monarchy was cultivating their holy links through the Capets, Anjou, and Plantagenets, so as part of the origins of the French royal dynasty, Hungary fits with Jerusalem and Rome as part of Huon's pilgrimage route.
1204] estiers, esters: outside of (T-L col. 1394, 'außer', 'outside of, beyond')

1250] Between lines 1249 and 1250 in column 9Va, running into the right margin is a line with an "x"; also at the bottom of column 9va, there is a line with a corresponding "x" in the left margin. Since the column is one line too long in comparison to the other, and normally the columns are equal, this final line (1264) is clearly to be moved to the position between 1249 and 1250.
1276] MS: une jors
1281] bu: 'chest' (buc, bus, bru, T-L col. 1184, 'Rumpf"); Matsumura, "bu, buc, bus, bru," 'tronc du corps' [trunk of the body] (Matsumura); cf. GdA, "bochon," "petto" [chest]
1282] aïst âcomplir for 'aidast a acomplir'
1295] This laisse is also transcribed by Tobler (pp. 616-17); again we note any substantial differences of transcription.

1300] This line is problematic; we are interpreting as a separated future (ti ho dire = ti dirò). T has difficulties with it as well, with a substantial difference in reading: v. 1287 Se zò mantene che tu ai dito i[n] to s[er]mone [If you continue that which you have said in your speech]; cf. diroy (vv. 1246, 1944, 2422, 2448), in rhyme position.
1316] aast: from aätir, 'défier, attaquer, engager' (Matsumura); cf. Legendario di Lion, RIALFrI, ahast, consulted 21 August 2022. T-L aatir, cols. 31-33.
1329] Tobler: uoire / non poit. MS: voie
1356] MS: tot. This section is difficult to read; the initial of the following line seems to have been changed from a "T" to a "C."
1361] "Sir désigne la ville de Tyr, puisque les tissus d'Orient étaient réputés et ... l'on indique volentiers une ville d'Orient comme lieu d'où provient un tissu précieux" (JCV).
1377] 7 poy 7 mon: there is a light line drawn through this second hemistich in the MS. The entire line is a repeat of line 1372; perhaps the editor was wishing to remove the entire line?

1390] MS: aīam; since Cappelli gives a variety of abbreviations for forms of Lat. ANIMA, we resolve to the standard text, though there is one abbreviation line only (Cappelli, p. 12: āīō for 'animo'; aīe for 'animae', etc.). The Latin "Magnificat" text reads, "Magnificat anima mea Dominum," "My soul magnifies the Lord" (Luke 1, 46-55). Here the scribe (or redactor/author) says, "Magnify my soul, O Lord."

1399] MS: ma[n]da na, however it seems most likely to be an error for "via[n]da na"; cf. line 6181 viande n'a and T 1382 de pan [et] d'aqua vita altra vianda non à. For vianda, see Gambino, "Code-mixing nel Bovo d'Antona udinese," p. 79.
1425] da soe mo[r]t da nos n'e[r]t ... Odd structure: perhaps there was an error in the redactor's transcriptions?
1466] si: cf. the form found in Romagna and Veneto "si"; Lombardy "sé" (Rohlfs, ¶ 540).
1482] Cf. T 1471 A questa parola molty de loro l'asaltone [At this word, many of them attacked him/assaulted him]
1523] Celor: the initial is an unusual shape, between a "C" and an "L."
1539] bosdie: cf. EE, trickery, fraud (T-L col. 1032, boisdie)
1541] MS: q eloiaute; an nseems to be elided, which would have read: Q'en loiauté
1559] chareme: interpreted as "carême," 'fasting'.
1566] in men: MS mein, saut du même au même. Cf. T 1561 asay te'n credo donare i[n]nazo d'un messe [I think to give you so much before a month (is up)]
1577] Note lack of sight rhyme here.
1667] In the rhyme position, the verb "savoir" takes this unusual form.

1698] MS: riponse; cf. forms of reponser (v. 2505, 2690, etc.). Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," notes a possible analogue to this episode in Renaut de Montauban, where a local citizen informs the knight that the city is besieged by Saracens (pp. 18-19). That similarity is continued in that both refuse to rule the kingdom and each is sent further on, Huon to the Holy Sepulcher and Renaut to Brindisi.

1703] la vent: "vent" in this MS normally is either a noun ('wind'), a form of "vendre" ('to sell'), or a form of "venire" ('to come'). Here it is clearly neither a noun nor a form of "vendre"; it seems to be either a form of "to go" (like Italian "andare a" or French "aller"+ infinitive [Ménard, notes that this occurs only in Middle French, p. 133]), or an error of "n" for "u" (veut for 'want'), since the connector is clearly above. In either case, the meaning is clear: they are not giving up the city.
1707] MS: constatinople
1711] MS: afie đs (crossed 'd' and long 's' above the line between 'a' and 'f')
1726] glorie: this is the most frequent form in the text when the word is written out; even with the resolution "gloire" the syllable count is high.
1741] a force: forcefully, by force (T-L col 2066); in the case of movement, as here, that would mean 'quickly', thus our translation.
1748] trainé here is the infinitive, missing the final -r ; that is how T understood the line. Alternatively it could be v'oit trainé, "the kings had there dragged before them."

1749] The MS is damaged at this point and extremely difficult to read, but the digital copy clarifies the reading; the tradition was problematic, since T's reading is quite different: morty zasere al sabione dead men lying on the sand. If the reading here were similar, it might be hon veit sor ce gravois; but the two are not always parallel. Gravoy appears appears five times, gravois once, meaning "sand" or "gravel" in some way (path, etc.) in this MS.
1765] del mois: cf. RIALFrI, EE 10188, 10668; GdA, vol. 2, Book 15, v. 2958.
1765] a force: forcefully, by force (T-L col 2066); in the case of movement, as here, that would mean 'quickly', thus our translation.
1790] somon: from "semoner" (semoner, semosner T-L, col. 418); cf. Rohlfs ¶ 137, labialization of a pretonic vowel.
1798] guioner: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 346), "guide"
1805] abravis: cf. Rinoldi, "Primi sondaggi", p. 43, abravé, referring to Holtus's Lexikalische.
1807] esclaris: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 307), re esclarir and the change of conjugation in Franco-Italian.
1827] coroi: see T-L conroi, col. 716
1830] MS: giat

1855] Note that this column is one line shorter than the following, and there is a flag rising from the illumination below into the column. This poses interesting questions as to the order in which the work was done.
1881] MS: nos; possibly from distraction of line above, "nos homage"
1910] enci: cf. Holtus ( Lexikalische p. 290), "ici," 'here'
1914] MS: et. The word et seems out of place here; we emend to e' (for "I"). Cf. T 1911, Homo sonto de Carlo Martelo [I am Charles Martel's man].

1965] faigeç: from "fatiguer" (Matsumura); cf. Vv. 10652, 11142. T 1960: che vuy l'avite fadigà duramente. The following line is not present in T; in B there it is not clear whether we should read nos or vos.

1975] Note the theme of a vow while on a quest; his ancestor, Guillaume d'Orange, vowed not to change his clothes, wash his hair, eat meat or stew; he won't drink wine or liquor, kiss anyone, or sleep in a bed, until he returned home with Guibourc; he too drinks only water and eats only rough bread (Aliscans; for an English translation, see Ferrante). Guillaume will be Huon's guide in Hell, as we will see.
2022] Turin differs substantially here: se luy lassa ora, el parerà a questo ponto [if he leaves now, it will be evident at this point] (T 2015).
2111] This line is missing from Turin. It is problematic; everywhere else in this MS "sovent" is an adverb; however "sovenir" appears as well as other forms of the verb.

2115] Between les and afi at the end of the line is a hole in the MS; afi seems to be written deliberately after it; there does not seem to be any letter missing. J.-C. Vallecalle suggests that it might have been an a there possibly scraped off?, making the line read Posible çonse il fust, bien le sai a fi, that is, "This [Huon's mission in Hell] would be possible, I know certainly (... if Hell were built on earth)."

2130] The original reading of the text may have been gieter , for "how to shoot a bow"; or this may be a form of "guerrer" to fight, since many Franco-Italian texts have forms of "gere" and "gerer" for MF 'guerre' and 'guerrier'.
2142] MS: une hom (emended)
2145] MS seems to be missing the abbreviation for n:m'acontent; cf. v. 747
2152] See Turin 2126: Se p[er] devin miraclo non m'avene[If by divine miracle doesn't happen to me]
2154] These 6 lines are very difficult to read due to the ink being worn.
2159] aquitier: there are 16 forms beginning with aquit- (and one other following d') compared to 9 that are clearly quit-, so we have divided those following d as beginning with the vowel.
2175] MS: resont with a caret below to insert a tiny p written above the line.
2186] n and u are frequently very similar in the MS. Ansi is perhaps also possible or intended.
2195] MS: Bout
2196] biendir: see note, line 1019.
2197] For the construction in genoillon, see Holtus (Lexikalische pp. 338-39).
2208] galon: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische p. 334), "côté," 'side'
2230] With 2227 the prayer moves to the New Testament; Simeon is in Luke 2, 25-35.

2431] Nunc dimittis: beginning of the Canticle of Simeon, said in services of evening worship such as Compline, Vespers, and Evensong. The full verse is 'Nunc dimittis servum tuum, Domine, secundum verbum tuum in pace,' "Lord, now lettest thou thy servant depart in peace, according to thy word." Luke 2, 29-32.
2232] Lazarus appears in John 11, 1-44.

2233] Te Deum laudamus: "Thee, o God, we praise" is the beginning of the so-called Ambrosian hymn, authorship attributed to Ambrosius or Augustine, traditionally ascribed to the fourth century CE. The name can also refer to a religious service of thanks, as seems to be the case here. The second half of the first verse of the hymn, 'te Dominum confitemur,' "we acknowledge thee to be the Lord," seems to be echoed in the following line here, as does the general context of the hymn to save His people. The hymn was traditionally sung at the end of Matins.
2244] âbandon="a abandon"
2258] See note, v. 2232.

2315] enfler: to inflate, swell up (T-L col. 340). See also Morlino, "Nuovi contributi," p. 409 'flés'. With six further appearances here (vv. 2541, 2700, 7093, 9340, 9503), the verb is an established part of the poem's lexicon.

2319] This line is problematic: T does not have an equivalent. Turin 2306 reads, "né ponto el [con]te né quily ch'era [con] luy," 'not at all the count nor those who were with him', so with a different initial (in fact in Berlin, the initial "L" is odd; it could be an "N" with a short initial upstroke. In that case, it would be something like 'Nor did Huon cease to pray.' However, nowhere else in the text is there a "Ne pas" in this sort of structure.

2320] ne laist: there seems to be a missing pronoun here– or some other error. "Ne" can be the first person plural object pronoun, but would require changes to direct discourse: qu' "il ne ne laist periler," possibly because of a saut du même au même. Turin has a slightly different version, with a change to direct discourse in the following line and the verbs in first person plural– but also with an object pronoun in the line equivalent to this (T 2307-08).

2329] bonacer: cf. bonaçay (v. 2703), both verb forms; T-L and other OF dictionaries have only the noun or the adjective for a calm sea, or calmness. Cf. Roques, CR Wunderli, p. 539, where he comments upon bonaze, the noun. All the forms that appear in RIALFrI (2 April 2022) are also nouns or adjectives: bonaçe, bonaze.
2358] T-L comunable, "Besitzgenosse", so we interpret this as the companions ("Genosse") of his domain ("Besitz").
2362] Psalm 50 of the Vulgate, modern Psalm 51, verse 3: "Have mercy on me, O God," a psalm requesting, among other things, "Let the bones which thou hast broken rejoice" (8).
2384] Veriteç appears twice (5504, 11099) and veritere once (6308) to one verté (8736), so we resolve here as we do.

2393] MS: loge. T: fora la bona fede e la crosse ch'el adorava (v. 2379). Visibly, "loge" doesn't seem to fit the rhyme of the laisse, - oie, but it is "loe" or "lie" from "louer," to praise, and the sense follows Turin. See the introduction on -ge- (cf. Wunderli, AdB, vol. 1, p. LIV, number 8, whose contention loge would seem to prove, that it is merely another spelling for the standard conditional ending; Mainone, Formen, p. 15, section e. "Conditionnel" [sic]).
2397] croie: cf. EdE v. 6868 (cf. Matsumura, croi from * CRODIOS germ).
2406] oie: could be either a form of "avoir" or perhaps of "oloir" palatalized referring to the odor; in either case, the following line has it rising to heaven.

2407] romanirin this text there are two meanings for forms of "remanoir" that go beyond the literal "to stay, to remain" for the verb (for the second, see note for v. 4892). Both occur with a negative particle; here, it is similar to the Provençal usage (see DOM (Dictionnaire de l’ancien Provençal) http://www.dom-en-ligne.de/dom.php?lhid=6oTVIO3tVKX8BQ8h6i5hNd, consulted 7 July 2021), "d. r. [en, per alcun] 'être empêché, ne pas avoir lieu [par la faute, par la volonté de qn]', 'to fail, be stopped'; cf vv. 3577, 4023, 4727, 4939, 5295, 5307. For the pretonic -o, see Rohlfs ¶135, "Labializzazione di una vocale pretonica."

2412] MS: aveit a bone foy, which seems to be a MS error with either an extraa(he had good faith or he went in good faith) or perhaps a u for an n (aneit as some form of "andare"), though there is no such form listed in RIALFrI for other Franco-Italian texts. Cf. Turin, "vene a bona fede, and here, vv. 1954, 2421, 7534, 8535. With the emendation, the line is 6+5.
2433] nos: Final letter is an odd shape; could be noç
2440] The phrase sans poy appears to be equivalent to "sans plus", "without adding anything further."
2446] We believe thatsavra is like the use of MSI "sapere," 'to taste': "it seems (it tastes) like..."

2491] coraïe: this and the following line are problematic; T 2475: Avante che lor prendano tera serano molty corezate [Before they land, they will be very angry], but in the next line of T there is another verb, "perderano," "they will lose." So here in B either there is a verb missing in the next line or this is the verb. See translation for a possible meaning.
2449] Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," pp. 19-20, compares these Laisses 93-96 to the Roman d'Alexandre (ed. Harf-Larcner), pp. 464-69.
2500] Compare T 2484: grande e derupossa p[er]ché ponto son li agradise[great and craggy for which reason he didn't like it at all] . EE has "graïr," but this form doesn't appear in RIALFrI.

2514] hagne: palatalization, "aigne" (lenition of the intervocalic occlusive, b>v>Ø, HABERE>avere>aer; 3rd plural àn + supporting vowel, the n is palatalized); see Rohlfs Morphology, ¶ 541, for the 3rd pl of the present indicative; the same stem is presumed for the subjunctive.

2519] Brown ink through theor of d[e]morr[re]. mal has a line above it; it is not the standard abbreviation for r or vowel + r, and there are no other abbreviations with l, so its resolution is not immediately evident.

2526] T 2508 Lo lion pardo corse, la branca li taia [He ran the leopard [down], he cut off its paw]; brasche is not found in RIALFrI, yet appears four times here, always in reference to animal paws (after this, vv. 2920, 3264, 6380). Modern Italian is "branca," but dialect forms of 'arm' (MSI braccio, braccia) in Rohlfs ¶ 275 include braso for Venetian, brašu for western Lombardy, and braš or bras for Milan. This would then seem to be a confluence of branca and braccio forms. Holtus cites cites brançe as a Franco-Italian form for 'paw' (Lexikalische, pp. 239-40). Since all four appearances here are missing the n, the form seems intended and not a scribal error. MS: aterer; the other two appearances in this MS as one word are both infinitives after a form of faire, whereas terrer appears in v. 1708 as a noun, so we construe this also as a noun in rhyme position, MF 'a terre', 'on the ground'.
2545] Note the rhyme not for sight here. The form "stanch" appears also in the EE and AdB, so this seems evidently a deformation for the rhyme, and demonstrates that the final sound was - n.

2566] Compare T 2542: Quando e∙l vede avrire la gola ch'el vede el fogo apredre [When he saw the throat open so that he saw the fire lighting up]; B seems to be understanding vait for both verbs, baër and esprenda[n]t.
2591] See v. 2702 re the term maroy (more frequently written marois).

2602] T has understood this differently, line 2584: "I praise [him] willingly (with good heart)." This could also be the meaning here, in which case the preceding line would end with a comma instead of a semicolon.
2611] l'asent: this could also be il la sent, "he felt it" and so T understands it: molta greve la trova, v. 2593.
2614] M: lö tēptz. This seems to be an unusual case of assonance alone, not rhyme.
2622] After tost, scratched out letter in the MS.

2642-44] De profundis clamavi ad te Domine / Domine, exaudi vocem meam: Vulgate Psalm 129, modern Psalm 130, "Out of the depths I cry to thee, o Lord! / Lord, hear my voice!" mixed with Psalm 101/102 (where verse 2 is "Domine, exaudi orationem meam") or Psalm 142/143, where verse 2 begins with that same appeal, "Hear my prayer, Lord." They are all three among the penitential psalms. Similarly, Psalm 141/142, verse 6 reads "Clamavi ad te, Domine" [I cry to thee, o Lord].
2646] MS: 7 la tēre sestent

2709] anoiay: here, 'to drown', but note similarity to 'anoier' (v. 3415), 'anoiere' (v. 3371), 'anoié' (v. 2713), to irritate, bother, disturb (cf. ModFr ennuyer); see Roques, CR Wunderli, p. 538, anogier, both lemmas.
2735] boce: cf. line 1281

2642] De profundis clamavi ad te Domine / Domine, exaudi vocem meam: Vulgate Psalm 129, modern Psalm 130, "Out of the depths I cry to thee, o Lord! / Lord, hear my voice!" mixed with Psalm 101/102 (where line 2 is "Domine, exaudi orationem meam") or 142/143, which begins with that same line: "Hear my prayer, Lord." They are all three among the penitential psalms.
2670] Eripe me [de inimicis meis], Deus: Psalm 58/59, verse 2, "Deliver me [from my enemies], O my God"; it is also a verse 9 from Psalm 142, seen above, one of the seven penitential psalms.
2674] bendir: see note, v. 1019.
2681] There is a letter scratched out after il before atant. This folio in general has many corrections.
2684] si stoit: they had to, they needed to; cf. T 2665: Quando lo zorno li mancha se ly coventa albergare.

2687] li jorner: This expression can mean "journey" or "day" in Old French. In Italian, it might have that meaning (DELI, 13th century), but "day" is the first and more frequent meaning. It is difficult to say which is intended here.
2689] ge inserted above the line.

2702] marois: in OF this is defined as "swamp," but that is problematic for this text. For the difficulty of "marois," here, and possible meanings, see Morgan, "Cent ans de franco-italien : du Huon d’Auvergne de 1341 au Huon d’Auvergne de 1441."
2719] doine: this is a hapax, perhaps a scribal error for "dame" that appears 193 times. Cf. T line 2700, done, 'women'.

2733] As frequently occurs where there is a syntactic or lexical problem, this line does not appear in T. The initial "A" causes a problem, since it would seem that their behavior/appearance demonstrates that they are afraid; without it, there is no subject stated for the sentence. We presume that the verb is plural, as in the following lines.

2745] Stengel's review of Brockstedt includes this laisse in a note, pp. 160-61 for the Berlin text. He uses square brackets for additions, parentheses for things he believes should be omitted. Included here are lines where he does either. Not noted are differences in uses of written accents.

2747] Stengel (Review, p. 160): ce q(e)'armés; this line caused a problem in comprehension; see T 2727: p[er]zò che lagreme li vedeno asay zitare, totally different from our meaning [because they saw him weeping many tears].
2749] Stengel (Review, p. 161): len
2751] Stengel (Review, p. 161): esciant, as usual. Not further remarked.
2755] Stengel (Review, p. 160): [e]n est

2757] Note the use of n here for "nous" (ne before vowel) object form. This is typical of early Italian texts. See Rohlfs 2 (Morfologia), ¶ 460. This is a legal formula meaning in the presence of witnesses. Stengel notes the appearance of Drusiant, a character in the Bovo story, in this laisse, but also that the King of Dalmatia in this line is not in the Bovo story, where Macabrun (sic) replaces him, but in Bueve (French version) he plays a role in freeing Josienne (Bovo's Drusiana). The Bovo story is complicated by many versions in the European tradition; see Morgan, GF pp. 76-105, for a comparison of the versions. There is no clear link between that Drusiana and this princess here.
2761] âutre: for 'a autre'
2764] Stengel (Review, p. 160): Qu(e)'aveque
2769] Stengel (Review, p. 161): par ameç; cf. T-L 180-183 (par13)
2771] Stengel (Review, p. 161): enavant
2777] Stengel (Review, p. 161): E [va]
2778] Stengel (Review, p. 161): (por)forma
2780] Stengel (Review, p. 161): atant
2781] Stengel (Review, p. 161): Ansi; there is clearly a cross-stroke at the line between the two downstrokes.
2784] Stengel (Review, p. 161): Yesu. However the MS reads yh'u (with the apostrophe over the "h").
2786] Stengel (Review, p. 161): desor voil... davant
2787] Stengel (Review, p. 161): Hoi, biau

2789] MS: Lort; the final letter seems to be an anticipation of the following word's final letter. T: Alora se ne vene al maro [...]; however, the word also appears in the EdE (v. 1767), seemingly in a similar way; initial position with the same meaning.

2796] End of the selection transcribed in Stengel's review. "Valence"(and variants) is a well-known female name as well as a city name; cf. Foucon de Candie (RIALFrI), and also heroine of a lost romance, Seguin and Valensa (cf. "A chantar m'er de so qu'ieu no volria" by Beatriz de Dia, v. 10, and Arnaut de Marueil,"Tant m'abellis e.m plaz" (v. 166). anomé: cf. Roques, CR Wunderli, 'anomés', p. 538, where he also gives the two meanings, 'named' and 'renowned', as here v. 7794.
2805] ên: e(t) + e + en, "and he is in"; cf. T 2784: che Dio abia marzede de luy [et] i[n] drito sentero li mande [that God have mercy on him and send him on the right path].

2806] This line is problematic; it is not logical that Huon asks the women what to do next. In fact, in the Turin MS, it is they who ask him: T 2875: Como la faremo?" le done al [con]te domandano ["How will we proceed?" the ladies asked of the count]. Perhaps the line should be emeded: "Com la fareç, ami?"
2818] MS: ci ņait. Though the n is expunctuated, it seems to be necessary for the meaning; see translation.
2821] MS: vos vos pri ne mie: second vos and ne are expunctuated.
2829] MS: sb'teīr

2840] herbolant: we do not find this verb attested anywhere else. "Erber" appears in T-L (for the past participle, used with flavoring a drink) and Matsumura (both for the T-L meaning and for "faire paître"). The image is one of farm animals, eating grass in a pasture. There are other forms based upon HERB- and ERB- in this text, but no others like this one. At this date, there is no other occurrence in RIALFrI either (15 June 20121).

2854] See the illumination on the following page (f. 21R) for an illustration of the bill; "guie" is not clear in meaning; it is a hapax legomenon as a noun in this MS. The other six forms mean "he guides, leads." Thank you to Kelly DeVries who gave the name to the "pichon" as a weapon; see the "Additional Notes" for further information.
2880] MS: pelle. p with a line above is always p[re] and thus is so transcribed here.
2890] marois: see note, line 2702 above, and Additional Note
2905] mait: cf. GdA, 8, v. 2499 (from mener)
2909] Abbreviation line very light in the MS.
2911] MS "vait" seems to be a form of "valoir."

2928] T 2905: homo da ora i[n]nanzo me diraveno molto laido [one would call me very ugly from now on]. Could this be an error for "ne devroit" [At this point, he shouldn't harm a man greatly]? We accept the original as it follows relatively closely the Turin version.
2956] çausi: see Holtus, Lexikalische, p. 248: "GI çausir «distinguer, voir», got. KAUSJAN."
2961] dagier: probably omitted titulus for "dangier", which appears five times elsewhere in the MS. "Faire dangier", 'résister' (Matsumura); cf. T-L.
2976] sta: this seems to be acting as the auxiliary verb here instead of a form of "ester"
2991] le lor: this seems to be a nonce rhyme, possibly 'wolves', used as a stand-in for all the vermin attacking the lion, by attraction to the wolves attacking the shepherd's sheep in line 2987.

3015] fire: Mainone in both his volumes cites this as the infinitive "faire" (Formen, p. 28; Laut, p. 28). However, the syntax here would not support this being an infinitive, it must be a conjugated verb in the third person. It could still be a form of "faire" (cf. firent that appears as a "vicarious" verb, that is, one that takes the place of others (Mainone, Formen, p. 43); in this case then it would be an analogical. Firant appears 1 time, firent appears 28 times. The verb here refers in any case to combat(cf. Ménard, Manuel 1. Syntaxe, ¶¶ 63, 76, on the use of "qui" for "anyone" or "if anyone"); if a form of faire, this line would mean, "Ready to fight, if he finds anyone [any creature] who does it/any creature to do it" (i.e., to fight with him). See also T 2989: pare a luy ch'el [com]bata, s'el trova [con] chi la fare [it seems to him that he'll fight, if he finds someone with whom to do it]. This second sort of construction with the infinitive occurs still today in Italian, though in French a subjunctive would be required.

3032] rapegon: we are interpreting this as derived from RI + A + PLICARE (cf. MSI "piegare"); however, see T 3006: vene y[n] rampgon; see the illumination here at the bottom of folio 21v, where the lion is lowering its front half before Huon's sword. Missing tituli for nasals are frequent in Franco-Italian; since the first hemistich states he was afraid to rise, it has instead the more frequent meaning of modern French, 'to crawl', cf. T-L, kreichen, col. 259. Onson: cf. Wunderli, AdB (vol. 3, p. 297): "It. osare, Fr. oser: "The epenthetic n is typical of northern Italy, cf. oncir" (Trans. LZM).

3038] Asprosement: cf. T 3012 aprosimando a my, 'approaching me'. The B form seems to be a combination of some kind. prosimans appears in AdB as an adjective, Aspromont only as the placename; asprosmer appears in GdA. T then means, "Approaching me, he therefore shows [...]." However, asprose appears once in this text, in combination with ferement (v. 2550); aspre [rough] collocated with dure (v. 10915), and asprement (v. 10073), each, respectively, one time, so we therefore translate according to those related forms.
3046] alieç: CF T-L 278-279 alegier, "to be eased, lightened"; Folco di Candia> V19, v. 1581
3065] The laisse initial here has a face sketched into it.
3075] MS: sa seori; asseürer/s'asseürir (T-L cols. 589-592) or s'asseoir (T-L cols. 583-586)
3116] The "good companion" in the king of beasts contrasts with the king of men, Carlo Martello.
3158] quoy=coi="tranquille," T-L "still"; s'ora derives from orer "anwünschen"="wish"
3163] dela : "over there," not "by there," so one word. There are many appearances of this construction in rhyme position.
3171] MS: mont le sen (le expunctuated)

3179] sor: this is one of two appearance of the lexeme at rhyme position; the other is a toponym (v. 4613), which this is clearly not. Normally it is the preposition (from Lat. SUPER) followed by an object; it could here be an adverb with a similar meaning, and in T 3148: desopra (though the passage is somewhat different) reads thus. However, "sor" can also mean 'golden brown, reddish brown' (T-L from a Old Frankish *saur), especially of hair or horses, or, by extension, 'dry' or possibly 'dark' (as opposed to sunny), which is how the translator has rendered it here.
3193] segure: DELI scure, segure before 1292, derives from SECŪRE(M), Latin. One wonders if this is the otherwise unidentifiable "guie" mentioned above in 2853.
3200] Funny face drawn into the capital for this laisse, as for many in this section of the MS.
3223] ponsa: cf. Gambino, "Code-mixing nel Bovo d'Antona udinese," ponsier, p. 77.
3228] This version differs from Turin where it is the serpent that cries out.

3251]As Meregazzi notes, this section resembles the Roman d'Alexandre where Alexander finds a demon imprisoned and asks the way out (ed. Harf-Larcner, pp. 470-77; Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 20).

3257] derumeç: a verb with this form does not appear in OF, in OI, or in RIALFrI. However, "desrompre" in T-L, from DIRUMPERE (cf. various forms in RIALFrI), 'to break apart' and "deruinant", 'precipitous', (T-L desrüiner) both appear, and here some combination seems to come into play. Turin uses "butaremo zosa" [we'll throw down]. See then 3266, "l'en ont fait ruiner."

3262] Or va pur a giter. This is one case where the French and Italian constructions differ but the meaning is approximately the same: "by rolling he was going to move it" and "by rolling he was going to toss it."

3271] caverne: see Morlino, "Nuovi contributi," pp. 407-08. Here, as in the other two appearances in this text (vv. 3277, 3443) the meaning is clearly literal, rather than the figurative meaning attested in Aquilon. It is interesting, however, that all three appear only in this section of the text, whereas chave also appears three times in a later section (vv. 7166, 7345, 7869), and chavere in v. 2928.

3286] For this section, cf. Le Roman d'Alexandre, Branche III, laisses 160-162, part of the "Dangerous Valley" where Alexander confronts a demon in order to leave. (Harf-Lancner trans. of E. C. Armstrong, pp. 470-477).

3313] pois: this is the only time that the form ending in -s appears to be a third person singular form. Of all the "pois" forms (140 total), only 27 are verbs; these are either first or second person (cf. Mainone, Formen, p. 31, who lists all as first and second person singular, present indicative). There are no earlier editions of this segment (see Chart); it might be emended *poit that appears in 141 other lines here, or would need to be translated differently: "you might fail quickly," perhaps in the general sense of "one might fail quickly."
3319] Psalm 112/113, verse 1.
3320] The Latin seems to be a mixture of several Psalms; see in particular 148/149.
3354] Here Huon addresses the figure aloud.
3361] The MS seems to be missing the abbreviation for an "r" here: archiere, "archer," as in vv. 1710, 9216, 11662, 1204 archiers.

3383] Quilidés: At this point it is unclear to whom this might refer. One suggestion is that this might deriving from Bacchylides (ca. 518-ca. 451 BCE), a Greek lyric poet who was included in the list of nine lyric poets. Longinus, for example, praises him, which might account for his name being familiar if not his poems.
3398] This might be a reference to Dante's hell: those inside the walls of Hell (Canto 10) cannot see the present and see the future only dimly (10.94-105).
3408] Note that this column is shorter than most by one line: it is only 36 lines long.

3445] stropoit: a metathesis from Italian "storpiare": 'impedire', 'to hamper' attested 14th century (DELI). Two uses of an str- form are attested in other texts: Aliscans, stropez 'portare in esilio' (from 'storber'); and GdA, stropie, 'to rub' (from 'stroppicciare'), neither of which seem likely here.
3501] T 3461 mio padre siè morto longo tempo [my father has been dead a long time]

3503] MS: oi ge, with ge expunctuated, the g with a dot above, the e with dot both above and below. "Natural" i.e., from a liaison outside of marriage, and therefore not legally an heir (though a woman as an heir held varying positions through the eras and in different locations).

3506] MS: Moit veut. There seems to be a copying error here; perhaps some kind of saut, for "Mout me veut." T 3466: Mo vedite [now you see], is also problematic. See also EE (v. 13137) and GdA (v. I.IX.791) for the use of moit for 'mout'. One wonders if the redactor understood veut as a past participle, so that "M'oit voulu/M'a voluto" was understood.
3522] MS: lemme
3556] defoissé: cf. defois, T-L "Abwehr, Verteidigung", 'defense', though it gives no verb based upon it. Cfr. FEW "defensum."
3577] remandra: for meaning of this expression, see v. 2407.

3610] pormi: appears 11 times in this next, never abbreviated. Cf. Gambino, "Code-mixing nel Bovo d'Antona udinese" "permé," p. 76; parmi appears here 12 times, with two abbreviated forms (of the 'r' only).
3678] Emendation for MS nōs avōs; note the use of the first person plural as subject.
3686] MS: geste beste; ; cf. T 3650 my e questa bestia [I and this beast]

3691] The grammatical structure here is unclear; this is the only sere form in the text. The people (or their spokesperson) are using "tu" with Huon, so it seems unlike that this is "seré" = 'by us you will be honored'; perhaps this is the "tu" form. On the other hand, using a conjugated verb after a preposition is also unlikely; see Turin, "mostra-ne la via p[er]ché seremo tuty salve" [show us the way so that we will all be saved], where the conjunction is used. Thus we have left the line as is.
3728] Miserere: see note, line 2361.

3740] ferir: the meaning here is one that differs in OF and OI; while the OF meaning remains close to the Latin stem, with "schlagen, treffen" [strike, hit] (T-L, col. 1733), the Italian "ferire" diverged early to meaning "colpire causando una ferita" [to hit causing a wound] DELI 1219), "addolorare con atti e con parole" [to distress with deeds and words] DELI 1294), so this may mean a more general harm or punishment than striking the ex-pirates who had abandoned Huon to whatever might happen when he went exploring. There seems in fact to have been some confusion; see the reading of T 3703:cristiany sono ancora; gran ben far porano [They are still Christians; then can do great good], where the rest of the segment reads very similarly to B.
3750] Cf. T 3704: quando y[n] mia vita tanto ben fato averò [when, in my life, I will have done so well]
3763] si seiron could also read s'iseiron, "they went out"; there are no similar forms for "to sit," and Turin has them sitting down, "putting" themselves at the table.

3809] There is a confusion here and in the following lines between the number of people: Huon, Sanson and Anseis. Turin has eliminated Anseis so that the plot is simpler and the action easier to follow. Verbs and adjectives vary back and forth between singular and plural. It does seem that Huon and Sanson are the ones conversing here.
3838] alor could also read a lor, "to them." Cf. T 3801: a le soue done

3852] This is a very Italian episode; the city-states in the Peninsula regularly exiled members of a losing party, who then ran coups from neighboring cities. The Medicis, for example, in 1433, were exiled from Florence, only to return the following year after a change of government. The constant wars of the fourteenth century in the northern Italian Peninsula reflected the various parties representing different interests changing allies and strength.

3862] MS: e par: this line is problematic. T 3825 reads Ugon y[n]tende la parola p[er] un paisante [Hugon heard the dispute through a local person, or alternatively, a passer-by]. The sense would seem to indicate that Huon informs himself of the reason for the dispute by speaking with a local person. Whether the abbreviated "p" here in B indicates some form of parler with a missing "l" or not is not evident.There are no other forms of parler without the "l" so we are leaving the line as it stands.

3867] MS: mō: -o- was changed from -e- (the edge of the loop is still present) and there is a line to the right of the vowel not quite totally removed; while it is difficult to distinguish, it could have been a t; the scribe was evidently having difficulty here. See T 3830: Se un sol moto de vuy farà trapasare [If any single movement/word? will be made by you to contradict...].
3886] acest: cf. V4, ed. Beretta, açil, açellor; he suggests the influence of Old Provençal (Il Testo assonanzato franco-italiano della "Chanson de Roland", p. 384).
3907] MS: vons
3932] ba: from bäater (T-L): "spähen", 'peer, peek'
3952] MS: el (inserted above the line)
3979] peis: this is one of the cases where it signifies OF "pas"; the line is 4+6 syllables, so no dieresis is needed.
3995] See T 3956: chi aveva, 'that had'
4012] The tenses here seem to be simple past rather than present perfect equivalents, since there are no auxiliary verbs in this line. Thus in the following line en is the preposition alone.
4023] remandre: see note to v. 2407.

4024] ferir: the construction here is a little odd; perhaps this should be emended to fereor (combattants), that appears at two lines (though always in rhyme, vv. 11745 and 12074). This line would then be in apposition with the preceeding one, with two absolutes.
4041] q'el ost = "qe en l'ost"; cf. T 4002: che y[n] l'osto atrovà sono
4082] Compare T 4044: a ly stendardy non trovano che ly defenda [they didn't find anyone at the standards to defend them].
4119] T 4079: De zorno y[n] zorno quanty y[n] naserano [from day to day, however many were born]; it would seem that the Italian writer did not understand the text.

4137] engres is normally an adjective; it is translated here as nominalized. Perhaps it is for = enge (T-L "Geschlect, Sippe, Art"; Matsumura, "race, espèce")? lionoit: this is a hapax in this text, and, as far as we can tell, in FI: it is not present in RIALFrI (as of 29 June 2021); we are therefore translating as "lion" alone. This section of the line is missing from T 4095 zò fo tuto dritamente lo lione [that was truly the lion].

4148] MS: fable pece hom; this is clearly a problematic passage, where the second hemistich was not understood. Cf. T 4106 Toa ventura siè fabule; ben tu la prendise [Your adventure is an incredible story; you undertook it well]. For pece, cf. vv. 4835 (peçe), 6441.

4160] ni'l Crucifis: it is unclear here whether "crucifis" means the crucifix itself or the person crucified upon it; this varies in the poem. Since Yhes is mentioned before, we presume it is the crucifix itself, though the term could also mean "the crucified one."

4179] niant en pris: the MS here seems to read mant enpris; but reading T 4137: la zoia de questo mondo siè niente, ben lo sapite [the joy of this world is nothing, know it well] indicates that it should read as we do here.
4180] agraïs: from "agreër"
4204] This is Psalm 133, 1-2; Dante also quotes it in his Monarchia, Book 1, Chapter 16, 5 https://danteonline.it/opere/index.php; English: On World Government, trans. Schneider, p. 23).

4208-09] This Latin phrase does not appear as such in the Vulgate. However, Paulinus of Nota, Carmen I, v. 51 reads, "quod sibi quis nolit fieri, non inferat ulli" (https://archive.org/details/corpusscriptoru25wiengoog/page/n405/mode/2up?q=non+inferat+ulli, accessed 29 August 2021). It appears in collections of proverbs, and is rendered as a version of the Golden Rule, "do as you would be done by," cf. https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_ledGIas0ZSQC/page/n23/mode/2up?q=nolit+fieri, p. 11 number 60 (accessed 29 August 2021).

4217] Cf. T4173-4174:E cosỳ remase quele zente a quele fede, / tute a ben fare zascun se mese [And so the people remained with that faith/ Each one committed himself to do good]: here however, "celle foy," as seen in vv. 635, 2616, 3056, 12153, like "a celle hore," usually means 'at that time'. Should the two lines be divided differently however, and "foy" be understood as Italian 'fede', it could mean "Thus the people remained in that faith; / they gave their hearts completely to doing good" but "remist a" would be an unusual construction. It appears in collections of proverbs, and is rendered as a version of the Golden Rule, "do as you would be done by"; quoted in https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_ledGIas0ZSQC/page/n23/mode/2up?q=nolit+fieri, p. 11 number 60 (accessed 29 August 2021).

4230] The next two lines (4231-32) have several possible interpretations; grammatically, they seem to form a conditional phrase with two result clauses, all in the imperfect subjunctive: If he perjured his faith, he would be a traitor; on him would fall pain and suffering. However, he is already suffering and in pain so speaking of narrative sense, the relationship of verse 4232 with 4231 needs further explanation.

4240] The right, by definition, is the "good" side, whereas the left is that of the devil; cf. Dante's Inferno, where the visitors must progress to the left (with two exceptions). See Durling and Martinez, ed. and trans., Inferno, p. 153 n132.
4244] biendir: see note, line 1019.
4247] Latin from Luke 23, 42.
4254] The following line (4212) in T reads, "con più marinary chi menauna grosa nava [with many sailors who sailed a large ship]. The tradition here seems to be corrupted.
4260] poine non: Again, this passage seems corrupted. Perhaps this represents peinant, 'taking pains', that is, to avoid capture or death.
4290] te[re]rre: This is unusual, perhaps the adding of an unnecessary abbreviation mark when the full word is already present.
4317] pes: T-L, "Jammer", 'misery'
4339] quient: from "quiter" (T-L cols 116-117), "erlassen, quittieren" 'to remit'; cf. T 4353: Li merchadanty no[n] mancha: chi [com]pra, chi vende [Merchants weren't lacking: some bought, some sold]
4347] desrogemant: desroiement/desreëment, T-L 'Unordnung'; see Introduction on -oge.

4360] Cf. Matthew 7, 14, "For the gate is narrow and the way is hard, that leads to life, and those who find it are few" [NOAV] ,Vulgate: "Quam angusta porta, et arcta via est, que ducit ad vitam: et pauci sunt qui inveniunt eam!" Could this reflect an Italianate structure with a tanti? "Stretta è la via che non l'ottiene a tanti" or "non la tiene a tanti"– 'that not many can hold to it' or 'that not many can succeed at it'. T 4317: y[n]trigata è la via chi no[n] la tene al presente, where al presente , [complicated/ without order is the route to one who doesn't follow it immediately/currently] is the equivalent of the OF adverbial a tant, prompting our translation here. (Intricare, DELI 'avviluppare, intrecciare senz'ordine', 1374, Petrarch; al presente, Zingarelli, 'subito' (arcaico); 'attualmente').

4371] seç: the person of the verb here is not clear; it is a hapax in this MS. "Ses" is the possessive adjective; "sez" does not appear. In RIALFrI, seç appears as the possessive adjective but also as the 2nd person singular of 'to know' (2/140 appearances). Mainone (Laut, p. 19), lists it as 2nd singular; T 4328: chose che dire non vole, che vuy nol credite [things that I don't want (he doesn't want?) to say, that you (2nd pl) wouldn't believe], suggesting a second person form in any case. However, the rest of the context in T is different, continuing, 'and you would say were lies, never proved' (v. 4329). Since the merchant is referring Huon to Prester John, it makes sense that he himself would not be informed; thus we propose this as a first person, altered for rhyme.
4399] quient:from "quiter" (T-L cols 116-117), "erlassen, quittieren" 'to remit'; cf. T 4353: Li merchadanty no[n] mancha: chi [com]pra, chi vende [Merchants weren't lacking: some bought, some sold]
4402] loin: MS seems to read lom

4407] This is a complicated passage, with non-standard forms. These two lines (4406-07) are not present in T, which compresses difficult segments. The manuscript must have been corrupted here; this is our best guess.

4408] MS: il g[ra]nt pechieç il fa; we have omitted the first "il" since it is one syllable extra (it makes 13 in the line) and it is not necessary. Cf. T 4360: Se zò fano p[er] vanagloria, gran pecha lor fa.
4413] ament: from "amener"

4418] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio") includes from here these laisses 164-174, line 4664. She uses a capital letter only for new sentences, not at the beginning of each line, and does not note resolution of abbreviations. Any substantial difference in transcription (i.e., not capitals, her resolutions or her standard word division) will be noted. She does not use quotation marks here, so direct conversation is not evident, though she does later in the passage transcribed.
4424] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): ata[c]ha

4437] This line is missing from Turin, as are many confusing lines. In Turin, Prester John is introduced here specifically, T 4389-90: davante li altre steva, sopra la cadrega alto, / el Prete Zane con veschove e [con] arcevescove acor [before the others was, on the high cattedra / Prester John with bishops and with archbishops around (?)].
4440] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): comenciet le jor
4466] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): qui l'ont
4469] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): oille istrent
4482] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): le menton
4503] The first hemistich of this line seems to be a repeat of 4501 above; in Turin, however, the two also repeat. so it is clearly part of the tradition.

4509] charene: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 251), "cherene: affection"; he cites also Gui de Nanteuil "carine," so we seem to have a combination of the two here (cf. also Matsumura, "cherine," citing EE). But the word also appears in line 1560; between the two, it seems here to mean "penitence," and in fact, Turin reads "gran quaresema fay, ancha no[n] vite la simele" (line 4461), with "Lent" as the original derivation.
4513] flagelle: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 326), "flageller, fouetter," 'to whip'
4514] roelle T-L 'roeler'
4515] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): dapne elle; êlle = est elle

4538] Istrent, istront appear a number of times in this text; aman this once, but also in GdA, where it is defined as "subito" IX, 254. T clearly did not understand: li stre[n]ze la man [he shook his hand].
4555] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): por ice
4559] Te Deum laudamus: Ambrosian hymn at the end of Matins.
4570] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): un quartier de pem

4573] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): ostalaisent; there does not seem to be any record of a similar verb, more likely ostà (past participle of "oster" or "ost[el]er") + a form of the verb laisser = 'well-lodged'. Cf. T 4524.
4589] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): n'a nil de voir
4592] somons: from "semondre/somondre" (T-L col. 413)

4597] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): feroi ge. Her word division does not alter the meaning, the verb remains present conditional, first person; the ending is frequently -oige for that form (see Mainone, Formen, pp. 15-17; Laut, p. 49).

4614] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): mille visque, mant en la sor. However there are no forms "visque" in the MS, and frequently "jusque" (with its abbreviations) has a similar form. The following section is missing from Turin, from just after the number. T 4563: fa .VII.C milia de bona zente [et] conte [that makes 700 thousand good people and counts]. T picks up again with an equivalent for 4616.

4617] There seems to be a problem with this line. It is missing from Turin, and the rhyme is the same as the previous line, -ore. 4566 T: quy sono de tuto el mondo la fiore [here is the flower (i.e., the best people) of the world].
4640] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): qu'il vit; our meaning here is *qu'il le vit, subject pronoun plus object pronoun.

4651] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): pam bescuit; she also notes, "corr. anone in avoine." In this text, it does frequently appear in the context of the horse: vv. 6402, 7011; v. 107, anons. However, in OI, "annona" was food distributed to the population periodically (DELI; attested end 12th century).
4652] asié comes from aasier (T-L), 'to reassure'
4657] atapinament T-L atapiner, 'vermummen', 'to disguise'
4662] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): qu'il en gardast
4664] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio") stops here to pick up again later.
4665] Tobler transcribes lines 4665-4672 (p. 619).

4669] Stengel includes this section in his "Eine weitere Textstelle," numbering it 4669-5008. The initial here is large and heavily decorated, as well as being in gold leaf. There is decoration across the top of the folio and down the left margin as well, indicating the beginning of an important new section.

4692] The end of the line could also be interpreted fai ces demostreison, but since Turin reads "fazy demostranza" we construe it this way. There are no other forms faicés; faige and faigés are related to "fatigué," but there are three faice tokens from "to do/to make."
4698] Stengel ("Eine weitere," p. 37): dau [sien] consoil

4703] Catchword after this line: A Ynide. At this point begins the inserted signature, and Turin differs. It is clear that there is a problem in sense; there are supposedly five messengers, of whom two are mentioned in Turin (vv. 5652-53), these first two here; they are sent to Ynide and she rejects them in two laisses that are not present here. The ambassadors complete an initial embassy that is refused, and then at line T 4706, the equivalent of B 4704 picks up. Among those mentioned with the ambassadors, at various points, are 15 names: Ruçer/Rugier; Teris; Henri/Enri d'Aubespine; Belençer (marchis); Morant d'Autefoie (relative of Rugier and the Archbishop); Gui de Barcelune; Conte Gallerant d'Arthois; duc Tholomeu/Tholomeis; Uger de la Savine; Gauter de Clervant (queens); the Archbishop of Mainz (Maance); Saudin; Aumeri; Galerains de Bertagne; and Riçars, le sir de Normandie. For the missing portion according to Turin, see Appendix.

4704] The previous line, at the end of folio 32V, ends with the catchwords A Ynide which do not then begin the next folio or signature. These first two lines are problematic also, since a verb is missing; there should be something like "There is" or "There was." There is a space in the MS after "arcives" that seems to be scraped; it looks like qe. With ultraviolet, one can almost see "q" and "e", and maybe something above the line too, "qe" with "u" above the line? Or just a bit of chalk solution or whatever they used. The line has far too many syllables, yet the word is missing its ending. Thus we give this as an emendation. Stengel ("Eine weitere," p. 39): L'Arcives[ch].

4727] armaroit: in this text there are two meanings for forms of "remanoir" that go beyond the literal "to stay, to remain"). For the meaning here, see note with line 2407. As for the form, in northern Italian, due to the widespread loss of atonic vowels, consonant groups coming together fostered the development of anaptyctic vowels, even in initial position, particularly when voiced consonants were together; thus for example, Jacopone da Todi, "armane" forrimane (Rohlfs ¶ 338).
4739] MS: plais, with a very small and light line above the i.
4741] pur che: it is unclear what is meant here; it is written as two separate words in the MS. This might be interpreted differently in OF from OI. See note in the translation.

4743] senator: title of Roland in the EE, and an office with a mixed use in the period of this text. The local government elected the senator (Charles I of Anjou, for example, in 1263, by the Guelphs), but the Pope confirmed the post (in this case, in 1264). For more on Charles's exploits as senator, see Dunbabin, Charles I of Anjou. The position encompasses, therefore, both church and state concerns.

4745] The reading Tholomé here is problematic, since Tholomeus has not been designated head of the band of ambassadors or otherwise much discussed until now. MS T, line 4745, reads "Servire debe esere tal sire [et] de grande [et] de menore" [such a man should be lord both of great and of lesser men]; perhaps the original here was "tal ome" (such a man), referring to the king, referring to the king. There are two possible avenues for distraction, the first written, and the second oral. In the first column of this folio, in line four (this is line 3 of column two) in line 4707, "Tholomeu" appears, so could have distracted a copyist. If the scribe were writing under dictation, he might have thought he heard "tol ome" instead of "tel ome," and would have added the "h" after the "t" because he had just encountered the name earlier [with thanks to colleagues for confirmation]. However, the redactor was quite familiar with the Roman d'Alexandre, as Meregazzi and Morgan demonstrate, so this may on the contrary be a reference to the Ptolomies of Egypt; see note in translation.

4760] Note the use of courtly love terminology, as in Marie de France's "Lai de Chevrefeuille,""Bele amie, si est de nus: ne vus senz mei, ni jeo senz vus," the words of Tristan to Yseut (de Marie de France, Lais ed. Karl Warnke, p. 266).
4766] Stengel ("Eine weitere," p. 41): fil econtre
4779] omais: cf. DELI, from oggi + mai, citing the Crusca

4787] The end of this line and the next are missing in the MS.For possible endings, see T 4765 and 4766: Enposible cose seria che tanty omeny savie / non sapeseno una dona far fare a so volere" [It would be an impossible thing that so many wise men / not know how to make a woman do according to their wish].

4799] MS: selong; though "selon" derives from SECUNDUM (T-L, col. 377), its normal function is as part of adverbial or prepositional phrase; T-L does not give any examples of it functioning as an adjective. This laisse is absent in T, so there is no comparison. Cf. v. 353, a le jor segond.
4812] impacer: cf. MSI "impacciare" (DELI: from OF empeechier, from Late Latin IMPEDICĀRE; DELI)
4835] MS: peçe=OF "pieça"; Stengel ("Eine weitere," p. 43): Lle

4839] MS: il est: since both cortoisse and insenne are feminine forms, and the line is twelve syllables as it stands, this must be feminine (with sinalephe), for Ynide, whose actions are in fact described in the following lines (PEB).
4866] MS indeed reads bein.

4869] armandrois: see Carlo Salvioni, "Annotazioni alla 'Antica Parafrasi Lombarda del Neminem laedi nisi a se ipso di S. Giovanni Grisostomo [...]," p. 427: e.g., "per nu no roman," 'non dipende da noi' [it doesn't depend on us]; it appears, as in his example, with a negative particle and a form of por plus a pronoun. Another example here is in line 4892.
4871] Langlois lists Teris as Lord of Vermandois (p. 668).
4879] The grammatical structure here is problematic; perhaps there was a saut du même au même, with a missing "por"? One could have "prendre arme" or "serons armé," but not both.
4881] çassons: cf. v. 4831, "la çasons"
4892] armagna: for form and meaning, see note to v. 4869.

4894] Note the multiple negation here; there is no reference to this in the standard OF grammars that we consulted (Ménard, Kibler) or dictionaries. RIALFrI does list Enanchet that has several examples (ll. 39, 85), and Hector et Hercule (v. 1504). It seems to be a reinforcement.
4920] This line is incomplete in the MS. These laisses are not in T, so there can be no reconstruction from that text.
4927] no: literally, 'knot(s)' (T-L "no" cols. 667-671)
4928] MS: un êve since êve is always feminine in this text="une eve."
4933] This is the point at which T picks up the story again, T v. 4776.
4934] MS: potē; reconstructed upon the form of v. 2017.
4939] armara: see notes to vv. 2407 and 4727.
4940] Something is clearly missing in this line, perhaps de [servir] vos? Cf. T 4782: de complire la vostra volontady [to accomplish your will].
4970] aremansu: see note to v. 4727.

4976] In the EE, line 15795 "brais de justisse" also appears, as in Gui de Nanteuil, v. 2921 and GdA, bk 1, v. 92. The second expression appears only in Gui de Nanteuil, v. 2920, Aubre de vertus. Ehe "arm of justice," like the arm of the law, could refer literally to a statue. These sound like fixed expressions, perhaps from well-known documents at the time.

4978] This line is incomplete in the MS. In MS T, v. 4820 reads "Ay, cristianità, como ay tuo onore p[er]duto!" [Oh, Christianity, how you've lost your honor!]. There is a little ink following perduto but it may be merely bleed-through from the back.
4986] aremansu: see note to v. 4727.
5008] End of Stengel's "Eine weitere" transcription.

5012] This line is incomplete in the MS. In MS T, v. 4851 reads "Dona," dize Berardo, "che loro lasate-ly y[n]trare." There is difficulty with this line, though the general idea is clear: "Lady," said Berardo,"may you allow them to enter."
5028] ester: estre3 (T-L col. 1464)
5034] MS: jambaseors
5047] coreste: cf. Holtus, Lexikalische p. 99, who cites the ending of -estre as a comparative construction in the Entrée.
5051] este: estre2 (T-L col. 1462)

5053] colleste: hapaxlegomenon; could this be some combination of "con" and "este," a tonic pronoun? Perhaps through scribal error of writing two strokes unconnected somewhere along the line? Since it is in rhyme, it could be a distortion of "(a)llestire", placed together with another form? Or, "con lei sta": cf. T 4889: "che lì state" [that you stay with them]; but this would mean a repetition of "with."
5083] Unusual abbreviation form: empeos with a sign over "e" and "o-" or perhaps a two-part sign?

5102] parcipemant: this a hapax; we find percevement , 'action of perceiving'; parçoniere, 'associate; the one who shares'; this seems to mean, from the context, that the king would share equally with Ynide and his wife– either by making no distinction or by sharing equally; possibly, he didn't wish to separate Ynide and the queen, make a rupture between the two (depecement / despecement). Here there seems to be a mixed lexeme, a combination of multiple words, possibly in part because of the rhyme. This line is not present in Turin.
5112] MS: serees; the second e has a tiny dot below and a bigger one above; not clear though if it should be expunctuated. We have done so here.

5124] The blue capital here is unusual in that it is not decorated at all with filigrees. Normally the red capitals are decorated with purplish designs and the blue with red; here the capital is bare and simple.

5132] T 4955: vuy avite; p[er] vuy tramiso, [et] zò e my y[n]seme siemo [you have; he sent for you, and that and I are together]. ensoine: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 300-301), "scusa," 'excuse.'ensoine : cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 300-301), "scusa," 'excuse.'
5150] cum: the final "n" here is the "vertical m" found in Latin texts. Cf. Vieillard, Conseils, Fasc. 1, p. 28 (¶11).
5157] aremenrois: see notes to v. 4727.
5172] strine: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 320)
5185] Cf. 2503, "faim et soy li destringne."
5192] For the construction with irer, see Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 352-53).
5231] nel= in + il (cf. Modern Italian)
5233] MS: ētase

5234] The Latin offered here does not seem to be a direct quote of any specific text, but rather a rhetorical device on the part of the archbishop. It does revisit traditional Church teachings, e. g., Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologia, Secunda secundae (second part of the second part), Question 104, article 3, which asks "quod obedientia sit maxima virtutum" and responds negatively (see for the Latin https://www.corpusthomisticum.org/sth3102.html). Certainly it was a popular belief; see for example, Pontano, "magna quaedam virtus est obedientia" in his De obedientia of the sixteenth century.

5242] This line recalls frescoes and statuary of hell where souls are balanced on a scales to decide their fate, with devils sometimes cheating by leaning on the scale or otherwise influencing the weight so that angels cannot take them to heaven.
5264] ont âcompagner = ont a acompagner, 'must accompany'; cf. "avoir a + inf., auxiliare servant à exprimer l'action qui doit être accomplie" (Matsumura 331); T-L column 758.
5295] armainrés: see notes to 2407 and 4727.
5307] armaroit: see notes to vv. 2407 and 4727.

5311] aclinan: MS aclian? The third letter/pair of letters does not resemble the h of achan in v. 5304 above; the first stroke is too high to be a u. "acliner" and various forms of it appear in the MS. T 5127: Berardo, Morando et Y[n]rigo y[n]sanble seno (the last word has been changed) [Berardo, Morando and Henry are together]. The Morant here seems to be Ynide's man since each of the other two pairs is one of hers and one of the king's; this is a case where having a man with the same name on each side causes confusion.
5316] arman: see note to v. 4727.

5329] Tobie: This may be a reference to the apocryphal book of the Bible, Tobit. It praises the purity of marriage, and is thus particularly relevant here. There are northern Italian versions of the text (cf. Marinoni, ed., La versione valdese del libro di Tobia, 986).
5347] Miserere mei: see note to 2361.

5363] MS: avon. MS T, lines 5179-80 read: "che avante m'averoy lo coro fenduto / e l'anyma de my del tuto avere peruta" ...for I would first have my heart split, and my soul completely lost (i.e., be dead) before I would ....
5371] crevant, from "creventer" 'to strike down, knock down' (T-L cravanter, gravanter, Column 1016; REW crepantare).
5379] fortese: Cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 329), 'force'
5399] T 5212: chi non fosse y[n] vergogna de l'apele, who is not ashamed to call him
5404] topinelle: cf. http://tlio.ovi.cnr.it/T-LIO/ "Gravato da una situazione difficile, da un dolore emotivo, da una pena amorosa; misero, infelice, sventurato"; frequent in exclamation, Oh ....!
5420] des or: this could also read "desor"; cf. T 5229: apreso vuy me menate desopra. This is one of two lines in rhyme where either could be possible; cf. 9109.

5430] This line is somewhat problematic, evoking different reactions in those thinking of Italian and those thinking of French.trasumans recalls Dante Par. 1, 70, "transumanar." This would be one of its earliest usages after Dante (DELI: before 1321, Dante, first use) if that is what it is. Certainly Turin seems to have interpreted it as Dante's lexeme: 5240 ch'el s'è partỳ p[er] desopra e straformò-se [he left for above and transformed himself]. But as PEB points out, "de suor" is 'with sweat' (cf. vv. 2504, 5027, 6821) so the preceding word could be a rendering for "tressüer," 'to sweat in big drops'. The "suelee" then would remain to solve; there is no similar expression in the MS. svelee: there are forms of "svelleir," 'to be awake, to awaken', and that seems most likely here. Cf. 5434 below.

5432] Note that here Ynide anticipates the cries of those in hell; see v. 7661, 8848, etc., reflecting too the later comment that life is a is a purgatory for those who suffer it (v. 2398), and the self-beating repeats Huon's gesture to himelf before the temptation of the sorceress (laisses 269-70, vv. 6882-6929).

5439] Ynide's men include her relatives and various vassals. Twelve names appear: Alisant d'Aquitaine; Galudins, the porter; Thomas, Baudoin, Berart, her relatives; Ulien/Elin; Teris; Gauter d'Estampes; Robert and Anseis; Corberan and Sanguin. There are also a few minor figures: Grailet, Melians e Gralant. The name Morant appears on both sides: among Huon's men and with the ambassadors.
