There are also multiple appearances of "Teris" and "Thomas" in various forms.

5443] One wonders about the significance of the holy figure here. Mary Magdalene was famous for being very rich and "sensuous pleasure keeps company with great wealth" before meeting Jesus (Golden Legend, "96. Saint Mary Magdalene," Jacobus de Voragine: The Golden Legend, Readings on the Saints, trans. Granger, pp. 374-83, at p. 395. Perhaps Ynide is attempting to imply to Charles Martel's representatives that she has repented of her disobedience. Mary Magdalene's feast day is July 22, so it may be merely a mark of time.

5445] Saint Helen was the mother of Constantine, who went to Jerusalem and the toured the Holy Land, supposedly discovering the True Cross. She also founded and beautified various churches. She brought various relics back to Rome, and down the street from St. John in Lateran is her Basilica of the Holy Cross in Jerusalem, where her head graces a classical statue, near the Aurelian walls. The floor was originally with dirt brought back from the Holy Land; thus perhaps the appropriateness of such a site here for Ynide's prayer and its particular appeal to Christ.

5447] baroine. The second and third strokes are clearly linked at the top and the first and second at the bottom. Since the line is already 4+6 syllables, and the number seems plural rather than a collective, we do not emend.

5450] A vernacular rendering of portions of the Credo (Nicene Creed). Unlike the "prière du plus grand péril" [prayer of greatest peril] that warriors use before battle, Ynide does not here invoke various Old Testament figures, but rather the redemption from original sin.

5460] MS: sa aubçēt ("b" also has a titulus over it). We emend here in part because of syllable count and in part because of sense: "sa aubercent" does not make sense: it is either two verbs together or a singular possessive pronoun plus plural verb. As frequently is the case for problematic lines, it is missing from the T version. devaine: unclear origin; perhaps "devant" in rhyme? By context, this relates to the first sin, original sin, and it is translated. This line is missing from the Turin version.

5467] Following this line, T has an additional line, 5277: Ynida dize un salmo ch'ela trovò yn lo salterio [Ynide said a psalm that she foumd in the psalter], an expression similar to those frequently used about Huon. Alternatively, since the MS writes "levoit" as one word, it could mean "when the priest raised the great lord", but what else could "magne sire" refer to? However, the archbishop is nowhere else called a "great lord." Or perhaps "And when she saw him, the priest, the great lord," but then why the "And" that begins the line? Clearly, there seems to have been a bit of a confusion here in these two-three lines in the tradition.
5468-69] See again Luke 23, 42.
5478] reïre: from the prefix RE- + ire

5479] Candace is the wife of Darius of Syria in Roman d'Alexander; she falls in love with Alexander the Great. She figures in Roman d'Alexandre Bk 3. See Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," pp. 19-22 on other Alexander romance derivations in the poem, though she does not discuss the Ynide embassy episode, and Morgan, “Le Roman d’Alexandre dans Huon d'Auvergne: tourisme et truismes dans une épopée du XIVe siècle.” Alexander tricked her, pretending to be a messenger and not himself, though he ultimately revealed the trick and spent the night with her and then left– as Aeneas also left Dido. So Ynide is suggesting what might happen to her.
5482] MS appears to read niiēs
5491] Lachebire: unknown figure. Not in Moisan, Langlois or Flutre.
5493] Morant here seems to be one of the king's men, since he is paired with Rubers, one of Ynide's men, since again, it is one of the king's men versus one of hers.
5496] aremanreç: see note to v. 4727.

5497] This line is missing from Turin, where it would fall between 5305 and 5306. It seems to have elements of the following line (Devant), and the verb form is unclear; conteç is normally an imperative or a past participle.
5505] sanctus: part of the Eucharistic prayer during Catholic mass. Isaiah 6, 2 is the origin of this expression.

5514] ait: we understand as a form of "to help" based upon T l5324: Dio aiute da mia parte che più l'averà biasemato [may God help my side, for it (she, in the situation) will be blamed more] ], though in general in B "ait" is a form of "avoir."
5524] armanir: see note to v. 4727.

5532] The forms here are unlike others we have seen in this text; and these lines are omitted from the T MS. We have interpreted sorer as "suer" and scaulir as "echauffer" through an Italianate "caldo" since MSI "scaldare"=to burn, though one might expect opposite expressions. The T text (in a different order) does mention the 'fire of love,' v. 5346, "Lo feu d'amore sovente li fate sentire." Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 454-55), relates it to "essorer," with varying meanings according to the text; 'to relax, cool off.'.

5537] païr: this is a hapax legomenon in the text. It could be several verbs: paiier, to satisfy; parer/paroir, to appear; palir, to become pale. See the translation for possible alternatives. The line is missing from Turin, where it would fall between 5344 and 5345.
5541] crosir: cf. GdA (Glossario: cf. croisir, "rompere, frantumare, ferire").
5554] Dé: interjection, written "deh" in MSI, expressing any number of emotions (DELI, deh, before 1300, G. Cavalcanti).
5555] MS: palam or palain (with an abbreviation apostrophe over the p); neither this line nor the previous are present in T.
5559] tort: from "tordre," 'to turn, to treat'; a sordois, T-L cols. 886-7, 'the worst'
5564] MS: dolonor; lais here is intransitive, "cesser" [Matsumura].
5568] MS: empëo, where the descender of the p is also crossed.

5620] soies: seems to have a final consonant in order to maintain syllable count, since the only other forms of soies both follow the subject pronoun "tu" (vv. 1556, 6797), but personal endings are not consistent as typical in Franco-Italian texts. armanu: see note to v. 4727.

5641] a laire: note the use of the cas sujet here as object of a preposition; the phrase is usually "a larron". T 5429: che non dicha l'uno a l'altro rialmente a l'altro; so there is something beginning with "a" at the end of the line.
5646] caume: (cf. 5811 and calm, v. 5786): gnomic expression, proverb (T-L 210, lines 40-42, "Redensart vgl. [compare] chançon, vers)
5649] eist from "eissir", to come forth
5656] sonelaire: cf. EE, v. 6140, "soneilés", which Thomas defines "sommeiler", ital. "sonneggiare"

5660] tu autem, Domine: said at the end of biblical readings of the liturgy in the medieval Catholic church (full form: tu autem Domine miserere nobis). The three-word expression occurs at several points in the Vulgate, e.g., Psalm 3, verse 4; Psalm 101, 13. Augustine cites it in his Confessions (1.6.9); Friedrich Ohly ("Zum Dichtungsschluß Tu autem, domine, miserere nobis," p. 244) that this is the end of the Chanson de Roland as well, and that the expression is used from ca. 1100 as the end of a prayer in the vernacular, not only in liturgical contexts, but also in various literary genres, including Girart de Roussillon. Ohly notes that the use of the formula as typical of the Germanic area, and suggests that its use in the Chanson de Roland shows the martyrs of Roncevaux as saints to be prayed to (p. 68). In that case Berard, Ynide's relative, is referring to a sacrificial offering on the part of Ynide.

5670] MS: susnel; this line is a puzzler. There are no expressions like it elsewhere in the MS, and T 5455-56: e dize, "Guardate, sire, crede tu che sia si fantinelo? / Perché non sa-tu che eio pa[r]la sỳ ysnielo?", so that the second line is clearly addressed to someone, where here in B, it is in third person. We emend based on T, but it is not entirely satisfactory.
5681] penel: cf. EE, v. 10709, 10722 (Thomas), and GdA, "insegna"

5697] rue: in this MS, "rue" is either 'road(s)' or 'wheel' or a form of 'to throw', so this clearly is the wheel of fortune. T 5474: Ora l'alta sezia desopra la raina sederite [Then you will be sitting on the high seat above the queen], reflects a scribal difficulty: the strokes in the middle misinterpreted and a possibly (and frequently) missing abbreviation for 'n' added, so that 'rua' might have been interpreted 'rňa'. Since Saudin says the queen will be dead, being over her makes little sense, or at the very least is gruesome.

5718] terllisse: cf. terlis, terlise, EE, vv. 1378, etc.; terliz, Gui de Nanteuil, v. 3198. Usually used of hauberks, triple-ringed; however, also for fabrics, three-thread fabric (T-L tresliz, col. 609). Though T-L defines it as "ein derer, fester dreifädiger Stoff" this is clearly rich material, not coarse.
5725] gaberisse: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 333), "raillerie," 'mockery, scoffing'

5747] MS: ɔpendre. pendre exists as an alternate form for prendre in OF, so we do not emend (T-L s.v. prendre, col. 1736; Matsumura). This entire laisse is a series of responses to Ynide, so these are all Charles Martel's men making remarks about how Ynide should behave and why. This line is missing from T; the entire T laisse is shorter, counting 13 lines to B's 26.
5749] armendre: see note to v. 4727.
5750] This expression or similar ones occur elsewhere in Franco-Italian; cf. EE, v. 2055: "Tiel quide vendre que moult seult achater."
5754] The references are missing from the Turin MS.
5756] For Porus, see the Roman d'Alexandre, Branche 3, laisses 30-240.

5757] Pelias: King of Iolcus. This may refer to Pelias sending Jason after the Golden Fleece when he arrived at a ceremony for Poseidon with one sandal, having lost the other crossing a river (it had been predicted that one wearing one sandal would overthrow him). "The port of Endre" or "the port Dendre" might then be near Mt. Pelion, where Pelias was being raised by the centaurs.

5758] The meaning and derivation of desgrendre are unclear. Perhaps "sgrenre" (for the form, cf. genero=gendre; tenero=tendre etc.), 'to seed a fruit/remove bits from cob; recite the rosary; eat with glee'. PEB suggests a deformation for rhyming purposes of "desgarander" = "render someone helpless" (T-L Col. 1598 ). The concept, to do in someone, is clear.
5762] This seems to refer to an earlier embassy, present in Turin, but absent here in the B manuscript, unless it is referring to the previous day.

5770] ven falus: this is the Italian passive with venire; cf. https://blogs.transparent.com/italian/how-to-use-venire-in-the-passive-form/. See Rohlfs ¶ 735, who cites Old Paduan and Veneziano in particular, tracing it in part to Latin fieri; he notes its popularity in northern Italian.
5783] porveüs: this seems to be a form of "prover" in rhyme.

5784] decernus: seems to be a Latin ending on an OF verb, "decerner" (T-L col. 1243-44) (PEB). The author's identity is unclear. There were two famous Venetian Jewish commentators named Isaiah of Trani (the Elder and the Younger), (c. 1180 – c. 1250; 13th – 14th century). The time frame and region are appropriate but whether their works would be known in the Gentile community is unclear.

5786] Zenat: unclear to whom this refers. In the Italian Aye d'Avignon, "Çenat" is given as the name of the poet (v. 798), which Callu-Turiaf annotates as a diminuitive of "Zeno" that was popular in the Veronese-Paduan era (p. 401). For calm, see caume, vv. 5646 and 5811. It is interesting to note that the term in this usage appears only in the inserted signature about Ynide. See also the introduction about the uses of the spelling with 's' in this text.

5801] diablemai[n]s: not present in T-L, but Godefroy and Matsumura (citing FEW 3, 64a), give a noun; Godefroy, "the power of the devil" (vol 2, p. 7070); "the devil himself" (Matsumura, , under "dïablement,"gives "diablerie" (p. 1026))."diablerie" (p. 1026)).
5805] Reference to Matthew 6, 12 and Luke 11, 4, the second of which is closer: "Demitte nobis peccata nostra, siquidem et ipsi dimittimus omni debenti nobis" in the Vulgate.
5812] See translation for the source of the Latin quote and discussion.
5813] This is a problematic reading; see note in translation.
5823] autor: atur, 'fine clothing' (T-L, col. 646)

5838] T 5575: Zascun dize, "Morto sia quisty traditore maledety!" [Everyone said, "May these accursed traitors be killed!"] However, seeking a source for the quote here in B and a reason that it be in Latin, the Life of Anselm in PL 158, p. 57, cites Anselm as being treated viciously "omnino more canino...exercebat," so the text here may be calqued upon that. However, it seems most likely that more here be a subjunctive form of 'to die' as in other lines (5895 (2 times), 5906, 9105), though in general a Latin quote is a full hemistich by itself; thus omnino is the Latin adverb meaning 'tout à fait]' (JCV) [completely, absolutely], and the translation reflects this interpretation.
5846] MS: mebruç; cf. me[m]bru, me[m]bre, me[m]brue in this text
5849] Dé: see note, v. 5554.
5856] leuç: from elire, 'to be elected, chosen' (Pope 1065, p. 414); but cf. also Aliscans, leueç from lier, 'arruotalare', 'to enroll, be commissioned'
5857] For the form se lagne, see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 358).
5860] aute Virgo benagne: "benigna" is an attribute frequently associated with Mary, found in numerous hymns; this phrase is mixed in form and language but calqued closely on prayers and hymns.
5864] armagne: see note to v. 4727.
5866] armagne: see note to v. 4727.

5871] braagne: T 5600, "bergagna"; T-LIO "bergagnare": 'tirare per le lunghe', 'draw it out too long' (first attestation, Villani, Cronica, 1348-63; from Prov. barganhar, OF bargaignier (DEI s.v. bargagnare); http://tlio.ovi.cnr.it/voci/005628.htm, 16 Dec 2020).
5866] armagne: see note to v. 4727.

5878] cloroit: these last two lines are not present in T, so they, like many here, confused readers somewhere along the line. It might be "coloroit" (LZM; colorare appears before Dante, 1321, DELI, and a saut du même au même or metathesis of l is easily imaginable; forms of it appear in other F-I texts, and the adjective elsewhere here) or perhaps "esclaireroit" (PEB; cf. T-L esclarir, esclarcir). "Cloïr" exists as well, 'to enclose' (T-L col. 496, lines 39 ff.), and there are two other forms here related to it, clois (v. 5569) and closis (v. 5914), but that does not seem to make sense here. See also the translation note.
5924] transis: cf. Gambino, "Code-mixing nel Bovo d'Antona udinese," p. 79, transiier.
5926] esmatés: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 311), "terrasser, détruire," 'to crush, destroy'
5942] acuissient: from acoisier, aquisier "calmer" (Matsumura; T-L acosier see cosier, 'schweigen', to keep silent, remain still, col. 547)

5964] MS: dorit; T 5669: l'arcevescovo et Ynrigo e Morando che no[n] dormea [the archbishop and Henry and Morando who didn't sleep]. In order to preserve the rhyme, the imperfect ending is needed. The result is rather ironic: the whipped messagers aren't glistening with gold, but rather blood.
5968] baster:=Italian "bastare" to be enough, to suffice; attested 1253, DELI (unknown origin; no attestation in OF, T-L)

5979] avist: there are three tokens with this sequence of letters: 5601 and 7579 in addition to this line. In each case it is a form of the verb "to have," interpreted also by Mainone as avist (Formen 24), similar to the forms in EE, GdA, V4, etc. As Veillard and Guyotjeannin's Conseils suggest, the alternation between "u" and "v" (avit and avait appear, as do aüst and aüstes, aüsés) suggests an interpretation with "v" (Fasc. I, 25).

5982] It isn't clear to what this refers. Ecce magnum is the beginning of the responsory dedicated to St. Martin ("Ecce magnum et verum sacerdotem ecce bonum dispensatorem" in the Ambrosian rite (http://cantus.uwaterloo.ca/node/219512, 17 Dec 2020). The expression appears subsequently in histories and in various Latin poems. It could be that "magnum" reflects the responsory here. It is part of matins, so would fit with the reference to "ancient prime" earlier (v. 5979). However, it could also refer to the archbishop's idea of himself as a great priest.

5995] MS maçerie: the letter l seems to have been corrected in r (for "Margery"). While there is no "Saint Margery" per se, Margery (Marjorie) is an abbreviated form for "Margaret." There is no Order of St. Margery/Margaret attested, yet St. Margaret was largely revered in the Middle Ages (hers was one of Joan of Arc's voices). T compresses these lines and in v. 5698 reads only that the woman was the abess at the "monastero ... Santo Giromia" [Jeremiah], suggesting that there may have been a scribal metathesis in transmission in addition other variations.

6014] pri: the word is normally a form of the verb "to pray, beg"; however the line here is at least a syllable short (5+4). T 5714: a pé a pé , 'on foot' (with redoubling for emphasis); one might reconstitute "a pi" (cf. V. 3083), which would allow 5+5 syllables
6015] MS: nuit demi .pl'. with a caret between nuit and demi .
6028] Tobler transcribes from here through line 6139 (pp. 607-609).
6041] porpre: rich dark fabric of fine quality (T-L "porpre," col. 1543-46)

6064] See Psalms 24/25, verse 7, "Secundum misericordiam tuam memento mei tu" [according to thy steadfast love remember me] and 50/51, verse 3, "Miserere mei, Deus, secondum magnum misericordam tuam" [Have mercy on me, O God, according to thy steadfast love]. (Vulgate; NOAB; with thanks to PEB.) See also Luke 23, 42, as above, v. 4247.

6067] Blank folio, Recto and Verso, follows. In the equivalent spot of Turin, f. 89R, is a note that the siege of Auvergne is missing here: Mancha quy como Carlo Martelo andò a champo [Here is missing how Charles Martel went to battle]. This may be the reason for the blank folio. The scene now switches back to Huon.
6068] Meregazzi, "Prete Gianni" recommences her transcription here, her lines 6223-6552, here 6068-6397.
6088] en die: it is not clear here what Huon is referring to; T specifies "de my" (v. 5783). I could be "about it," the mission, or Huon's dedication to it (dying in mission).
6105] entre cil: cf. T 5800 quando averite passà oltra quelo pozo altane [when you will have passed beyond that high hill]
6110] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 32): n'en cuit
6112] Tobler: de grant pri. sic. The print seems to be missing a letter at the end.
6117] MS: mais; an "s" seems to be written over an "i"; Tobler: mas; Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 34): m'as
6126] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 34): Si non
6132] Avenois: see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 224).
6139] End of Tobler transcribed section.
6144] la qui: Cf. Ménard, ¶67, p. 82; Rohlfs, ¶485 for the genitive of the relative pronoun.
6150] cf. Roques, CR Wunderli, 'a(l)lozer', p. 538.
6158] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 36): fors qui l'en dure. T-L endurer, col. 304, "aushalten, erdulden," 'endure, suffer, bear'

6178] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 38) also includes only the final line, 6178, as a quote. The division between authorial comment and where the quote begins is not clear since the verb ere could be third or first person. For vv. 6177-78, compare T 5870-71: Se Dio li consente, tanto como el serà vivente /"Che a myo podere non faza donda eio son travaliante." [If God allows him, as long as he will be alive, / "That I do (accomplish) that which I am working on to (the best of) my ability"]. If these lines were similarly divided, understanding ere as third person, as Meregazzi does, they would have the same meaning. Note the double negative that cannot be directly translated into colloquial English: he will not allow that he not accomplish.
6194] plus mes: 'plus mieux'
6200] MS: son son signor
6221] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 40): Lors que
6226] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 40): qi conquis
6229] This would seem to refer to a hell similar to Dante's Inferno, where Lucifer is encased in ice. However, when Huon arrives to Lucifer, that is not the case here.
6240] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 42): gardera li mon grant
6278] pecer: peçoiier/peciier/peceër ,'split, break into pieces' (T-L 538, l. 39).
6257] The storm and cold as a means of phyical suffering are a recurring narrative trope; compare the ambassadors as they head back to Charles Martel, vv. 6046-6053.
6269] Miserere mei: from Psalm 50, see v. 2361, above.
6278] pecer: peçoiier/peciier/peceër ,'split, break into pieces' (T-L 538, l. 39)

6287] Salve regina: one of four antiphons to Mary sung at different parts of the ecclesiastical year. This is sung at Compline from the Saturday before Trinity Sunday until the Friday before the first Sunday of Advent (since the thirteenth century), but is also spoken at the end of the rosary, and it figures in other important uses.
6288] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 46): la proiere

6292]In adiutorium meum: first verse of psalm 69 (70). "These words form the introductory prayer to every Hour of the Roman, monastic, and Ambrosian Breviaries, except during the last three days of Holy Week, and in the Office of the Dead" (Frederick Holweck, "Deus in Adjutorium Meum Intende," The Catholic Encyclopedia, vol. 4, 1908. Consulted 20 Apr. 2022). ONAB: "Be pleased, O God, to deliver me!"

6293] Gloria patri: known as the doxology, is traditionally sung in the western Catholic Church at the end of psalms since the seventh century, with few exceptions, such as during the last few days of Holy Week and at Mass for the dead. It continues in use at various points through the modern Mass, and in local languages in Protestant sects (Adrian Fortescue, "Doxology," The Catholic Encyclopedia, vol. 5, 1909. Consulted 20 Apr. 2022 http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/05150a.htm).
6294] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 46): benig[n]e chiere

6296] Line incomplete; see T 5987: charegò-le per vero lo francho conte [the brave count truly put it on], but there the previous line has Huon picking up his equipment only, so here dressing, and an exact equivalent to that line, is missing.
6297] MS: over it plu there is an ink smear.
6301] pere here for 'per', equal etc. (T-L cols. 698-707)
6304] ala Âgollant for Ala a Agollant; reference to Aspremont; Meregazzi: il ala a Gollant. See Extra notes for Aspremont.
6305] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 46): Hei Diex.

6319] plase is: This is written together in the MS; Matsumura gives "swamp" (plasceïz); plasseïz, plassis, however, is a "hedge" (T-L col. 1057), but neither seems to make sense here. Compare T 6010: Quando fono oltra de ly grandy passe [When they were beyond the great pass], so this is an area of difficult. Plaseïs would also be a hapax for this text, and no marsh has been mentioned, so we divide as shown. Plase as 'place' appears also in Cronaca del templare di Tiro (RIALFrI, 18 August 2021, two appearances).
6337] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 50): le pieç
6349] golir: an Italian-based form; cf. GdA, "goloient"; T-LIO "goliare," 'desiderare'.
6350] MS: (t) is inserted above line with a caret under the line before the s is underpunctuated at end of the word.

6359] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 50): aré tinir. There are no forms "aré" or "tinir" in this text; "tenir" appears 25 times (5 with [n]). "retenir" in various conjugated forms appears numerous times, including "retint." Turin line 6050 read "retenire" in line-final position. The a- prefix is frequent in Franco-Italian, as noted above.

6362] In the manuscript, the final stroke of the –r is extremely light. These fights with beasts each have a moral drawn from them that the writer states, and the animals recall Dante's initial encounters in the Commedia: the leopard, for instance.
6366] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 52): acrement

6371] escrie: to escry, gain sight of ("escrier1," Anglo-Norman Dictionary (AND2 Online Edition), Aberystwyth University, 2021. Web. 18 August 2021. https://anglo-norman.net/entry/escrier_1), dated to the twelfth century).
6387-6389] See notes in translation for Latin phrases.

6393] MS: moy. Possibly a scribal distraction of following "soy"; cf. T 6084 mé molto se dota de sé e de l'afare [but he worried/feared a great deal for himself and for his business]. 'mui, moi' does exist as a measure, a large quantity (this last in Matsumura, but not in T-L); thus it would have a similar meaning. However, it does not appear anywhere else in this MS, so we have emended, presuming a scribal error.
6397] End of Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni").

6398] Stengel publishes from here to line 6992. He notes in the introduction that he edits for reading ease: resolving abbreviations, differentiating i/j and u/v and adding punctuation. Any comments related to that edition will be listed by Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe"). Differences in editing style are not noted.
6400] mesay: T-L mesaise (col. 1566); cf. GdA "mesais" and "mesas."

6408] MS: cōsent; Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 687): qu'il conseut (with no explanation or comment; from "consivre"); confusion between links for minims is quite possible. Quant que: quando che is a veneto expression according to Zingarelli 2018, for "quando, proprio quando," 'when, just when'. Consentir is defined as 'to win' in both T-L and Matsumura, the construction with a here differs from that of the single example given universally (from Benoît, Troie), and would be a hapax in this text.
6413] Meregazzi notes similarities here with the temptation of Perceval in the Queste del Saint Graal ("L'Ugo d'Alvernia,"p. 25).

6417] s'aregone: Cf. T 6108: s'araduna, 'to meet'; we are interpreting "aregone" as related to aringo T-LIO , "a place for meeting, a meeting" and extrapolate the verb as "to meet." DELI: ragunare, alternative of "radunare"; here with a typical a- prefix (RI+ADUNARE); cf. Rohlfs vol 1 ¶ 339. One might imagine that "s'araison" derives from RATIONE(M). While this might work phonologically (cf. MSI ragione and Modern French raison that both derive from RATIONE(M)), it is problematic both because there is no other support for the derivation, and because here the ladies are singing, not just talking or discussing.
6425] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 688): (!) At the end of the line, va[n]celles : another example of confusion downstrokes in "n" and "u"; cf. lines 402, 2868, RIALFrI, numerous appearances.
6437] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 689): "Que ferés...

6465] car: the function and meaning of this word is unclear here; elsewhere in the MS it always is the conjunction, and there is no equivalent in T 6156. Furthermore, it is not necessary for the syllable count since the line is 4+6 without it.
6473] fanos written as one word in the manuscript, as usual for object pronouns following the imperative.
6475] astu written as one word in the manuscript, as usual for subject following the verb in question.
6484] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 690): Venuç [a] li
6486] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 690): enfer atrover
6495] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 691): luy [g]e

6503] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 691): Conten[t]eç moy; a scribe seems to have confused "contez" and "contentez," so 'Content me' and 'Tell me'. Since four syllables are needed but "contendre" and "contenir" appear here in various forms with their standard meanings, as does "contenter", we emend. Cf. T 6193: contentaty-my [content me, please me]
6520] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692): de ci; "Ne" here is the negative non of MSI.
6522] ençaigne: trickery, cunning, wiliness (T-L engan, col 373; DELI inganno, 13th cent., cf ingegno, also 13th cent.)

6523] Mestre could be understood as a feminine plural here, in which case the comparison would be with other female necromancers. The line in general is tricky because the verb seems singular (soit) but tant would indicate a plural.

6531] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692) : efforç par. Cf. the Roman d'Alexandre, Branche 3, laisses 207-213, seeking the trees of the Sun and the Moon (ed. Harf-Lancner pp. 528-535). All references to the Alexandre will be to this edition and the format Branch, laisse(s) or verse(s).
6533] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692): Et qui distrent
6540] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692): au roy (!) pooire; Roman d'Alexandre, Porus I, laisse 217, etc. for Porus.

6543]There seems to be a missing line here— the end of one and beginning of the next. In T there are two additional half lines here to further explain their quandary: 6231-32 quando viteno no·l pono atrovare, / né nisuno trovono chi li sapesse y[n]signare [When they saw that they could not find it [the path] / Nor anyone who could show it to them]. "asenoire" 'to guide, to indicate' (T-L col. 577, lines18-45)

6549] Alexandre, v. 3189. There is clearly something missing here as well; in T, this appears as 6238 tute le spiziarie naseno y[n] quela abitanz(i)a, 'all the spices are born in that location'. Perhaps this is another case of end of one line and beginning of another missing.
6552] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): No(n) avons. The second hemistich of this line is different in T. T 6241 Non avemo mesazo, sapiate p[er] vere [We have no suffering, know truly.]

6554] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): qui [tant]ert ; brin: Nicola da Verona, 'lineage' (Di Ninni, p. 450; Pharsale, Continuazione dell'Entrée); T-L col. 1150, "Sproß, Stengel" ['scion, offshoot'; 'stem, stalk']; Matsumura, "ardeur; tige menue," so the expression includes both lineage and valor. Cf. T 6243 a vedere la dona chi è d'alto lignazo [to see the lady who is of high lineage].
6558] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): Qu'ici. There are 15 appearances of "ici" versus 140 of "ci" so we have divided differently.
6568] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): et la dame en demin (emend)
6571] We are presuming a dative construction after "plaise" for a parallel with line 6573.
6572] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 694): Que mesremoue art (!); remoüe: seems here to mean something like 'stir up' (cf. T-L remüer, "rühren"; "umrühren" col. 760)
6577] Presumably this means saying spells.
6578] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 694): a la vetre maison
6580] carme: "componimento poetico" (DELI, bef. 1321, Dante)
6586] MS: ī ombre; T 6275 ben me posite mostrare ombre chy no[n] sono. The abbreviation is expanded in qui since the pronoun is a subject in this interpretation.
6607] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 695): Apalpe nos; since the rest of the discourse is in the second person plural, we presume this is too and that the final syllable is accented.
6611] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 695): sainç [nule] male
6623] Jâ = Ja a
6628] Viscardi (Letteratura franco-italiana, pp. 133-34) includes through line 6636.

6633] li lusage: this seems to be a case of "concretion of the article": that is, lusage is a plural noun for "habits" or "customs." Cf. Rohlfs ¶341. Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 696), followed by Viscardi: si l'usage; the MS reads clearly "li."
6635] sorvage: T-L: sorvenir, hinzukommen, 'to ensue'; Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 696): so(r)vage

6644] MS: le isle; -sl- for -ll- is a frequent paleographical error. Cf. T 6333: la cità (PEB). Of course thus a syllable is added (le isle = two syllables with elision; la ville = three syllables), so unless the first hemistich ends with "ville" and thus does not count the final -e, the line is one syllable too long.
6645] Note the use of verbs of appearing or seeming rather than being.

6649] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 697): est açe; the letters are all written together, not separated. Though OF might suggest pillars, T understood "rooms" (stanzie, v. 6338). The form also suggests an equivalence with "estage," which might mean residences (cf. T-L: rooms; residences).
6653] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," 697): il [i] vont
6654] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," 697): reguardant
6658] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," 698): le charoill(e)

6668] A long epic comparison begins here, to a victor after a tourney and his arrival. Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 698): ant .II. grant (beginning of line missing); Viscardi (Letteratura franco-italiana, p. 135), includes the entire laisse based on Stengel.
6670] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 698): gaaign[é]
6674] Viscardi: puign; T 6362: lo brando nudo [the naked sword].
6676] MS: astu, written as one word
6684] Viscardi: mervoille ot
6687] Viscardi: soie venu
6688] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 699): Yesu! MS: yhu, with abbreviation line over the "h." Throughout, "Yesu" is Stengel's resolution of this abbreviation.
6696] E·maintes = 'En maintes'; cf. Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 699): E[n] maintes
6699] (e): written above the line, very light, no caret below. DELI: vanagloriarsi "vantarsi, essere pieno di sé," 13th century. Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 700): vanglorïer
6707] MS: Mes e non: expunctuated 'e' after the first word

6713] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 700): giant [i] vont; cf. T 6402 molte zente vano a ley p[er] [con]solarla [many people go to her to console her]. Perhaps this "consiller" is meant to be a verb related to consollanse, to console her (for loss of her spouse; see below, v. 6812).

6717] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 701): l'estriver. This is the only appearance of the expression in the text, and "le" is written slightly apart from the following word; see introduction on vowel + s + consonant. Cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 319-20), "étrier," 'stirrup'
6726] stable: cf. Gambino, "Code-mixing nel Bovo d'Antona udinese," p. 78, stabel
6729] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 701): Döes
6731] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 701): pas [ni] noise ni cri
6735] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 701): fiuç (de) Davi
6736] Matthew 27, 46; Mark 5, 34.
6741] Note the word order: le plus + noun + adjective.
6742] Compare the illumination at the bottom of this folio.
6755] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 702): salue[e]

6759] MS, Stengel: l'asist. The queen approaches him then speaks to him; perhaps she then sits too and it is not mentioned. But see T 6448: dapresso luy s'aseta e possa li rasona [near him she sat down and then spoke to him]; perhaps a banal error of misreading a written text to confuse "l" and the long "s"? Or a deliberate choice?
6760] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 703): ne l'[av]oit

6766] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 703): devers, which normally means "in the direction of"; "de devers" would mean from the area of ("du côté de," Matsumura). Thus two words here, as they are in the MS.
6772] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 703): Qu[e] il
6776] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 703): Tant que [d] (l)'enfer aige (Tant que + subjuntive for 'Until')
6778] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): feütee (which would bring the line to 10 syllables); but cf. v. 4129, where two syllables are not necessary.
6779] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): desfiëe
6782] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): dame l'oit
6785] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): delïee; perhaps a better emendation would be "tot [li] delïee," for 12 syllables.
6795] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): enfer [la]

6800] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): g'estoie (in this text, there are two forms that are clearly "stoie"; two clearly "estoie"; two not clear, this and questoie, v. 10177, for the use of the initial e- before s+consonant).
6810] See Dante, Inf. 5, 112-122, for the joy to sadness trope, here reversed.
6817] (qe) inserted above the line with caret below, but very light with tiny letters, not visible in microfilm.
6819]See Scattolini on this section and the antecedent tales ("'Chorisantes itaque puniuntur'").
6823] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 705): Et retorne; perhaps possible since "avoir" is the auxiliary verb of the previous line.

6824] Sections of these three lines of the MS are here practically unreadable since somewhat rubbed off; as the middle of the section, the beginning of this line in particular is difficult to distinguish.
6845] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p.706): m'ait mort'e (ni) perie
6858] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 707): raïne
6864] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 707): s'embla
6867] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 707): embracé
6869] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 708): Aces
6890] Deus, misere mei: see line 2361.

6891] peçé traitor: this could peçe traïtor, "worst traitor"; we have followed Turin's usage of "pechà traditor"; had it been "worst" Turin would have read "peçor" or something similar rather than "pecha" from Latin PECCATU(M). This narrative motif is again a repetition, this time of Ynide's beating herself after she receives the king's ambassadors (vv. 5343-5350). See Morgan, "The Passion of Ynide (I)."
6896] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 709): sentirés [dunc] d'un
6903] See first (left) part of the illumination below, where he holds a rock in his hand while he kneels in the garden.
6911] Le Roman d'Alexandre, Branche 3 for the plot to kill him; Branche 4, laisses 4-11, particularly 8-33 (ed. Harf-Larcner 752-83) for the actual poisoining.
6919] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 710): moy, [diex], ni
6923] See the second (right) part of the illumination below, with fires, three angels (one with an open book) and devils coming out of the house on the right.

6925] Durling and Martinez, Inf. 3.130-33, speaking of winds, note that medieval science based on Seneca's Natural Questions and Aristotle's Meteorology attributed winds in the atmosphere with producing lightning and thunder (pp. 67-68).
6936] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 711): (en)vers
6938-6939] Nunc dimittis: see Vulgate: "Nunc dimittis servum tuum Domine/ Secundum verbum tuum in pace" (Luke 2, 29-32); see note in the translation for context of the quote.

6955] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 712): poït. The right side of the illumination at the bottom of this folio figures the scene in the lines at the beginning of the following folio: three angels descending to Huon, one holding a book open. Though the writing is not legible, it is probably intended to be "Gloria in excelsis" (PEB).
6957] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 712): luy [et] conforter
6958-6959] Gloria in excelsis... in terra pax: cf. Luke 19, 38; Luke 2, 14.
6964] deivent (cf. Stengel, "Keuschheitsprobe," p. 712): could also be read "devient" but since it is clearly here from "devoir" we read it thus.
6975] bocheran: "boquerant, boguerant," TL 1060-1061
6982] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 713): [A]lor
6983] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 713): vers (le) ciel
6984] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 713): qu'envoiantes
6989] MS: por expunctuated after moy; there is also a scratch through the middle of the word, cutting each letter in half. Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 713): (por) [per] diex.
6992] End of Stengel, "Keuschheitsprobe" (his line 7147)

6993] Begin Stengel, "Suche" (his line 7148). He uses square brackets for his emendations/additions, and parentheses for his items to remove. He seeks to regularize the lines to 10 or 12 syllables, usually in comparison with the Turin version and Andrea da Barberino. Our punctuation here frequently differs; it will not be commented unless there is a difference in meaning conveyed by the punctuation.
6994] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 53): stree = OF "estree," [Matsumura, 'route'], T stra
6997] Stengel ("Suche," p. 1): an es le pas; aneslepas: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 292): "eneilepais," "immédiatement."

6998] las: it isn't clear to whom or what this refers. One option would be to Huon himself, since "las" in general either refers to a person or is an abbreviation for 'alas'; however, the forest is the nearer referrent here, and the expression is in rhyme.

6999] Stengel ("Suche," p. 53, for his line 7154), notes tas here = 'Dickicht' [thicket, tangle]; he compares 'a tas', line 10361. However, that would make no sense in hell. T-L gives "Haufe" [heap, pile, hoard] for tas; see T 6684: Passò la costa e la vale e lo paiesse. DEAF: ensemble de personnes ou de choses; boue; Matsumura: amas.
7006] Stengel ("Suche," p. 54): Baldras = Baghdad (citing Langlois)
7009] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 1): Men esciant. The line is 4+6, so needs four syllables in the first hemistich.

7011] Stengel ("Suche," p. 54): talavas (=Schild, "shield"); FEW: talevas, "bouclier en bois"; cf. Roman d'Alexandre "talavat/z" (RIALFrI, 22.XII.2017), from *TALAPACIUM (https://apps.atilf.fr/lecteurFEW/lire/131/35).
7017] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p.1): Pou(t)
7018] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 2): (qu'il)
7026] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 2): Fors (da)
7029] (t): inserted above the line, with a dim caret below. For the flying birds dirtying all with stink, compare the Harpies (Virgil Aeneid 3.226-265 and Dante Inf. 13. 10-15).
7031] c(h)ar: very light insert, with no caret below

7037] storné: Italianism, "stornare" (DELI, bef. 1300), "volgere ad altra parte," to turn to the other side'', from tornare with the s- prefix from DIS- (DELI suggests perhaps on the model of OF "desturner"). To a French reader, it may sound like étonné, 'startled', which would also work in the context, making a perfect example of how F-I works with different publics. It may also be a combination for similar reasons.

7038] See illumination below; on left, ship with line tied to horse; on right, Huon fighting off the birds. Lots of blood, some birds in air, some on ground, and flock coming toward him. Cf. Roman d'Alexander again, for attacks near a pond (Branche 3, laisses 64-85) that include griffons that carry away horses (3, 66; Harf-Lancner pp. 368-87, esp. 370-71).
7042] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 2) : a val
7044] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 2): b[er] natural
7052] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 2): per(e)
7058] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 3) : Pr[ent] les; Stengel seems to be basing his choice on T 6741: prende le coverte del destrero ardito [he seizes the the bold horse's blankets]

7060] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 3): pardesor; Stengel combines many multi-word prepositions (e.g., pardevant below, 7104), so this will not be commented again (he resolves the abbreviation as par for our por; see introduction on abbreviations).

7062] chemis: this is the only appearance of the form in the MS. It is masculine, and there is one appearance of chemin with "prist" (v. 7156), but it is odd that this appear in the middle of arming himself. Three lines cover the same information in T, 6745-47: e luy lo spenze e ponze avè so chamy[n] presso./ Ferma(r)se sa de soe chamy bruno,/ prende le soe arme e lo scu dorato, where the version seems also to have mixed preparing to fight and fleeing.
7074] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 3): pecéou; pecé is from 'peçoiier', 'to break apart, shatter'.

7075] (l)aris: again, very light insertion above the line and no caret. This was probably a correction from a saut du même au même: the preceding al ends with an l so the writer realized afterward the missing l.
7081] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 3): hom [abesoign]os
7082] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 3): que l'en face
7085] rescos: DELI riscossa, before 1348, 'without recompense' [possible]; cf. OF rescos, 'help' (T-L, col. 1000)
7086] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 3): navant; nos is a deformation of "nuls" for rhyme.
7087] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 3): l'em para; empara from "emparer" (T-L, col. 90, 'surround')
7091] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 4): que descoverte [f]os
7095] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 4): l'air en est
7097] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 4): quuens e(t)l(i) destrer
7099] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 4): Le quuens [Hue] d'Auvergne

7104] sereç: it is unclear whether this refers to Huon or to how Huon was holding the shield, but in either case, Huon is crouched under his shield, trying to avoid being bitten; the adjective is the past participle of the verb "serrer" (TL, cols. 548-554). Cf. T 6787 Por davante se mete el suo scudo [He put his shield in front of him], a simplified form that indicates there may have been difficulty comprehending the tradition.
7110] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 4): qe stoit, as always
7117] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 4): fust (il) cheü

7128] Possibly sant desis; see translation for alternate meanings. The second hemistich here is problematic; desis is written together, but Huon is already on the ground so does not seem to follow. Cf. T 6811 e luy se lamenta di sé, apena sente de soa p[er]sona [he bemoaned his state, as soon as he felt himself, i. e., came to].
7131] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 5): P[ou] sant
7132] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 5): Mès [cum se] membre

7134] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 5): a envis. Both forms exist in this text and in F-I; cf. enoy (15 times); ennue (1); enu (a grant - , v. 7115); envie (9, par/por envie 7 times). Looking at RIALFrI, we see 11 a(d) envi/z/s, and 6 a enoi/r/enui (19 April 2021).
7136] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 5): pecheor [et] çaitis
7138] For the second hemistich here, see v. 7135, that ends in the same way; this line might be a scribal saut. See translation.
7145] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 5): Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 5): meioré; but cf. pejor (T-L); meillor (T-L)
7149] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 5): Queou
7151] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 5): il manjue; here i·l = il + la
7157] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 5): herra [il]
7162] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 6): navant
7165] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 6): Tigris; bru: cf. GdA, "rumore, fracasso" short for bruit (vv. II, 692, V, 717; XI, 766).
7168] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 6): transglotu
7170] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 6): iluech [il] fust
7173] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 6): A (tal) fuson (s'en) ist
7179] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 6): söe grant vertu
7180] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 6): Que l'en aït

7182] a la nom: note the feminine article here, as in v. 11653; the reason is unclear. The formula "a nom de" or "a le nom de" is relatively frequent, and there seems to be no motivation for a different structure in these two lines.
7209] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 7): maint pais; the line can be construed as 7+5.
7217] The initial letter of quuens is capitalized, which is unusual for this MS.

7226] avit: If read aiut, then the meaning would differ: "Well he helped him so that the horse is not hurt." This section is difficult to parse. Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 7): avi[n]t. See also note in the translation, and compare T 6909 Ben li avene che lo chavalo no[n] li peria [he was lucky that the horse didn't perish there].

7227] trasfumé: cf. AdB, "échauffé, exalté" (vv. 425/37), from It. *strafumanto/trafumato, 'riscaldato a fumare' [heated to the point of steaming] (vol 3, p. 322). The term also appears in GdA, but without definition.
7232] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 8): revint [el] serpant
7233] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 8): Lor s'aseüre; this line is missing from T.
7236] The division between downstrokes in the MS is unreliable: p[er]cuit/p[er]ciut are both possible.
7237] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 8): regracïé

7242] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 8): jor[nee]s; this depends upon the pronunciation of the number .IX.. If it is a more Italianate two-syllable word, then an extra syllable is not necessary. There is only one written-out form: nof (v. 897), so it is difficult to know what the standard was, if any.
7245] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 8):Requïer (not necessary: line is 4+8).
7252] mal gré que: see T-L 597, concessive

7253] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 8): Sovent regrete... Stengel has contrued the initial lines of this laisse diffently, ending the first sentence with the previous line rather than understading aige as the subjuntive of "avoir".

7260] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 8): ni [a] talant; cf. T 6943: De tornare y[n]dré non à talente ny corazo. It is possible, however, that both talant and corage are verb forms (from "talenter" [T-L 63] and "(en)coragir" [T-L 241] respectively).
7264] There is a scraped section of MS before trova, long enough for one letter. It too has the appearance of liquid correction fluid in the MS.
7272] Stengel ("Huons Suche"): tut ore, as always (not further remarked)
7274] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 8): De biendir il non cesse, proier... This line is missing from Turin, so clearly caused some confusion. biendir: see note, line 1019.
7275] Note the unusual abbreviation (for this MS) above sorpagne; el = et + el.

7278] sovragne: this word appears twice elsewhere as an epithet of God ("rois/roy sovragne," vv. 5859, 7269), always in rhyme. It only appears elsewhere in Nicola da Verona's Pharsale (v. 825; RIALFrI). The line is not present in T. Because of the frequent palatalizations of -n– in forms of venir, this could be a form with sovra + venir; cf. for example, "vagne" in v. 7270 in this laisse.
7279] marois here could be the standard OF usage, "swamp."
7282] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 8): tue et magagne
7283] MS: marois as 7279 above. T 6965: De le prede; cf. T 6963:Li gra[n] predon (cf. 7279 here). This description recalls also elements of the illumination on 54v, with the birds and fire.
7285] MS: q vif (q with line over top, normally que)
7295] el = et + el
7296] rocheit: cf T-L recet

7306] See illumination below: merpeople, male and female. Possible source: there are a number of similar monsters in the Roman d'Alexandre, 3, 164 (for mermaids); for men in two parts above the navel, 3, 181, etc.
7307] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 10): ensus

7308] This section seems a bit confused. See T 6988- 6900: che da l'onbrio y[n] suso estatura d'omo tereno, / e dal mezo y[n] zosa statura de peso veramente. / Dentro lo maro [con]versano, del peso vano ma[n]zando [that from the navel up they had the built of a man, and from the middle down, the build of a fish. They lived in the sea, they ate fish]. Either Turin has added a final hemistich and an initial hemistich, or two half-lines have been lost. Magiant would then be missing an abbreviation line for -n-. Another possibility is "imagiant," looking like (from "imagier" (T-L col 1433, imagier2), which we accept here.

7312] As Meregazzi says ("L'Ugo dAlvernia," p. 19), the Roman d'Alexandre cites "li Otifal" (p. 319, v. 19, ed. Michelant), so we have divided this as "L'Ocifal." However, Harf-Larcner uses "Liotifal" (III, 2452) for "Ichtyophages"; grammatically, an article seems to be necessary in both the Alexandre and here. Following events are also similar to those in the Roman d'Alexandre (Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 22).
7318] Stengel ("Huons Suche"): esciant. However, the second hemistich is only 5 syllables without the trema.
7321] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 10): l'eve [en vont]; we presume that the verb ending has been altered for the rhyme, since the line as it stands is 12 syllables.
7323] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 10): jor (ap)parant
7325] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 10): Voit [le] le
7329] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 10): [Et] en
7334] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 10): i voiremant; however the three strokes are written linked together.

7340] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 11): hor'è; it is not clear whether ert of the previous line is the auxiliary verb for this line as well, in which case it would read "monté... hore desanduç." However, monte en requires elision for a 6+6 construction, so we presume that the final syllable of monte is not stressed.
7342] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 11): fu [al] monter
7343] si at end of line with a dot before it; in the line, a caret below with the same dot to indicate point of insertion.
7346] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 11): Mout [il]; in the previous line, Stengel writes ne for the conjunction.

7347] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 11): abescuç T-L, bescoz (en- "schief," [crooked, skew] col 940; cf besochier, 'schleudern' col. 939, "swerve, skid"). T 7029: el se sta besognoso, interprets "abescuç" as "abesoigner": 'he had put himself in need'; as always, Stengel divides se stoit; not further remarked.
7351] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 11): fanduç
7352] See illumination below with rendering of the creatures.

7358] au pré: nowhere does aupré appear, whereas pré and aprés do appear. Furthermore, here the text makes a point of saying that Huon has just come down the mountain. T 7037: quando un tal remore è al pra venuto. Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 11): storbeillons li [est] au pré.

7360] Illumination in fact shows creatures first standing by water then falling from sky amid flames and light. Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 11): vive force (but 1st letter higher, last r); cf. T: Per liura forza, line 7039; 'livre force' [literally, free force].
7366] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 11): (Au)Si; ; Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia" (p. 21), notes the similarity here to the Roman d'Alexandre (Harf-Larcner, p. 492-94).

7367] Cf. Dante and Brunetto Latini in Inferno: the seventh circle, those of the violent, includes the violent against nature, the sodomites, who walk under a rain of fire (canto 15). As Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," points out (p. 21), these two lines also reflect almost exactly the Roman d'Alexandre; see Roman d'Alexandre; ed. Harf-Lancner, pp. 494-95, ll. 3156-57.
7369] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 11): Que (de)
7372] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 12): encor pluç
7378] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 12): confonduç
7382] miel: cf. T 7063, "melio," 'better'
7384] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 12): (de)storbeillons
7391] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 12): Lu e[l]
7392] biendir: see note, line 1019.
7395] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 12): Mainte(s)... conquesons
7401] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 12): l'en a öy
7404] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 12): cist [si] ert
7411] Fors: F-I 'perhaps' (Matsumura, citing PP 2494; T-L col 2144, lines 29-32, same citation).
7415] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 13): Si[l] leise
7420] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 13): environ
7421] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 13): onquisons
7422] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 13): ot hons
7424] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 13): non ay; MS: nō nay
7428] fi: auxiliary verb typical of N. Italian passive construction (Rohlfs vol3, ¶ 736). See also line 6774, "fi desevree."
7431] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 13): ni voil mon civus c'or mel... This line is absent from T.
7437] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 13): nuls [mal]

7443] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 13): ert [en] moy; certainly there could have been a saut du même au même omitting the preposition: (in) moy, in which case the line would be 8+4, an alexandrine.

7450] rais: the term normally means 'ray, rays' [as of light] in this text; here, it is clealy not that. Perhaps it is from rere, "raser, gratter" [to scrape, scratch] past participle rés (or similarly written form). It however, also be related to OI "reo, " 'cruel, accustomed to doing evil' (DELI, before 1292), which would confer a different nuance to this passage: he would need to not be guilty of sin.
7455] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 14): dit [il]
7462] arais: we are interpreting this related to the verb "areër," to be prepared, disposed, equipped, dressed" (T-L col. 511); noun, "aroi" (T-L col. 541, lines 26 ff.).
7463] Stengel ("Huons Suche," 14): en es li pais (T-L col 1472, isnelepas)
7464] Stengel ("Huons Suche," 14): Saluër le veut [il]
7465] Stengel ("Huons Suche," 14): salüé
7467] plais written below the line, following the next line with a box around three sides.
7468] ais: Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 53) notes that this is a third person singular present indicative; note also again a missing abbreviation for "n" ("tençon") .
7475] a il is written as one word in the MS
7487] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 15): de spir(i)t
7488] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 15): part (ala)
7492] ap[re]nonl: one cannot help but wonder if there is perhaps something missing here; lines 7475-93 are problematic; Turin has omitted the equivalent of lines 7492-93 and altered line 7490.

7493] MS: asoil; a soil is a difficult expression; it is unclear whether this is a single word or two; it is written together in the MS. "soil" in general is "alone" or "sun" in F-I (cf. RIALFrI; it can also be a form of the verb "soloir"). "asoil" appears in the V4 Roland; R. F. Cook, "a soil" v. 6009, p. II/372; he notes in his glossary, "unclear" and refers to his note; Beretta, v. 6009, gives "asoil" in his edition, saying that until it is clear to what tradition the line refers no conclusive meaning can be assigned (373 n6009). Possibly the combination "asoilveç" could be a form of "assoudre," 'absolve', but then the person of the verb is not comprehensible. And in the MS "veç" is written a little apart from the previous word.
7495] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 15): Volonter vos [di]ray
7498] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 15): si confort[e]
7499] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 15): sont [forment]
7504] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 15): [et] dricer

7508] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 15): l'out (il)
7512] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 15): il satisfie

7513] mendie: cf. T 7194: nostraname[n]te li dizea, com homo mo[n]dano [mondano: of the world, "mondo"]. It seems unlike that Huon be speaking to a fellow human as if he were a beggar, which is the lexical family to which mend- belongs. The error of e/o or o/e is a frequent scribal error.

7519] MS: E vanaglorie; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 16): E[n] vana-glorie; cf. T 7200: en vanagloria no[n] vole romanere nemicho [he doesn't want to remain an enemy in vainglory]. If manir were a form of maniier, emendation would not be necessary, but the line would not make sense.
7524] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 16): poïs[se]
7527] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 16): douto ge
7534] gart: used as a subjunctive; see vv. 1437, 5022, 5213, etc.
7540] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 16): enpechieç; this is more OF, 'tormented,' where our reading follows that of T 7221: y[n] pechaty
7543] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 16): selonch (le) pooir
7544] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 16): Doi[ven]t fer
7545] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 16): se [acono]ist
7546] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 16): en ames

7554] MS: la fair; the meaning of this line is not clear initially; Turin adds a verb, T7234: perché l'afare è si grande, como eio vo pur pensando [because the matter is so important, as I believe]. However, Par as a verb clarifies the meaning. See also note in the translation.
7555] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 17): voir(e)ment
7556] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 17): Fache, ages

7589] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 18): cel le plaist
7590] Epic simile: Huon is like good gold in a furnace, the longer it's there, the better it's refined.
7592] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 18): clers [il] vient

7594] MS: puiç? The second letter is not clear, it is smeared at the top; there are three strokes after the "p." cf. proer in V4=prover, 'to test, to confront one thing with another' (Beretta, p. 588, sub voce). There is a very light line over the descender of the "p." T 7275: che y[n] molte afare li è aparù dezà e delà [for in many situations it appeared to him here and there], but here a form of 'to appear' does not seem to be likely.
7599] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 18): cuers l[e cl]ama
7603] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 18): s'il en scape...sciant
7607] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 18): il a costum' a; but see OF "acostumer," 's'habituer, avoir l'habitude' (T-L col. 118)
7612] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 18): sigue; this is a possible emendation (and T 7292's reading), but equally Huon might make the sign of the cross over his path, as the MS seems to read here.
7613] Cf. Luke 2, 19 "Maria autem conservabat omnia verba haec, conferens in corde suo." (Vulgate) .
7614] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 18): pur doutre
7616] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 18): son affer(e)
7620] DELI attento: "che tiene la mente rivolta ad un oggetto" dated to the fourteenth century (Dante); related to "attenti" used with military for "Attention!"
7627] Meregazzi notes a parallel with the Roman d'Alexandre, where griffons carry Alexander to see the world (Harf-Larcner, pp. 606-43; Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 21).
7634] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 19): d[es] osiaus
7639] See illumination below: Huon vs. serpent with two griffons, bleeding badly.
7644] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 19):si stant
7647] veit... a soy saçant: a reflexive-type periphrastic construction; cf. Ménard p. 172, ¶ 180.
7648] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 19): qu'il [ert] mort

7653] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 19): nuls [autre]; cf. T 7332: né nulo altro y[n]stormento da pasare [nor any other [vessel] to pass]; see Holtus, Lexikalische, pp. 317 sub voce 'estormant'.
7654] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 19): fer[e] nuls
7665] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 20): le mes(t)ere
7668] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 20): li veu[len]t

7669] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 20): nos(i) partir[ont]; haëre cf. Holtus heire, 'chemin' in the EE, v. 5621 (Lexikalische, p. 347); but it sounds like a calque on a biblical expression, a combination of "aage" and "ahé" in rhyme position for 'life, lifetime' (cf. Holtus, Lexikalische p. 193): 'he would never leave him any day of his life'. Cf. the frequent biblical expression, 'days of his life' (with 15 examples in a textual search; for example, 1 Kings 15: 5 "[...] because David did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, and did not turn aside from anything that he commanded him all the days of his life [...]" (NOAB, p. 439)). T 7351: da luy no[n] se departirano niun zorno p[er] esere y[n] suo altorio [he would not leave him on any day in order to be in his aide] ("altorio" TLIO, 'aiutorio' https://tlio.ovi.cnr.it/voci/001752.htm, 18.X.2021).
7670] MS: si sa acostere; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 20): compagn(on)... si s'acostere
7671] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 20): qui(ln) non

7677] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 20): d'amere; this could be divided d'amere, "of loving"; however, it lacks a pronoun as a referrent and is divided "da/mere" (onto a new line in the margin below). See also the various references in Dante's Comedy to Virgil as parent: Inf. 23.38, for instance. T 7359: d'amare
7680] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 20): droit[e]

7685] These three lines are problematic; there seems to be an unannounced change of subject, for Huon is not afraid, rather it is his horse. Turin is quite different; 7366-68: de quelo afare no∙l vite miga homo spaventare; / e li osely sono honesty e cridano como foseno a la rivera;/ al suo signore donano [con]forto com lor pono più fare [for that event no one saw him frightened at all; / and the birds are faithful and cry as if they were on the river bank; / they give their lord comfort as best they can].
7688] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 20): dote (fou ni)

7689] MS: perice, peris="de pierre" (EE, GdA), but in 1355-56, the pope says that there is wood in it. Also, this adjective would not normally precede a noun. Cf. T 7371: p[er] la pizola crose che lo papa li feze donare; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 20): petite crois
7694] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): dentrel(e)

7698] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21):merveilloç; the final letter is unusual; it is written up next to the "o" it may be an "s" or perhaps, as Stengel writes, a "ç". But there are no other "ç"s in the section, and no other form of the adjective appears with that grapheme, so I read it as an "s."
7699] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): ne qui avenir
7700] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): non partant

7701] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): soie tot foit; s'oie might be soie here, the feminine possessive adjective, in an Italianate construction. This would be the only time in the text the form would appear after the noun. It can also, however, be s'oie: "he also had [held] the entire time." Line 7701 has no equivalent in T. The three lines 7701-7703 refer to the episode in the illumination at the bottom of the page, where burning masses fall into water, and spirits are led along the side of the stream; the language seems to be corrupted. Compare T 7383: Vite un monte che tuto se corla e tuto brusa [He saw a mountain that shakes all over and burns all over], for B 7702; there is no equivalent to 7701. Perhaps it means "He called on God, Holding the cross in his hand the whole time." In line 7702, the word "sevre" or "seure" could be related to "(es)sever," 'drain, channel, ditch' from 'to stream out, flow away' (similar to Modern English "sewer"). Cf. Matsumura, "essee": "canal d'écoulement." Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): Si l'avoit seüré [...] qui crolle. In fact there would seem to be a confusion of what is illustrated here: burning masses appear from v. 7365 to 7398 (v. 51V, where the illumination instead is of the divided humans, vv. 7349-62); the griffons ultimately lift Huon and his horse to the other side.
7704] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): jusque[n] la; for marois, see note for line 2702, above.
7705] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): conso[m]ant

7707] This line is out of place, since the spirits have not yet been mentioned; in Turin it is omitted. In order for the text to make sense, the translation reorders lines 7707-7710. See also the note to the translation.
7716] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): se fie
7717] Ên='Et en'
7719] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): se [es]laisent
7720] engita: from "enjeter" (T-L, cols 431-432)
7722] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): D[e] aler
7726] qu'i' vos...: 'that I would tell you'
7729] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): de spir(i)t
7734] quue[r]: could this be an error of abbreviation for "quue[n]"?

7736] enatement from "anatemer" (T-L, col 511 "nateme, anateme"; Matsumura, "anatemer," 'maudire'); T 7414: en altamente y vano quily che lor y[n][con]trano [those people went crying loudly [to] those whom they met]; the initial word clearly was difficult to comprehend or misunderstood. qeroit is a hapax in this text; one wonders if it were originally *"geroit," 'who made war on them'; cf. 4783, geroie, and 166, gerrer, both in rhyme.
7741] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): parçoit
7743] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): emprist; here we construe 'emprendre' as MSF "apprendre"
7744] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): crïe as spirç [disant]
7748] Ms: sb'tāce; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): e spir(i)ç
7751] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): [ja nul] n'en ace

7759] dople: this could be second person singular or plural; the preceding line is all second person plural in addressing Huon and his party; the following line is second person singular (as), so either is possible. Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): vos le dople
7760] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): main, [que] garder

7761] T 7439:romanemo quie, "we stay here"; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): por ce mainir a toy. Though standard OF grammars suggest that the infinitive is only used as an imperative following Or de or in a negative (cf. Ménard, ¶ 161, p. 160), here the construction seems to indicate an imperative. In Italian, the use of the imperative in the negative is and was accepted; the positive was and is used for "generic instructions" (e.g., public signs or cooking instructions; see Maiden and Robustelli ¶14.8, p. 248).
7762] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): "Autre non puet [estre]." di[t] le quuens demanoy; cf. T 7440: "Altro no[n] pò esere," lo [con]te dize," de presente."

7764.1] T 7442: "Ora me dite," dize lo [con]te, "a ponto a ponto, no[n] me celate [Now tell me," said the count, "point by point, don't hide (it) from me]. Turin has two forms of the verb "to say." Here we seem have "Ore m'oÿ," "Now listen to me" in order to keep the syllable count. The verb form, however, is second person singular, not plural as at the end of the line.

7766] An alternative for lines 7766-67 with different punctuation implying different speakers: "Figure ont d'om teran." "Tot ce vos non ageç; / Que atent ce a toy?" plusor dit demaineç.
7767] demaineç: this as a form of "demanois" in rhyme. See also translation note.
7769] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 23): E un de ceus respont: "[Tu] par un forseneç (cf. T 7447)
7771] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 23): entroisque; perhaps he is interpreting as "entruesque," 'jusqu'à ce que', 'until', but that has no sense here.

7800.1] MS: puer, with i above the line: form of Latin puer, 'child'.
7800.2] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 24): puer (!)
7800.3] Reference to the Massacre of the Innocents (narrated Matt. 2.16-18) perpetrated by Herod on all male children two years old and under after the birth of Jesus.
7804] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 24): Or[e] poëç... e[st]

7805] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 24): veör pöé; noient: F-I noier, "ennuyer" ('to be annoyed'; AdB and Matsumura, sub voce); quais: Holtus, Lexikalisches, "calme, tranquille" (p. 415); compare v. 8048.
7806]Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 24): Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 24): Qu'il i ont.... qu'il i a apresté

7809] Gayne, subject case for Ganelon, the antagonist of the Song of Roland, who betrayed Roland, Charlemagne's nephew and the hero of the French army; also in Dante's Inferno 32.122, the ninth circle of traitors to country or party, Antenora. Marsile is presented as the Muslim King of Saragossa in that poem.
7813] Cf. Brunetto Latini to Dante, Inf. 118-120, and various places where the sinners cannot remain because of another group coming.
7818] Notice the irony: earlier the speaker avoids the name of God (vv. 7771, 7773, 7790) could not be mentioned there, but here he speaks of "your Lord."
7824] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 24): malectïon; we construe this verse instead as a case of the Italian "Dio" in two syllables.
7828] There seems to be something missing here, a verb. Stengel: [s'en vont]. T 7509: Le sperity malvasy s'en vano al centro del profondo [the evil spirits go to the center of the depths/hell]
7829] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 24): segueot tot foy
7830] andon: T-L andon ? (Horn), col. 384; we presume it to be a form of "andare."
7831] marois: see above, note for v. 2702; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 24): en chaïron; it is written together in the MS, so we leave it thus, though it might possibly be two words.

7832] It would seem that there was a saut du même au même here, with the verb "to fall" omitted, that probably began with "cai-" as well as the word çaitif. Cf. cait (5950), chait (v. 7281). The line is missing in T, it would be between vv. 7513 and 7514.
7836] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 25): defend[oi]t
7841] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 25): s'(en) avit

7849] arche: The meaning of this term has been debated, especially in relation to St. Peter, in the Couronnement de Louis (see Lefevre, "L'arche"; Crespo, "Alla ricerca"). For Noah, the question is particularly problematic; see note in the translation and line 8139 that speaks of when the arche landed. Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 25): Arche-Noëç en son; in Venetian, it is attested in the meaning 'tomb'; cf. Alfredo Stussi, ed., Testi veneziani, p. 189.

7853] MS: ponser. The first vowel was corrected; it seems that an "a "was changed to an "o." The lines of the "o" are heavier. Laise for "las"; cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 359), "laiser," on the confusion of stems.
7859] MS: endormï; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 25): Pois se stoit [il] colgieç, endormi( r) tost si fu

7869] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 25): [en] une chave; roçet can be a cave or rock-dwelling (T-L col. 1360). Receto is the term that appears in T 7550: un povro receto y[n]n-una chava zò fo [a poor refuge was there in a cave]; cf . T 6977 (here 7296, rocheit). That form reflects OF recet ('retreat, refuge, shelter, sanctuary; hiding place; shelter, abode' (T-L col. 397). Here the form could possibly be a combination of "roche" and "recet," or a confusion of the two.

7870] MS, Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): regulal en fu; whether this is in fact rhoticism or an error is unclear. See Mainone, "Laut," p. 54, for other examples of "l" for "r" as well as its omission.
7872] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): Quant [il] le vit
7873] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): Lor vient...que [i]l n'oit
7874] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): si [a] dit
7877] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): [Et] quant

7880] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): [...] indicates he believes that something is missing here. In T 7563 there is something similar, but it seems that the original(s) were confused with who might be holding a cross that shone; there is no stated subject in the next line. In B, is the final line of a column, and that can sometimes cause losses between one line and the next line.
7882] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): "Je toy conjur" [dist il] "au nom da part Yhesu...
7890] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): Cum [je] vau
7891] MS: Une cleres; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): Un(e) clercs; T 7572: un cherego y[n] letre

7893] MS: d'ceuemāt; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): dire [saince] decevemant. Another syllable is needed for 6+6 syllables; perhaps it should be emended to "de ce veremant"on the model of T 7574: Forsse tanto vuy posite dire veramente. veremant appears twice in B — one of those times two lines above — and "de ce" is a common formula. In that case, it would mean, "But this much I can tell you one of these truly."
7898] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): doman(dan)t
7999] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): contree et
7900] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): entent entemant
7901] See the illumination on 57R: there is what appears to be a casket on top of the mountain.
7902] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 26): Ensi [fu] le dilúvie, cum a diex
7903] MS: De ogne gnäcion danimal; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 27): De ogne gneracion d'animal (i)ci fu ver(e)mant; T 7584 De tute generazion d'animaly. Cf. 7306: une generacion de home
7908] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 27): pués [fu]; we are interpreting "isant" as a conjugated verb here; cf. Mainone (Formen, pp. 34-35 "eissir," for other forms).
7911] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 27): no[s] va lui[n]tanant, probably using T 7592: Sopra la montagna chi demore no[n] vede luntano [Those who live on top of the mountain do not see far].
7913] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 27): le jor dou vener[di] sant
7918] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 27): lor (tot) l'animal...beneisant

7921] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 27): et achoi (!) atant; there is a problem with this line and this expression: "achoi" or "a choi"? There is a small space between "a" and "choi" in the MS. T 7602: e l'afeto atanto, totally unrelated to B's expression. In RIALFrI, under "coi" appear two terms: "per / par choi" = 'pouquoi', and "choi" = quiet (cf. T-L coisier, cols 547-548, referred from "acoisier"). In the second case, the verb in the first part of the line would probably need emending as well: Qui tout voudroit 'couter l'estre et achoi atant [...] (escouter, T-L cols 988-999; cf. forms of "scouter" and "escouter"; "ascouta"), but this would not help the sense of the line within the laisse, since the next line refers to telling a lot and being quiet. We construe "atant" here from "atenir," 'apartenire; convenir' (Matsumura; T-L 635).
7923] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 27): diroi ge
7928] This line resembles those of Dante's Commedia where Dante signals to the reader to pay attention; e.g., Inf. 9.61-63.

7940] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): per(e); there is an empty ruled line in the the MS between lines 7940 and 7941; Stengel inserts: [Soe mer fu estraite voiremant de Rabis], derived from T 7660: soa madre fo veramente trata de Rabisia [His mother came truly from Araby].
7942] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): Hom(e)
7946] Arleschamps / Aliscans is the famous battle that Guillaume d'Orange [William of Orange] fought against the Saracens, losing all his kinfolk, and especially Vivian.
7948] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): j'è par nom
7950] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): [a] moy

7952] arche: we follow the use of Crespo ("Alla ricerca"), as indicated in his discussion of the Couronnement de Louis, especially relevant since he cites F-I versions of the Chanson de Roland (pp. 349-50): 'tomba degna di un martire della fede' [tomb worthy of a martyr to the faith]. With thanks to JCV for calling our attention to the published discussions.
7955] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): [A] sainct Jacque; the "de" may be a reflection of the Italian "da" for "at the house of" (cf. French "chez" or Latin "apud"), so appropriate here.
7958] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): Sil(e)

7959] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): laide[n]gé. Once again, a line is missing here in comparison with T 7641: E p[er] chamỳ fosemo prisy y[n] quel locho da nemisy [And en route we were taken prisoner in that place by enemies].
7960] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): e (ces) mon. This is a typical Italianate construction: cf. "questo mio amico." Rather than not count the word, one can count "veeç" as one syllable.

7962] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): [re]viençerent; i vençerent: "viençerent" would be a hapax; there are three downstrokes in the MS, and they do not seem to be divided. "vençer" and "vengier" (in various forms) do appear, and we therefore divide. The scribe may have mixed "venir" and "vengier." T 7644: sopra nuy vene soa grande yra mortale [on us came his/their overwhelming anger], which is quite different from our text here.
7963] taus: plural of "tal"; cf. EE, vv. 11607, 14825, also in rhyme.

7964] vasaus: while this looks at first glance as a plural of "vassal", cf. T 7646 P[er] amor de Dio y[n] pase le portasemo vasalo [For the love of God, in peace we brought him...], the last word could also be "vaissel," offering one of the common chores of slaves or servants, to serve at table (T-L vaissel, 'vessel', col. 90, lines 10ff).
7965] terraus: plural of "terral," 'rampart' (T-L 257, lines 31 ff.); taken as part-for-the-whole (synecdoche), 'fortress'
7971] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): recov[r]irent

7972] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 28): söe; cf. T 7652: desopra nuy tornò soa yra de lor malvasetà [they turned their anger and evil on us]. "raille" here seems to have been linked to 'rage' (versus the rallying of v. 1830); see introduction on -ge- for conditional endings.
7973] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 29): jorne[e]
7975] aus: each time this term appears here in B, it refers to a group of people, FM "eux"; thus our interpretation here.
7981] Stengel ("Huons Suche"): söe part; if the verse is construed as 7+5 syllables the trema is not necessary.
7985] neïs: T-L col. 582; "pas même" (Matsumura)
7988] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 29): (a)loïs (T-L col 308, line 20: aloer)
7992] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 29): cum [nos] or
7997] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 29): tenoit [il] la ville et li do[n]jon
7998] Stengel ("Huons Suche," 29): après (de)
8005] Stengel ("Huons Suche," 29): Non oy
8010] This section of the MS is difficult to read; perhaps there was water damage? Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 29): öy ... tendre a don
8011] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 30): embrace[r], ne dit [ne] oy
8014] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 30): does not include this line in the quote
8017] tenir plait: parler (T-L col. 1073 plait, "Rede, Erörterung, Auseinandersetzung"; Matsumura, tenir parlement, parole ou plait, "parler, délibérer")
8025] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 30): dampné [en] vont; the elaborate simile here recalls Dante's use of natural comparisons in Inferno, such as that of the waterfall in Canto 16. 91-105.
8027] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 30): ille fusent
8029] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 30): fe[ï]sent
8034] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 30): hom(e)

8035] despont: T-L deposer (col. 1426, line 1: "absetzen", 'dispose'); cf. Italian disporre (TLIO, disporre 1 vb. 2, "Rendere qno incline o pronto a qsa; indirizzare qno o qsa verso un det. fine (anche pron.)".

8039] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 30): De j'a sté e sunt; in Italian usage 'to be' is conjugated with 'to be' as an auxiliary, so ja, as seen elsewhere is 'already', and sunt sté is the present perfect of 'to be', e' 'I'.
8042] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 31): Diex [vos] aït
8047] païs: the umlaut here indicates 'country' as the meaning rather than the syllable count (see Conseils, fasc. 1, pp. 51-52).
8054] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 31): osero ge (see introduction)
8057] scharagais: see "scaraguaita," Bezzola, Abbozzo, p. 154.
8058] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 31): [ce]l erbais

8064] MS: en dir; the emendation is Stengel's; cf. 8066 following. T 7746: Tuto li dize l'esere
