8068] Cf. Matsumura: griçoler (sub voce), citing DEAF G 1369; see also Morlino, "Contributi al lessico italiano," pp. 74-76.
8074] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 31): [r]estora. But T-L estora, "gut machen"; "ersetzen" etc. (cols. 1419-1420).
8078] Stengel ("Huons Suche,"p. 31): Poisqi
8081] Stengel ("Huons Suche,"p. 32): mal pais...seürer
8089] Stengel ("Huons Suche,"p. 32): mostraou santier

8090] fruscle: the meaning is unclear. DELI offers "fruscolo" 'ramo secco' [dry branch]; Matsumura and T-L send from "fros" to "fro." Matsumura gives "combat" also as a definition, citing Meraugis F 2894. The context suggests problematic humans (possibly of various varieties) in contrast to animals. Stengel ("Suche," p. 61): fruscle, T 7771 frosche, probably It. "fruscolo" [small dry branch]
8093] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 32): sent(r)ent, following the Turin use of "sentir" rather than "s'entrer"
8094] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 32): qui (lor) veïst

8105] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 32): Mout (en) fu
8111] roteç: T-L roter4 (col 1512, lines 8 ff), cf "aroter"; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 33): luy [a]roteç.
8114] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 33): la [ou] ont
8115] MS: aíal. This line is missing from T so there is no comparison; this is Stengel's reading that we follow ("Huon's Suche," p. 33).
8117] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 33): Mout la va [re]gardant
8120] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 33): la tient [et] aseç

8123] MS: avoir. T 7803: per sy avea pregà [he had prayed for himelf]. Though the MS is very clear, this makes the greatest sense and is a typical copying error. Should one instead run it together with the following line, it could be construed that he staying up all night having prayed, but it seems to be a stretch.
8124] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 33): l'ajorneç
8125] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 33): Söe veine; T-L col. 162, "venie" ; Matsumura "venie" and "veine" (sub voce)
8129] sclap: T-L esclate (col 919, lines 33 ff)
8130] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 33): requer[t]

8136] An octave is the week following a holy day, based upon the Latin system of counting the day from which the count is made (that includes the day in progress); so, a week. Cf. T-L uitave. For the tradition of celebrating festivals with octaves and the history of the tradition, see https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11204a.htm, "Octave" (18 May 2021).
8143] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 33): aüneç
8145] This is an apo koinu, where the object of the preposition in the first hemistich is the subject of the second; see Ménard, Manuel, ¶ 217.

8148] This is section is problematic, with le vereç twice, vereç three times. T 7828-29: Cum canty de meludie mé no[n] le vedirite / alcuna volta, pur vedere li porite [...] [While you sing songs, you will never see them / at all, yet you will be able to see them ...].
8149] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 34): apert(e)mant
8152] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 34): savoir d[e] alchun; ; see below (vv. 8204-8213) for the execution of this need to communicate in writing.
8163] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 34): öyr
8164] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 34): [Pués] a terre
8165] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 34): animal (et) tot (ces) qui
8166] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 34): adès [tre]tot

8167] MS: Sue fenue.The form "fenue" or "efenue" does not appear anywhere else in F-I literature or in OF dictionaries. There are four downstrokes; it might be a form for "epiphany," but that would add a syllable. Another possibility might be "service" if the "f" is an error for a long "s" and there is a "c" missing; but the s/f error is not frequent in this MS. The tradition was clearly corrupt; see T 7847: Suo hofizio fazea [he performed his office]. Stengel: Sue fenue ("Huons Suche," p. 34), with a note on p. 62, "Is somehow fenue deformed from synfonie?" However, in vv. 8125 and 8400, the construction with a form of "faire" and venie appears, and in 8400 in fact in almost exactly the same construction in almost the exact same word order and usage, and makes sense, so we have thus emended. Possibly the initial f is an anticipation of feisent that follows, with a confusion of minims afterward.
8170] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 34): [Et] quant Ugon
8173] biendir: see note, v. 1019.
8176] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 34): avant (et) Ugon; s'en va cf. T-L 294, l. 32 ff.
8179] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): oi ça (iça: 'ici'); T 7859: non piaze miga [didn't please at all]
8181] parlla[n]t: the final t/ is almost entirely washed out; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): parllan
8186] mener, T-L 1412 "behandeln"
8192] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): per[e] aresteç

8197] anbaiser: seems to be a combination of "embracier"+ "baisier"; OF dictionaries list enbaisier as an alternative to baisier, but the Italian abbracciare, attested at the beginning of 13th century and pre-1321 in Dante, offers a parallel prefix (DELI). Two verbs appear as its equivalent in T 7877: Crede lor prendre et abrazare e basare cosie [He thought to take them and embrace and kiss them thus]. The situation– affection for the departed, as in Vergil's Aeneid 6 and in Ynide's visit from her father, with an inability to embrace– has created an overlap, making translation also difficult. Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): an baiser
8199] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): A maint (et) maint
8200] MS: butēt, very light, almost whited out (T-L boter, col 1092)
8203] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): mostrent (et) signe
8204] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): S'il veu[t]; see above (vv. 8152-8155) for the introduction of this need to communicate by writing.

8205.1] enclostre: clearly written together in the MS. This is a Franco-Italianism, by someone very conscious of language structures, 'inchiostro' [ink]. It derives from énkāuston; as DELI points out, the -l- was inserted. However, one must also note that in the case of Latin -CL- (/kl/), as of other consonants plus L, -L- is normally palatalized in Italian (Rohlfs ¶¶¶ 247-248; 250; 270), the spelling -clo- may represent a false etymology on the part of a scribe.
8205.2] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): si savra [toz] lor

8208] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): [a]fere; en dit>: this could be written as one word; cf. GdA, indiray, indirent, indiroie (RIALFRI, consulted 1 Dec. 2021), and modern "indire" in Italian (first attested sixteenth century, according to DELI); here there are 46 appearances of "en dit" of which 22 are "l'en di*". Baudoin de Sebourc is the first attestation in OF (dated to ca. 1350); however these seem to be primarily official uses, and for this reason we leave in two parts though the MS writes them together here. AN "endire" (AND2 Online Edition)https://anglo-norman.net/entry/endire) shows uses already in the thirteenth century, thus we wish to signal the usage here for future etymologists and lexicographers.
8209] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): d[ist] ja
8210] This sounds like a written confession, which is sealed by secret.
8211] Cf. T 7891: che amaistrò l'omo y[n] ben fare devotamente [that teaches men to do well devotedly]

8212] MS: sorjugeç. This seems to be a scribal error for "forjugeç", 'condemned'; cf. line 10994. T 7892: Homo che l'avese sopra luy no pò es[er]re zudegato [A man who had it upon him could not be judged]. Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): sorjugeç
8215] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 35): sïe sevreç
8221] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 36): [Mist la en sa mosnere]. For mosnere, see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 377)

8284] "Beati imaculati" are first words in Psalm 118 of the Vulgate, 119 the modern Bible. The lines from it continue throughout this poem; see Morgan, "Dirige gressus meos." The Psalm is also unique in its structure and length, construed as a meditation on the law of God, probably a prayer for dor deliverance from trouble (for commentary and summary, see NOAB, pp. 749-54).

8286] Scribal error? Line was written twice by scribe, once as last line of a column, again as the first line of a column. We omit the repetition. The first version, on 57Vb, reads "puis quil oit troveç par lui nët oblie"; the second, 58Ra, "puis quil oit toueç par luy nert oblie"; Stengel places the first line in parenthesis, as usual to indicate portions to be omitted; for the line printed out to keep, he edits: Puis qui [il] l'oit... oblïé (the dieresis is not necessary since line is 5+5).

8289.1] MS: conte. One wonders if this should be "[en]contré" for "to meet" since a list of what they encountered follows. This line is problematic in the tradition; see the difference in Turin, T 7969: En molte afare ne fo et y[n] molte [con]trade [He was in many situations and in many regions].
8289.2] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): fu [il] puis
8291] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): (e)scampé
8295] T 7975: Lo menor corso ch'el fese fo .XV. lige grande [the shortest journey that he made was fifteen leagues long]
8296] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): De riens qu[e]
8299] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): Un[e] val[é]; not necessary, the line is 4+6.
8301] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): maint [grant] esclap
8304] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): mostrent (tot)
8306] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): [Et] pués

8307] adesés: there seem to be three possible verbs here; one, the OF "adeser," 'touching, reaching'; second, a number of F-I texts (GdA; EE; Roland V4, GF use "adeser", 'to hurry, rush' (cf. Holtus, Lexikalische, 178-79); and finally, Foucon V19, line 6434, "Ch'el venist in França por son cor adasier" (RIALFrI), 'to relax'; this last, especially since it also appears in 8403 where the meaning is quite clear (he had gone for a long time without ....), is thus our understanding (ad+aasier, T-L col 27, ll. 17 ff).
8311] MS: une jor; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): civauça (li ber)
8313] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): Qu(e) un(e) jor. We presume that riva counts as one syllable, with the final vowel as a French epic caesura ("rive").
8314] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): fluns (Tigris); not necessary. The line is 6+6.
8315] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): Un (petit) repaire
8316] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 38): Iluech (li ber); again a 6+6 line without emendation.

8320] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 39): leisir dormi(r); the edit is not necessary, the infinitive is a parallel construction with the previous line, vait jesir... [vait] dormir. For the encounter with the black birds, again see Saint Brendan and for the souls in the form of birds, Saint Macario the Roman (Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia", p. 26); Scattolini, "'Chorisantes itaque puniuntur'," p. 335). For specific passages in English, see Gardiner, "Saint Brendan's Voyage," Visions Before Dante, pp. 92-96. For Saint Macario in Latin only, the Patrologia Latina, Vol. 73, cols. 0415B-0426D, at Chapter 11. Several of the following points are quite similar to those in the Life of St. Macario the Roman (Meregazzi, pp. 27-28). While vol. 73 would date to sources from approximately the seventh century, the whole includes sources through the thirteenth, so the Life of St. Macario definitely precedes our text chronologically.
8322] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 39): vit [il]; again, not necessary, the line is 5+5 syllables.

8329] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 39): Diex cum (ert); the words are from Psalm 132; cf. vv. 4203-4204. It appears also in Saint Brendan's Voyage (Gardiner, Visions Before Dante, p. 111). Meregazzi furthermore notes the appearance of a restful pause there (Gardiner, Visions Before Dante, pp. 117-19) and in other religious texts (Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 26).
8333] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 39): qui face
8339] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 39): Tu as [a] diex
8344] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 39: adonqne (typographical error?)
8348] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 39): vi[n]t le pont de [nostre] departie
8351] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 39): aurent [tre]tuit. This line is missing from T, a sign that there was some difficulty with it.
8355] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): Quant [plus] non porent (il plus), aval
8356] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): Autre (remis)
8358] See Saint Paul's Apocalypse for sinners with a day off (English translation, Gardiner, ed., Visions Before Dante, pp. 45-46).

8361] MS: Te tenir; cf. T 8040: de teneresempre; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): De tenir; clearly a saut du même au meme (homeoteleuton). For the concept of not choosing sides, cf. Dante, Inf. 3.22-69, particularly vv. 38-39, about the "angeli che non furon ribelli/né fur fedeli a Dio, ma per sé fuoro" [angels who were not rebels yet were not faithful to God, but were for themselves; trans. Durling and Martinez, Inf., p. 57].
8362] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): [Et] por ce

8364] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): Da l'or; however, this form does not appear elsewhere. https://deaf-server.adw.uni-heidelberg.de/lemme/lors?expand=true#lors, defines "d'alors" as“à partir de ce moment-là,” similar to "henceforth". RIALFrI lists 68 "da lor" forms, of which the majority are 'from them/their' (lor as pronoun or possessive adjective); a few might be either "from then" or "from them". There are two examples of "d'alora." Of the 13 appearances in this MS, only one is unequivocally "d'alor," line 11177. Etymologically the expression derives from 'from that hour/time', but since it is not traditionally represented thus, we choose to represent it as most frequent in OF editions. Another possibility would be to use Dâ lora where the circumflex would represent the assimilated initial vowel, but we are attempting to avoid extra diacritics.
8367] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): se elle
8368] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): [Et] en air

8370] This line is missing from T. The first hemistich is problematic; it is grammatical, but knowing how to fish and not getting anything though they know how is a little strange. Perhaps it was something with "avoir à" originally; "A pescher s'avomes," "We must fish" [...]. "se" as pronoun for the first person plural is well-documented (see Wunderli, "Se omnipersonnel dans L'Aquilon de Bavière"). Rohlfs (¶702) gives examples of "avere" with an infinitive without a preposition, but it is unclear to him and also from the examples whether an "a" is assimilated into either the conjugated verb or the dependent infinitive. He notes that in northern Italy various verbs are used with infinitive meaning "dovere," but gives no examples with "avere." Since the hemistich does make sense as it stands we have not separated a pronoun from the verb, but suggest this alternative meaning. The situation is a Tantalus-type torture for the fallen angels.
8383] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): E e... regracïés

8385] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): Si vos (riens) de ma queste (car) rien (vos) en savés [if you know anything about my quest]. "Ensavir" can mean 'to instruct, teach' (T-L ensagir, col. 506), and the MS reads ensaves written together; a change of conjugation in rhyme position is not unique. This continues the question in the previous hemistich, "do you know anything about my quest?" so perhaps there are two possible meanings: either "Why do you know nothing?" or "Why do you explain nothing?". We here opt for the second. The line is 6'+6 syllables; Stengel presumes various sauts, perhaps based upon T's version.
8386] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 40): J[e] en...oïr porés
8388] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 41): Sanç (la) devine ... (mès)
8394] The word order here is turned around: en la fin, chascun ert loé de soe ovre; cf. "löé" (T-L col. 567, 'famous')
8395] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 41): c'ha ovrés
8391] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 41): avant que (c)il
8400] venie: cf. lines 8125, 8167. This is almost the exact same structure and suggests a similar meaning for that line. Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 41): Soe veine
8403] See note at line 8307.
8405] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 41): si [de] deu [il] non; without emendation, the line is 8 syllables.
8407] See v. 2412, aveit: from the verb "avoiier," to set off.
8409] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 41): par[oi]t

8412.1] MS: don (with an apostrophe above the "n"). This is a single example in the entire MS of "n" with the apostrophe-like abbreviation, so its meaning is not clear; here "donque" seems to be the best interpretation for meaning (it is missing in T). Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 41): don' (!). Following the equivalent of this line is T 8088 P[er] lo pasazo che ly sono da qua alora avè la Crose piata [Through the passages that were there from that point forward, he had taken up the cross]; presumably the cross's light and marvellous nature helps keep the darkness at bay— missing here in B.
8412.2] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 41): don' (!). Elsewhere in the MS, the apostrophe over a letter indicates missing letters (a missing syllable); see the introduction.
8413] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 41): [tres]tote

8415] palastre does not appear in T-L as a noun in any sense that would seem to work here; there is an adjective meaning 'pusillanime', or a reference to "palestre," 'exercise field'; "palestrage," on the other hand, is 'lock casing'. DELI offers "pala," which among other definitions is a device to take things out of the oven (perhaps like a modern pizza peel?); -astro is the suffix for "big and bad." Turin's "pilastro" (v. 8092) on the other hand is a column, like modern 'pilaster', a generally square-shaped column (DELI, 13th century). Here, it is engraved, according to the following lines, so a writing surface is needed. Neither B's form nor T's appear in RIALFrI as of this date (December 2021), and it is a hapax in this text. Since there is no mention of needing to open it or fight, we translate as "pillar."

8416] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 41): [Le]tre i oit entaillé; he has clearly taken this from the T version, which reads just so, T 8093: Letre lì g'era y[n]talliate dal tempo de Moise [There were letters there, carved from the time of Moses]. Alternatively, one wonders whether L'Autre would be more appropriately resolved with some emendation to "L'Autor," meaning God.
8426] sor soy la oit prendue: cf. Ital "prendersela," 'to get offended, get upset'
8427] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 42): [Maintenant] dou cheval
8428] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 42): s'est(oit)
8430] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 42): pechieç [av]oit
8433] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 42): q[e] il; not necessary: the line is 5+5 syllables, with the final -e of estre elided to the following vowel.

8439] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 42): pas un[e] cenue; this expression does not appear in OF dictionaries, and in F-I lists appears as "canu/chenu," old man (white-haired), usually an adjective or nominalized adjective. That does not make sense here or in v. 10862 (raim d'une cenue). In both cases they are expressions of little value, and as PEB points out, "cenele" (T-L col. 109; Matsumura p. 518), 'fruit of the hawthorne' (f), or "cenelier" (m), 'hawthorne tree' appears in such constructions, so both lines are possibly a vocalized variant of that construction. We presume 4'+4 syllables.
8441] De profundis clamavi: One of the penitential psalms, 130 (129 in the Septuagint version): "Out of the depths I cry to thee, O Lord!"
8442] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 42): "Ad te (d'ne) domine"qui(l); Ad te Domine, Domine: appears once, in Psalm 140/141.8; Ad te Domine appears numerous times; 10 in the Psalms alone.

8443] Orationem meam appears 17 times in the Psalms, plus once in Lamentations; it frequently appears with "exaudi" for "grant my prayer." In Ps. 68.14 is the only case that includes both this and "Ad te Domine" (not repeated), though both appear in different lines in Ps. 85, 87, and 141. Psalm 68 of the Vulgate (69 in modern Bibles) is designated a prayer for deliverance from personal enemies, a lament.
8446] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 42): non l'a[vo]it
8452] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 42): Celle [la voie li mostre]
8454] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 42): proëce argue

8455] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 42): que de[s] tenebre; if the final mute -e of the first hemistich is counted, then the line has an even number of syllables. Since tenebre is plural in Italian, the article le would make sense to Italian speakers.

8466] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 43): cuy [il] l'avoyt

8481] preste: while in French forms this can mean "quickly, readily," in Italian it could mean "early" (DELI, already 14th century).
8483] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 43): loant [la] gloire [deu] celeste; biendir: see note, v. 1019.

8506] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 44): [A] deu
8508] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 44): Que [vestre] non par, following T 8189: che el vostro nome per my...

8509] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 44): quier la ver(i)té; usually Stengel has emendations of items to remove in parentheses; the "i" is not present (cf. vertie, vertee, verteç, elsewhere in the MS, though there are also forms with the medial -i-). The line is ten syllables (4+6) without it, so this seems to be Stengel's error.

8564] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 46): oit [il] herré

8618] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 47): amb[e]dos. The following line is mislabelled in Stengel, "66b" for "60b."

8621] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 47): oisel(lon) que
8624.1] See T 8305: per mé la rivera; clearly the writer here understood "l'areine" like MSI "la rena," 'the sand."

8624.2] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 47): Pormi la reine a or mainel(e); It is not clear whether "aor" (now) or "a or" (of gold) is intended; since "aor" does not appear anywhere else, we accept "a or."
8627] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 47): petit de rais
8628] For the form laine, see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 358).
8653] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 48): las, [que] non
8636] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 48): Sparagner [la] le veut
8637.1] MS seems to be missing the definite article, which is necessary for sense as well as syllable count.

8637.2] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 48): Vait s'en quuens [Hue], proposing instead that the name is missing; perhaps the scribe thinks of "quuens" as a nickname. T is of no help, since it has both in one line: 8318 Va lo [con]te Ugo[n], che no[n] se vole arestare [The count Huon , who did not want to stop, goes]. Here only one syllable more is necessary for the meter.

8642] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 48): [Il] morbirent [...] l'eve fer... This is a problematic line. There is no recorded form of "morbir"* in OF, OI or F-I, and its analogues mean "soft" in Italian (cf. T 8323 Fresche e morbede sono como foseno y[n] l'aqua fere [Fresh and soft they are, as if they were in the fierce (?) water]), so somewhere along the line a term was interpreted as "soft". PEB suggests l'eve fer, 'wild water'; in this MS, leue appears three times as the measure of distance, 'league' (alternatively, lieu (4 times) and plurals of both), and leu (m) as 'place' 51 times (with lou, 28 times), so we accept 'water'; however, perhaps "Morbirent," in an extension of meaning, could be 'they calmed down, eased up', once they were in the water, since it was too hard to continue fighting. Yet they have just been chasing each other, so are they attacking each other? Making each other sick? Biting each other? All have been suggested. See the translation for the two possible interpretations in context. We thank colleagues Logan Whalen and Roberto Pesce in addition to PEB for consulting on this passage.

8646] s'alonge here clearly for "s'aloigne" (s'alonger would usually be to "prolong"). This usage also appears in AdB (76.8; RIALFrI, http://www.rialfri.eu/rialfriPHP/public/testo/testo/ordinata/ot|rialfri|aquilon|006|35286/query/l#mark, consulted 09 Jan 2021), and EE (v. 14107; also RIALFrI).
8651] el = et + il
8655] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 48): Al cef davant po[u], clearly modelled on T 8336: e quỳ l'è davante un pocho dapreso la costa [and here ahead of him, somewhat nearby the coast, is]

8656.1] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 48): Un[e] grant; gold-digging ants are a part of European tradition, found in Herodotus's Histories, 3.102-105, where he describes them in India. https://www.livius.org/sources/content/herodotus/the-gold-digging-ants/. They appear subsequently in various authors, some versions of the Physiologus , and bestiaries, that attribute them instead to Ethiopa (Badke, Medieval Bestiary, http://bestiary.ca/beasts/beast218.htm); these became "ant-lions."
8656.2] MS: Un gnt (with two dots over "n") masse.
8657] MS: du cengler; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 48): d'u[n] cengler

8658] This line could be interpreted in two ways, depending upon punctuation for the modern reader. Either it modifies the previous line, speaking of the cengler that resides in the mountains — in which case, "cavent" derives from OF chavoir— or, if line 8656 ends in a comma, and 8657 is set off with dashes, the mass of ants, as in line 8659, dig in the wildest part of the mountain, and cavent is an alternative spelling to chavent of 8659. There is really no way to distinguish between which was intended. This line is missing in Turin.
8666] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 48): [a]chaminer; not necessary for meter if the abbreviated number is two syllables, like the Italian.

8670] Scattolini edits from this line through 10382 in her dissertation. She has generously allowed us to compare readings, sharing her transcription with us. Where we differ in reading, it will be noted. She does not use capitals at the beginning of each line, or diereses, and the punctuation differs; these we do not note. In addition her word divisions can differ. She also resolves all abbreviations for "p" with per, where we vary according to context. The copy that we have is electronic, and therefore we do not give page numbers; the line numbers should suffice, though she uses Stengel's line numbers for the Berlin version. S'ovre might be possible here: "a great worry opened itself/began"; however, we find T 8351: sopra un gran pensero [over a great worry], so we follow that understanding.
8674] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 49): Quil(e) pais
8675] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 49): le vit, [va] adès (va)
8677] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 49): Mès (ja)
8678] tanser: cf. GdA, p. 461, "tansaire... defendere, proteggere."
8679] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 49): serp(ant)
8683] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 49): [vive] force. But cf. line 7360 above.
8685] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 49): puisqu[e] il
8689] Scattolini: ne ̓l; wherever I use the raised dot, she uses the apostrophe; it will not be commented again. Atuer: cf. Gambino, "Code-mixing nel Bovo d'Antona udinese," p. 71.

8690] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 49): ala aficher; another example of the double possibilities of verbal constructions (French aler + infinitive; Italian andare a + infinitive). Seven forms are clearly with the prefix (frequently s'+ verb); four are clearly without (past participles). There are no other constructions like this here, after another infinitive, so there is nothing to compare it to directly.
8694] mari: from "mairier, merier," "dominer, apprivoiser" (TL mairier, cols. 850-851)
8700] Scattolini: nen seroit
8702] Scattolini: e obliay ... e' fi [...]
8709] Scattolini: neanch (cf. Italian "neanche")
8710] Scattolini: pués
8711] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 50), Scattolini: voil [conv]ant; but cf. T-L (col. 27, col. 31: cant que), 'however much'
8713] Scattolini: age nul
8714] MS: magiay; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 50): (qi) ni ma[n]giay. This line is not present in T.
8724] Scattolini: clamese'n colpe
8726] Scattolini resolves cu[n] consistently.
8727] bendir: see note, line 1019.
8729] Scattolini: dastus, as always combining following pronouns. This will not be commented again. Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 50): Ay sire diex
8736] pieté here seems to convey something like Aeneas's epithet, "pius Aeneas," that is, one who respects religion, country and home, and heads a divine mission.
8744] il furent nascus: it is unclear here to what the subject il refers; the sins were forgiven up until whose birth?
8745] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 51): sir(e) Naçarenus

8748] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 51): esmate; Matsumura gives "esmater" as a specifically F-I verb (it does not appear in T-L), appearing in the EE, CdR V4, and V7, Hector et Hercule, and the GdA, meaning 'abbatre' [to beat down].
8749-51] See notes in the translation for sources.

8752] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 51): Voy (en)ci ; Scattolini: "Voy enci toe mere, si l'avoi esleus"; the subject of the second hemistich is not clear. With the -s ending, it seems a second person singular– two of the other three forms are definitively so (the third is in rhyme).
8754] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 51): merci (de moy) douç e ben[eoiç] fius

8756] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 51): Estrange part; but see T 8433: En stranie parte d'andare yo sonto recresuto [I am tired of wandering in foreign parts]; see also the eight other appearance of "strange" (including "stranges," "strangne," "strançe") of which only two could possibly have the initial e-.
8758] Scattolini: le scripture; she divides generally with the s- plus consonant ("s impura") as a start of the word, as in Italian. This will not be remarked again.
8759] Scattolini: ferai (MS: ʃerai)
8760] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 51): me clain
8761] End of Stengel's "Huons Suche" transcription.

8762] Transcribed by Tobler, lines 8762-9038 (pp. 609-14). Since there is only one Tobler article, we do not give any precisions other than the line number. Casini comments on these lines, 8762-8771 (p. 82), shortly after Tobler's discovery of the Berlin MS, suggesting it as the French original of the text, a contention that of course is disproven later through more complete transcription and analysis.
8765] Scattolini: e[r]t cheue
8769] obscure veüe: this is an odd construction for Italian; "scuro" means 'dark' in a rather literal way. Thus we have presumed it must reflect the wider semantic field of OF 'sinister'.
8772] The hand under the chin is a traditional pose for one pondering that has come through to modern times; cf. Rodin.

8777] Scattolini: et Hue; the line is somewhat problematic. This is the only appearance of "hue" as a verb, elsewhere it is a form of "Huon." But there is "il dit" and the line is 10 syllables so we do not emend. The section is in different order and missing this element in T 8452 Segna el suo visso e possa dize Ugone [Huon made the sign of the cross on his face and then said]. It may be that, in spite of the abbreviation, the end of the line should be read "e thue," meaning something like 'and was quiet'. Cf line 8446, with theue in rhyme position, and the EE, v. 6062, "theü," also in rhyme.
8791] Scattolini: el dit, "N'avoir [...]"

8793] Cf. Roques, CR Wunderli, bexogner, impers., 'être nécessaire' , p. 539. Elsewhere in this text (and in various spellings) it is a noun (9748, 11635; 4079; 8814; 8807; 862; 3059; most frequent is besoingn, 11 appearances), and it appears also in adjectival forms (bisognable, v. 2289; besognos, v. 9739).
8798] sogne ("soigne" T-L cols 763-764)

8803] se resoigne: for "se renseignier": a missing abbreviation line is a frequent paleographical error. This line is worded differently in T, as is whole section vv. 8476-78. T 8477: e dire poray el to volere a quelo chi besogna [and you can tell your will to the one for whom it is necessary].

8805] Mainone suggests OF bargaigne as the source of "bergogne" (Laut, p. 31). The construction of the phrase— with "justisse" as object—makes one wonder if "vergogne" might not have been the intended word, since it takes a direct object. Rohlfs (¶167), offers examples of initial b- for Latin v- for central Italy, and also for the Veneto. Of course vergogne appears just above in v. 8796. There is no equivalent in the other MSS; T 8478 da parte del re che yustizia li besogna [on the part of the king to whom justice is necessary]. So the redactor of B may have confused two expressions.
8808] Scattolini: Di va
8809.1] Scattolini: e le malvais
8809.2] el malvais = "et + il" malvais
8810] muer: Mainone lists this as "muert" with the final -t fallen (Laut, p. 50); but third person is not possible here, this must be first person with the final -s dropped.
8811] Scattolini: que ti rien
8818] Presumably the devil is referring here to the siege of Auvergne by Charles Martel in order to take Ynide.
8821] Scattolini: seroi ge
8822] Scattolini: Fuyci
8823] Scattolini: creroi ge
8828] Tobler: laut [o]steil
8829] The rhyme here calls for a diphthongue, but the standard form is traïs to mark the hiatus. Cf. the situation with "oÿ" in vv. 1643 etc. Cf. below, line 8831.
8830] Cf. T 8502: zò fo senifichanza che nula no[n] l'amasty [that means that you don't love him at all]
8835] Scattolini: fesis mançer

8840.1] Or possibly, en ci berais, "drink it here / thus"; however, we here follow T's word division; cf. line 11168 "cibe." There are only the forms with bev- for 'to drink' in this MS (4 forms), and see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 290) for enci.
8840.2] Scattolini: enci berais (she gives "tu t'acibe" for T 8512)

8843] MS: remaine. Cf. T 8514: coventa che yo te mene a le gra[n] tenenbre. We emend basing on the Turin line for a frequent paleographical error of "r" for "t." Mainone derives "mais" from MAGIS (Laut, p. 44); however, there is also a form for "mauvais" that can be nominalized, and we construe it thus here (T-L col. 875, ll. 32ff).
8846] Scattolini: Chain
8851] Scattolini: de ci ore
8857] Scattolini: a don
8859] Scattolini ends the direct address with this line.
8862] For enbron, see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 288).
8875] T reads "six feet" (de sy piede me parea longo, line 8546).
8879] Scattolini: t'encontron; T 8550: te contoe

8880] This section of conversation is problematic to understand. This line and the preceding are significantly different in the Turin MS. The scribe would seem to have misunderstood or omitted something from his original here.
8881] Scattolini: "Non creira s'a toy non [...]"
8885] Scattolini: qu'e[st] (sic)
8890] Scattolini: za usir poras
8896] Scattolini: Si i ert; This line is missing from Turin, and, as is frequently the case for those lines, translation is difficult.
8900] Scattolini: l'aut del tron

8901] The connection of this line with the foregoing laisse is not clear. Cf. T 8571: e medessmo Aristotele lo vederay e soa [com]pagnia [and you'll see even Aristotle and his company], where a verb is added. See note to translation also.
8906] Scattolini: m'es mostree; cf. Inf. 1, v. 66 (Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 30)
8913] Scattolini: de jant; note that this seems to differ from Dante. Here Aeneas says specifically that he is part of the damned, not outside of hell itself.
8918] Scattolini: çorné (emendation not necessary; the sounding of a horn is part of the Day of Judgement).
8928] MS: ausi. Cf. T e che cossỳ morite al tempo dey anzoly falsy [and who thus died at the time of the false angels].
8929] Scattolini: [de]strucion; but this adds a syllable to a 5+5 line.
8936] Dante (Inf. 9.22-30) recounts Virgil's trip to hell at the bidding of Erichtho, perhaps based on Aeneid 6.562-65.
8938] Scattolini: ll'inferno
8944] Cf. Inf. 1, vv. 79-80 (Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 30).
8955] Scattolini: sastu, combining verb with following subject as always. Not further remarked.
8959] Scattolini: auroient
8974] âlgun = "a algun."

8975] afaitement: see Bezzola, Storia dei gallicismi (253). ; while OF afaitement has the standard definition of 'arrangement, appearance, or construction' (cf. Matsumura, T-L), or 'a collection of graceful qualities' (DEAF-él), Italian also has the sense of 'enchanted thing'; cf. DELI for affatturare, 'to put under a spell; to alter, falsify'/counterfit" already in the fourteenth century (before Dante). This seems to be the sense here, 'magical creation/origin.' See also lines 10819, 10944.
8982] Scattolini: de ci, as always. Not remarked further.
8984] Scattolini: exilment
8992] Scattolini: l'en
9003] Scattolini: qui te voy
9008] Scattolini: en doit destrie
9009] Scattolini: a une fontaine
9015] See Scattolini on this portion of the text and its renditions in different versions (Ricerche sulla tradizione, p. 186).

9016] floch: this is listed as "floc" or "floche" in T-L, and defined as "tuft" of wool or hair; it is similarly listed in other dictionaries (Matsumura: floc, flocel/floquel). It would seem to have continued into English from AN as 'flocking', adding particles to a surface for texture (as to wall-paper). Turin did not understand and and changed the line: T 8687 le vistymente sono d'altro colore [they(?) are visibly of another color].
9020] perduç: no abbreviation line is visible in the MS; Tobler: pdu'x; Scattolini: perduç. T 8691: chi è p[er]duto yn le stranie [con]trade [who is lost in the foreign land]

9025] Tobler: ɾaincte Marie. Forms of "Marie" with the saint prefix appear 19 times; of those, 6 are abbreviated. Of the remaining 13, 11 are "sancte" with only 2 "saincte," so we here follow the most frequent, though overall "sainct/e" forms are more frequent (93 to 52, including adjectives, superlatives, verb). In line 9032 below, two unabbreviated forms "saincte vie" appear, so we resolve to follow those.
9026] a conduir: separated future, 'will lead', typical of the northern Italian peninsula (see Rohlfs, vol. 2, Morfologia, ¶ 590).
9027] Scattolini: n'aura; T 8698: davante coluy che zamay no[n] averà paxe [before him who will never have peace]
9031] Scattolini suggests in lines 9030-9031, present only here and in T, the memory of Purg. 2. 77-81; it then reappears, in her lines 351-352 (here lines 9131-9134).
9034] ausi tot com: ausi can be "ainsi," thus the translation here.
9035] Scattolini: cue char
9038] End of Tobler's transcription selection.

9039] Beginning of Stengel's transcription of "Huons aus Auvergne Höllenfahrt" (abbreviated "Höllenfahrt"). As elsewhere, only differences will be noted: [ ] indicate his emendations, ( ) his suppression of a MS reading. He edited through laisse 385, line 10079. He uses no capitals for nomina sacra. We do not follow his punctuation, and do not note our differences from it; nor do we note differing resolutions of abbreviations unless there is a bearing on the meaning. For equivalencies, see chart of line numbers.

9045] examplir: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 305-06), 'accomplir, observer (la loi, etc.)' ['to fulfill, perform, observe (the law, etc.)]. exempliier, T-L col. 1534, lines 26-27, essempler T-L col. 1300. The term can also mean 'to exalt', especially in this expression; cf. Matsumura, 'essamplir'.

9048] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 6): [Et] quant [ge fuy] vieuç.... dekoy (or: desroy), as corrected in his note p. 80; Scattolini: e fuy; ; she comments on Stengel's emendation, noting that his additions are not necessary, that it is enough to delete the e. In fact, no emendation is necessary; the line makes sense and consists of 5+5 syllables. For comment and insertion of this in French tradition, see P. E. Bennett, "Guillaume d'Orange: Fighter of Demons and Harrower of Hell," pp. 24-46.
9049] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 6): (Que) rien (as he notes on p. 80, for a 12-syllable line with a "lyric" first hemistich, 51+6)
9051] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 7): Vne ovre fesoie (b[etter]: F. u. o.); note , p. 80, b[etter] Une ovre fesoie a honor (de)

9052] This line is missing from T. The word "herroy" is not found elsewhere. We interpret it as a form related to the Lat. verb ERRARE. Other possibilities might be enroi/erroi, 'undertaking'; or erroi, 'uncertainty; concern; distrust'

9056] quaroy: Scattolini defines as "charoi" [carro; 'cart']. However, the Châteauroux manuscript of the Chanson de Roland reads "quarraus" in line 5899 (Duggan; cf. Moffat v. 5898, "qarraus"), and V7"quarraus" v. 6018 (Duggan). In Duggan and Rejhon, Song of Roland, it is translated 'stone', as is appropriate for quarried material. Throwing carts one on top of the other would make less sense for building a secure bridge raised from one side to the other. Cf. Matsumura, quierre, querre, carr, 'bloc de pierre taillée', also found in the EE, v. 3569, and several other texts (RIALFrI, consulted 23 March 2021).
9051] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 7): Vne ovre fesoie (b[etter]: F. u. o.); note , p. 80, b[etter], Une ovre fesoie a honor (de)
9052] This line is missing from T. The word "herroy" is not found elsewhere. Other possibilities might be enroi/erroi, 'undertaking'; or erroi, 'uncertainty; concern; distrust' (T-L, sub voce)

9056] quaroy: Scattolini defines as "charoi" [carro; 'cart']. However, the Châteauroux manuscript reads "quarraus" in line 5899 (Duggan; cf. Moffat 5898, "qarraus"), and V7"quarraus" v. 6018 (Duggan). In Duggan and Rejhon, it is translated 'stone', as is appropriate for quarried material. Throwing carts one on top of the other would make less sense for building a secure bridge raised from one side to the other. Cf. Matsumura, quierre, querre, carr, 'bloc de pierre taillée', also found in the EE, v. 3569, and several other texts (RIALFrI, consulted 23 March 2021).

9058] MS: adesloy; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 7): Tant cum ovroie...; Scattolini: ovroie l'andeman a defloy. Cf. desliier, desloiier, "disperser" (Matsumura; T-L col. 1633 ll. 38ff., "losbinden", 'to undo').

9071] Scattolini: s'il conjuray, "and he begged" vs. "and he begged him" St. Eloy, or Eligius, was a great goldsmith and patron saint of artisans in metal, including goldsmiths. He was famous for having shod a horse possessed by the devil by removing the leg and restoring it once shod.
9074] el = et + il
9075] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 8): (E)Stara; Estara cil dïable (p. 80, correction, since dïable always three syllables in this poem); Scattolini: estara
9093] n'ais for Modern French "en a"
9097] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 9): sosten(i)s; changes his mind in note, p. 80, sostenis for a 12-syllable line
9099] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 9): N'auis

9109] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 9): Un avoer auis; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 9), Stengel, Scattolini: desor; this follows Turin 8779, "de sopra," 'up above'; but "des or," 'from now on,' also is possible.

9117] This line is not present in T, but it is in Br and B; two syllables are missing from that version here; there, it reads, "tot son plasire li fist le large doneor," 'all his pleasure the generous Giver [i.e., God] gave him'.
9136] deveeç presant: from desvoiier (T-L col. 1820-1821); T 8804: diverso presente [different presence]; does this mean not human?

9137] MS: si prāt ('p' with a slash on the downstroke) very light at end of line; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt, p. 11"): .....[a series of dots]. there is no meaning in OF for "se prendre" that seems to work here. It is erased so what was originally intended is unclear; we interpret it as a for of "parprendre": 's'emparer de' (Matsumura); or an intensive, 'par'+ 'prendre'; Matsumura offers "arrêter" which would make sense also (under 'prendre', ll. 8-9 p. 2689 col 2), but again for a non-reflexive. This second does not appear in T-L. T 8805: per l'altruy ridre el se vergognâ spramente [because of the laughter of the others he was extremely ashamed]
9138] n'i: [he seizes] nothing there. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 11), Scattolini: ni
9140] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," pp. 80-81): b[etter], espir(i)t; cf. 9351, 9461, etc.

9142] Scattolini: verra; the abbreviation is a single line in slightly checkmark form, where abbreviations for "r" are normally two dots (though sometimes run together): see "torneront" just below with the two in contrast. Furthermore, there are three appearances of venra and three (including this) vēra, plus five others with "nr" in the stem, and none with "rr"; thus we expand "nr."
9148] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 11): (de)l' omnipotant; the line as it stands is one syllable too long (4+7). Stengel, in his appendix, notes "cf. 10536" (p. 81).

9153] Vidossi (Le Origini, pp. 1202-19) includes laisses 350-361 (not completely; sections are omitted). Vidossi (p. 1202-03 n1) says that he and Arese have transcribed and translated from a photograph of the Berlin MS; they mention Stengel's "Huon' saus Auvergne Hollenfahrt" [sic].

9160] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 12): (grant); as the line stands, it is one syllable too long; if enchaëneç were three syllables instead of four, that would eliminate the problem, but since T reads "inchadenà" and P "incadenado" the origin of the word and the number of syllables were clear.
9167] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt,," p. 81): b[etter], por (ce) que, to bring the line to 5+5; Scattolini: voeç
9170] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 81): elision of l'a asis; Scattolini: Willelme...luy la asis
9174] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 12): estormaut, corrected in appendix to estormant (p. 81)

9178] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," 13): Descend[i]rent; the line is only eight syllables, 3+5, and his addition would make a nine-syllable line. In his notes he edits, b[etter]: [Soëf] descendrent, for 41+5 (p. 81).
9179] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 13): en [un] parfont; Scattolini: da mont a val profont
9180] T has an additional line following this: 8849 si foseno l'uno sopra l'altro tuty metute [if they were placed one on top of the other].
9184] Scattolini: ni mist; n·i = ne les

9185] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 13), Scattolini: a lume; the structure is not clear here. If "the Creator" of the line before is still the subject, of course He would have light according to his pleasure. However, it is Huon who needs the light, together with his spirit guides, so the Creator's lighting the way for Huon's pleasure seems more likely (alume).
9189] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 13): D(a l')un ... parfis; as it stands, the line is twelve syllables (6+6); with Stengel's emendation, 11 (5+6 syllables).
9190] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 13): verm(in)e; not necessary, 6+6 syllables. Perhaps he is modelling on T 8859: piena de vermy e de grandy dragone [full of vermin and huge dragons].

9191] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 13); Scattolini: le avis. Other forms of "avis" in this MS are generally with 'to be' plus the indirect object (lines 135, 440, 7510, 9425, 9455, 10098), or are nouns with the preposition 'a' and/or a possessive adjective (lines 284, 1717, 2762) or a form of 'to have' (3419, 9099, 9109). This point was problematic for the tradition: T 8860: che zetano fogo per bocha e per visso [that throw fire from their mouths and from their faces]; PEB suggests that this B reading may be the error, for "e(t) l(e) vis," "and their faces," similar to the T reading.

9192] This lines is problematic; it is ten syllables as it stands, but the subject of the verb is unclear, and "stranglotir" has two possible meanings; in either case something missing: the subject or the object. One possible emendation, if there were a saut du même au même, would be missing le/li a before stranglotis: "strangled them" or "extinguished it.">.
9193] Scattolini: sianç
9195] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 13): Et
9202] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 14): Mout [fu] felons

9207.1] MS: dovien. This is the only appearance of that form. Note, however, that doiven appears three times (7925, 10369, 11855) while devien appears three times as well (6964, 8091, 11660), so the position of the diphthong varies.
9207.2] Scattolini: doiven marois
9207.3] marois: here definitely the OF standard definition, 'swamp'.
9209] T 8878: semenare, "to sow"; one wonders if that was also the intention here, "a devil sowed [planted]."

9211] Scattolini: Guillelme, as always for the name; not further noted. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 14), Scattolini: d'aseger; cf. Morgan, ed., GF, v. 7128, "Qe nul falçe herbe por seger." "Aseger" is registered as 'besiege' (T-L, assieger, cols 571-572; RIALFrI, "aseger" 12 appearances; cf. MSI "segare," Treccani, Dante, from Lat. SĚCARE, 'to cut', https://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/segare_%28Enciclopedia-Dantesca%29/ consulted 22 March 2021).
9213] marois: see note, line 2702.
9215] al traire d'un archier: cf. 3602, 403, 8866, a formula for giving a distance, length, height, etc.

9216] MS: vit; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 14), Scattolini: aviser. T 8885: de fero avea senbiante che·l venese bene [it seemed of steel to who saw it well]; the lack of an abbreviation line is a frequent scribal error. The construction "venire a" is typical of Italian, whereas "venir" + infinitive is the French construction. Both "viser" and "aviser" are attested in F-I; in this text, viser appears in v. 6955; constructions with "venir(e) a" + infinitive and without the "a" both appear in this text, as do both forms "viser" and "aviser" with no difference in meaning. a visare; the lack of an abbreviation line is a frequent scribal error. The construction "venire a" is typical of Italian, whereas "venir" + infinitive is the French construction. Both "viser" and "aviser" are attested in F-I; in this text, viser appears in v. 6955; constructions with "venir(e) a"+ infinitive and without the "a" both appear in this text, as do both forms "viser" and "aviser" with no difference in meaning.
9219] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 15): [a]près (de)
9223] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 15): men n'oit n'oit trop; in his note, he emends "read: men 'n oit 'n oit trop" (p. 81).

9227] See illumination at the bottom of the page for the four gates; they would seem, however, to be out of order. The one to the right seems to have its gates on the ground, with a figure of a man above; the third from the binding seems to have a lion above. Note the three men to the left; Aeneas, Guillaume d'Orange, and Huon. Huon seems to either have a brown face here, or be wearing a mask. All three are identifiable through their clothes as seen in the earlier three illuminations. The female figure above the first gate holds a sword in her right hand, and a scroll in her left, that reads "ju/sti/cia."
9234] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 15): E qe (da ce) ...

9235] D'aprés: this seems to be a combination of OF aprés and Italian dappresso (DELI, 1310-12, 'vicino, accanto'); "d'aprés" (Hindley, 'after'); "de prés" (Matsumura, 'bientôt'); "d'après" (Matsumura 'derrière'); T-L col. 471, line 35, 'hinter, nach'

9236] This quote (or paraphrase) would seem to be related to classical condemnations of hubris, such as that of Hesiod in his Theogony (where he relates the succession of gods getting what is coming to them in return for assaulting authority), and also in his Works and Days, where he illustrates how hard work merits an appropriate reward, in opposition to the hubris for glorious deeds advocated by the classical epics of Homer. He especially praises Justice, Zeus's favorite daughter. See http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0132%3Acard%3D1 for the translation into English (esp. chapters 255-73 for Justice).
9246] Scattolini: qu'el; here, que·l mistrent for "que le mistrent," with an object, not subject pronoun.

9249] planoy: "planets" (Mainone, Laut, p. 32); there seems to be no other attestation of this form in F-I or in OF. In T, "fede," 'faith' (v. 8919). The reasoning behind the lexeme is not clear, and seems to be a scribal error at some point. There is no evident typical scribal error, such as a missing abbreviation mark, and the line is ten syllables as it stands (4+6). Perhaps the final term is related to "esplaneör," 'interpreter' of the world?

9251] forfere: while this is normally defined as 'doing harm to someone' or 'commit a crime', it would literally mean "to do out", so 'lead astray', appropriate here in speaking of prophets whom the writer deemed false.
9254] regraigne: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 294-95), "rugir," 'to roar, to bellow'.
9255] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 17): Qu'as autre semble, (ce) ...; in his note, he emends: "b[etter]: Qu'(a) as" (p. 81).
9261] Scattolini: ert de menor
9264] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 17): por[oi]ent; not necessary, this is a future, not a conditional, and the line has 6+6 syllables.
9265] This is a reference to the Harrowing of Hell.
9265] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 17): Grant temps resamble qu'en trabuce l'ovragne; (v. 9422); Scattolini (v. 467, p. 267): Grant temps resamble qu'en trabuce l'ovragne

9268] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 17), Scattolini: la versa (but cf. v. 9219, "Fasoit le jonchs tretotes averser" where the verb must have the a- prefix; v. 3216, "terre tant versa" with no prefix; and vv. 1096, 2531, with no prefix). See introduction on the use of prefixes.

9270] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 17): Ce fu (a) cil temps; the line as it reads is 11 syllables. Possibly despoilla could be read as 4, though elsewhere in the text that is not the case. Stengel, in his notes, says that "fu a" is elided, comparing the situation with other lines in the poem ("Höllenfahrt," p. 81).
9273] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 18): 'navant; Scattolini: navant [...] serra (there is no abbreviation)
9278] Scattolini: cil que la enç
9283] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 18): Puis qu'(il) ert...
9284] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 18): qu'el a; Scattolini: que l'a. Since the MS uses el 145 times and il 1568, the resolution here is "il."

9286] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 18): pont (b: poines); Scattolini: ert, de. Scattolini notes that this line and the following three are only present in B and T, and contain a specific reference to purgatory so that they are more similar to visionary literature than other versions. She suggests that the reference to reading something in line 9288 in particular might be reading the Tractatus de Purgatorio Sancti Patricii (Ricerche, 358). For an English version, see Purgatory of St. Patrick, ed. Gardiner, p. 142; for the purgatorial mountain, pp. 144-45 .
9287] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 18): Mès en (la)...
9288.1] The second hemistich here is problematic; the meaning seems clear, but the lexeme division is not. Vidossi notes that there seems to be a damaged spot.

9288.2] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 18): de la dis (!) hom; Scattolini: lejera (since the line is twelve syllables without hiatus here, we do not add a dieresis; in general in this text, reflexes of laisser do not have a hiatus according to the syllable count.).

9289] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 18): davant [dit] je t'ois; Vidossi follows his emendation: "davant [dit] je t'ois" = "ti avevo parlato," 'I had spoken to you'. See translation for another possibility.

9298] MS: anue d'vois; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 19): anue devois.(!); Scattolini: [...] ritirt a nue devois. Anve de for Modern French 'envers de' (cf. v. 5500) and vois for "vous" (cf. vv. 4729, 4875); we presume "retit" is from retraire (T-L col. 1160, line 50ff : (einen Weg) wieder aufnehmen 'to start again') . The use of "enver(s)" plus "de" is an Italianism; cf. GF and other F-I texts. This is a problematic line, absent from T.
9299] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 19): Huon: "[Tres]tot...
9307] avois: this must be the present tense, a deformation for rhyme. Cf. Mainone, Laut, p. 34 and p. 37.
9308] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 19): (e)spirt; the line is 11 syllables as it stands, so would need either another vowel or to have one not pronounced in order to have a standard line.
9310] Cf. Dante Par. 33.64; Graf, p. 107.
9314] en plois: compare line 7494 for the construction with en: s'il vos en plaist .

9320] Cf. Inf. 5.31, "bufera"; Scattolini: Aquilenois. "Aquilon" (T-L col 484, ll. 25ff) is usually defined as 'north, northwind'; it is associated with the afterlife. T-L quotes from Marie de France's Espurgatoire de saint Patriz.
9326] Graf, p. 107; Inf. 4.13. Much of this laisse derives from expressions in Inferno, especially Canto 3.

9331] Note that here Huon is able to touch Guillaume physically, though he was not able to embrace him earlier. This contradiction is not dissimilar to the situation in Dante's Inferno, varying between Virgil touching Dante and Dante not being able to touch Virgil.

9334] As for many numbers in this text, the second part is written above the first, so above .x. is the 'm'. Note that the noise here is compared with sounds of war— weapons, hunting and blacksmithing— before moving to natural comparisons more typical of Dante.
9335] T 9004: che tute a ponto foseno tra tuty y[n]guale [so that all were equal to each other in every way], adding another imperfect subjunctive here; we translate it thus.

9337] Cf. St. Brendan (Gardiner, Visions Before Dante, pp. 115-16). As Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 81) remarks, this seems to be a three-part twelve syllable line (4'+3'+4), and he sees no other such line in the hell segment.
9339] For the sound of water, see Inf. 16.
9343] blasfemer: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 235-36).
9345] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 21): "[Ugo] homo loial; Vidossi skips this line through line 10500 in his translation into Italian.

9346] For cobre, see Möhren, p. 321; it comes from old N. Italian, and is attested in old Bolognese and old Genovese. For the idea, see Inf. 18.2: "pietra di color ferrigno"; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 21): le mer (b[etter]: met)
9347] Cf. Inf. 3. 34-36 (Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 31)
9348] Cf. Inf. 24.124, "vita bestial"
9349] mer = "mirent," from the verb "metre"? Perhaps a crossing with "merir," 'to merit' that should be followed then by "un peril." 'Their conscience brought (rewarded) them such a danger'.
9351] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): ponsent [ne] la nuit nel jornal
9352.1] Scattolini: Ore si garde: qui muer sainç sper oit mal
9355] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): esp(e)riç; the original line would be 13 syllables, a problem avoided by qu'
9356] Cf. Inf. 3.31 (Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 30)
9358] Scattolini: a ge dit

9359] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 22): la [lor] poëste; in OF "poëste" is feminine but the adjectival form also exists (Matsumura p. 2622, not found in T-L); throughout this text the gender is often unclear (cf. v. 5040, where it is also in rhyme; poëstés, vv. 3679, 4307, 10305, also in rhyme; poësté, vv. 7146 (in rhyme), 11029).

9362] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 22), Scattolini: Qui manganel (missing "i"); Scattolini: balestre (no abbreviation or "r" present; note that this is not therefore a rhyme, but rather assonance, as several lines in this laisse).
9367] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 22), Scattolini: fineste; the reference here is to the Last Judgement, when sinners will be placed at God's left hand, and the MS reads "s" with no cross-stroke.
9374] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 81) comments that Eneas seems to be generally stressed on the penultimate syllable, which makes sense for the romance languages.
9377] 'l' inserted above the line, with caret below.

9378] enquesicion: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 298), "enquête," 'investigation, inquiry'. Stengel notes that many of the -ion endings count as only one syllable: cf. sospicion 9539 [=9382], 10790 [10633], entencion 10605 [10448] (beside entencïon 10589 [10432]) ("Höllenfahrt" p. 81).
9379] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 23): devés (b[etter]: dois)
9383] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 23): ceste (b[etter]: tel)
9388] Here we resolve "cum" to keep a parallel construction.
9393] Line edited at the end; after son there is a light line and then the first downstroke of m seems inserted, darker, very close to that line. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 24): Tot (les)
9394] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 24): faus(i)té; he says "read fausité (5'+6)" (p. 81).
9396] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 24): mains (ja) n'oit n'(av)oit; he also says, "b[etter]: Cil qui mains ja 'n avoit 'n oit trop; compare [9223]" (p. 81).
9397] MS a expunctuated with e above. We give the corrected reading here. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 24): fuïrent (for sivrent)
9399] Scattolini: laser
9400] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 24): [Quar] je voy

9403] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 24): (et) a troy; this scene is illuminated at the bottom of the page, the left-most panel, with multiple bodies in coffins, surrounded by devils with red flames coming out of their bodies. The insects are not visible. Stengel remarks that the (et) a is elided (p. 81).
9404.1] e- inserted with caret below.

9406] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 24): Li pieç [loieç] ...; Scattolini comments on Stengel's correction, and suggests that lumere is out of place here, that it perhaps replaces perdre. However, worms eating corpses' eyes are a common illustration of death, so not at all out of place.
9408] MS: sor, emended; Stengel: sor (b[etter]: soi)
9409] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 24): [de]soç; he is thinking of French, no doubt; "sotto il letto" works for Italian, and the line is 10 syllables as it stands.
9410] T 9074: che zascun el so corpo speza [each one of whom cuts up his body]
9412] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 24): graffes oy n'a nul, ne le fere
9415] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 25), Scattolini: de pere; depere is from "deperir" 'se perdre' (T-L col. 1416, "vernichten" 'destroyed, annihilated').
9417] MS: sedaine; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 25): luxure ... sedame; cf. P=sodoma; T 9081: sotimity. This seems to be a combination of "sodomie" with "sodoine," 'drunken' (T-L, col. 703-704).
9420] Cf. Dante, Inf. 33.135
9421] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 25): fel(ons); ; he notes that this is necessary if Ci a is elided (p. 81). Cf. Dante, Inf. 22.15; Morgante 18.144.8.

9423] Third part of the illumination at the bottom of the page: figures with blotches on their clothes, devils around, and another figure looking down, looks like he's being pulled by devils. Center illustrates the three figures, Aeneas, Huon, and St. Guillaume, in that order.
9425] MS: set; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 25): set (b[etter]: sot); T 9089: soto soy drapy [under their garments]

9426] See T-L pustule col. 2103; for marmosse, cf. marmoser, FEW marm-; T-L marmoser, col. 1185, ll. 9ff, 'to murmer'; Matsumura, "marmotter," 'mumble'. Scattolini suggests that marmosse is in analogy with flamos/flamosse, influenced by OF "marmitos" ('lamentable, misérable'), and suggests an origin for pusterne from "pustule"; we also note a similarity.
9428] fuserne: OF "fuisel" "Holzstück?" ('stick of wood', Mainone, Laut, p. 23) .
9429] berne: "berner": 'faire sauter en l'air, secouer; se moquer de qqn' (DMF 2015, consulted 16 Jan 2021) http://stella.atilf.fr/Dendien/scripts/tlfiv5/advanced.exe?8;s=1153139070

9430] Dictionaries refer to "enfrener" for "enferner" (see Tobler-Lommatsch; Hindley; Matsumura), but here there might (also?) be a play on words: "to put into inferno, hell." That is clearly the understanding of T 9093: Quelo pechato le y[n]fernò [That sin put them into hell]; it is also close to "enfermer," 'to make ill', but also 'to enclose'.
9433] Scattolini: vaneglorie, here one word but two words in previous line.
9438] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 26): qui a diex
9439] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 26): bat(i)ra
9440] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 26): (ja)mès; he later notes, mès = jamès appears elsewhere; he reads thus because the verse form 6'+5 is probably the base form for this line like 9978 [=9821].
9441] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 26): qu'el font; following line, "qui ici." Differences in resolving q + abbreviation not further remarked.
9446] Scattolini: n'el font
9448] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 26): ist[e]ront
9449] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 26): que (lor) poine; Dante, Inf. 14.39, etc.
9451] Cf. Graf, p. 107; Dante, Inf. 7.64 ff.

9453] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 27): [a] man a man; the reason for this is unclear; the Italian "mano a mano" would be 'bit by bit', and so T 9116 reads. But see T-L col. 823, "main a main," "hintereinander, alsbald", 'one after the other', 'at once'.
9455.1] Scattolini: por man
9455.2] porman appears in EE specifically in the form "ja porman" in the meaning "bientôt," 'soon' (T-L cols. 298-299, "parmain," 'early in the morning'; Matsumura, "bientôt").
9459] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt", p. 81): b[etter] something like: por l'(om) human

9461] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 27): [l']oit pris; in so doing, he changes the meaning: here Guillaume is afraid and suggests a change of route; with Stengel's reading (that follows the three other texts), it is Guillaume who takes Huon by the hand and suggests the change.
9462] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 27): lui[n]tan
9465] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 27): dit le spir[i]t

9466] MS: ceran; this word does not seem to appear in any dictionary, but the MS reading is clear; it would seem to mean either a place or a time. Terran, terren, etc. appear numerous times in this text, and in other F-I texts both as noun and adjective; in RIALFRI on 9 Nov. 2018, teran appears 19 times, frequently in rhyme, and "c" and "t" confusions are frequent in paleographical tradition. Mainone (Laut, p. 16), suggests that it is from the Greek κεραύνια (light bulb?); Scattolini: ceran. T-LFI suggests "serran", an enclosed place; perhaps 'grove'? But again, there is no other example (in RIALFrI 'seran' is equivalent to: 'sera'; 'serena/o'; 'saranno'; 'serrando', no nouns other than 'sera', 'evening'). As Scattolini points out, there is no OF verb "peoner"; it is an adjective or substantive only (T-L cols. 690-691). However, "pedonare" appears in Old Italian; TLIO cites glosses on Boccaccio, 1375.

9468] Cf. Dante, Inf. 2.13; according to tradition, Aeneas had a son after his death, whom his wife bore in the woods, so named him "Silvius." Various Latin historians give "Aeneas Silvius" as the son of Silvius (Livy, Ab urbe conditor 1.3; Dionysius of Helicarnassus, Antiquitates romanae 1.71, Perseus); according to the same historians, his successor was Latinus Silvius. In any case, the descendants of the rulers of the Trojan settlement took the cognomen "Silvius" attached to personal names. Here then the "Silvian" seems to refer to the family line initiated by Aeneas's father, Anchises, whom Aeneas brought with him away from Troy. The father did not make it to the Italian peninsula. Scattolini notes that the reference is backwords and turned around, though referring to Inf. (361 n641).

9471] This is the first part of the illumination at the bottom of the page. Several figures are in water up to the waist, with devils at the bottom, rocks over head. The furthest right figure in the swamp has an 'S' over his head. In the middle are the two figures, Huon and Guillaume (who is always identified with a halo, and is in bare feet). Huon is turned toward the left, to Saudin. Scattolini notes that the Br version "schai" for B's schine is a Venetian dialect term for 'armpit', which clarifies the image (she cites Cortelazzo-Marcato, Dizionario veneziano della lingua e della cultura popolare nel XVI secolo).
9472] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 28): lu[n]tan
9473] Note the -nt ending in an -n laisse.
9475] rufian: Cf. Möhren ("Huon d'Auvergne") who defines it as "maquereau" from the Italian (p. 320).
9477] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 28): part(ie)
9479.1] MS: quil sont ouran; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 28): qu'il sont ovran; Scattolini: qu'ils ont ovran

9479.2] T 9142: lor àno lavorato [they (have) worked]. It is difficult here to know how to interpret "ovran," which might help explain the preceding verb. If a past participle, Scattolini's reading makes sense, but in B the long form of s is usually used at the beginning of a word, the short form (like modern printed s) at the end of a word, and here the long form appears. Mainone (Formen, p. 15) gives "part" (for "participle") but that could be either present or past.
9481] Scattolini argues that the laisse is part of William's discourse to Huon (361 n651).
9484] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p.28): maint[e]; but in his corrections file, he changes his mind: "read: maint" (p. 81).
9491] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 29): [en]durer

9494] The second (rightmost) portion of the illumination on this page is a mangonel hefting stones, a series of which go across the top of the illumination. The drawing is very detailed and would no doubt interest a historian of arms. Engeter (enjeter): 'faire tomber (qn)'; 'envoyer (qch) à quelque distance de soi' (Matsumura); enlaisser: 'abandonner'; line is missing from Turin.
9497] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 29), Scattolini: par man

9500] Brown spot in the middle of the line, over end of tu and beginning of gre, as above in 9477 at the end of the line. Furthermore, the illumination at the bottom is in two parts. The first consists of the jugleor with devils around them with fire coming out of them. The furthest right of the figures has S above his head to indicate Saudin; there is a brownish wash over their lower extremities that could be the source of the spots elsewhere on the page.
9503] di above the line with caret below
9505] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 29): tot(e); Graf, p. 109; Inf. 21.50 ff.
9507] Scattolini inadvertently mislabels here, 65 r b (her v. 9664)
9508] E 'n = et in; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 29), Scattolini: en tote
9519] Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia": Inf. 10.22-24
9521] estrage (T-L 1433), 'Spur, Weg'; Italian strage [massacre] is not attested before the sixteenth century (DELI, Firenzuola, 1518-1525)
9524] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 30): Tramis [par]
9533] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 31): quuens [Hue]
9547] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 31): et [por t'] oncir
9548] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 31): (en) sont
9549] chorin (T-L corin, col. 862, third entry 'Groll, Kummer, Sorge, Streit' [resentment, sorrow, worry, strife])
9550] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 31): com(e) fist
9551] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 31): (b[etter]: enchaïneç) ausi
9552] For the form inferin see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 350).
9562] t inserted above the line with caret below
9564] Scattolini: seroi ge
9567] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 32): après (la) mort

9572] For robist (T-L rubist, col. 1529), see (Lexikalische, p. 431) who suggests a derivation from Italian RUPES, producing a landscape element, which he also says is not always clearly identifiable from the context (Lexikalische, p. 431). However, "robestre" the adjective also appears in F-I for "wild"; see the same page for Holtus, EE. As an adjective, the GdA defines it 'robusto' [strong/fierce]. For fagon, GdA gives "facion: .... fazione, l'insieme di schiere di soldati." Mainone is unclear as to the meaning; he notes that it is not French, and relates it to earlier appearances such as those mentioned, suggesting that all are based on the landscape feature (GdA, 'côteau escarpé' [steep hillside], and but also notes the adjective "wild" [Fr. "rubeste," Ital "rubesto"; T-L rubeste, col. 1525], related earlier to rivers (Laut, pp. 30-31). He then suggests that fagon is like 'fango', 'mud' in the other versions. T-L defines "fouc" (with an unvoiced instead of a voiced consonant) as 'Schar' [crowd, host], but if that's the case, there is no element relating the word to the preceding one, so robist might be an adjective deformed for rhyme. Previous lines mention a stone being loosed from above causing fear (9568-9569). Perhaps "Those of the muddy abyss"? Note that this and the next line were problematic for the poet, both with truncated finals and with no exact correspondence in the other versions.

9573] MS: menistr; there is no abbreviation mark. For the lines 9573-75, Cf. Graf, pp. 107-108; Inf. 3. 103-105. The 'mo' of mort in the next line has been edited. Scattolini does not emend. Scattolini suggests that the blasfemant in the following line is an error, repeating the verb of this line. However, that is not necessarily the case, since repeating the term creates a certain rhythm reflective of prayers– in the contrary sense. One can invoke St. Francis's "Beato si..." or various Latin prayers, like the Beatitudes, for positive examples.

9579] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt", p. 33): 'l enc(l)usa; Holtus (Lexikalische 290): enclusé in EE comes from "accuser" (It. incusare); but there are also examples where it means 'enclosed'; cf. EE v. 4230-31, "la grant tor desus/ O sont nos Frans anserez et enclus" [the great tower above / Where our Franks are enclosed and emprisoned].
9587] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 33): t(oe)'aïe
9599] This could reflect Inf. 3.52-54, where Dante sees an "'nsegna" that spirits follow mindlessly.
9601] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 34): n(on)'entrarent au laris(!); T-L col. 196 estre au larriz, 'in übler Lage sein' [to be in an awful place]
9604] This is the illumination at the bottom of the next page, 67R, next to this description.
9607] Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia": Inf. 3.84. The next line appears in Graf, p. 108.

9608] cenis: cf. Mainone (Laut, p. 29 n1), 'Asche' [ashes]; he notes that it also appears in Hector et Hercule and GdA; RIALFrI adds Martin da Canal's Estoires de Venise to the list of other occurences.
9611] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 35): tot [les] dis

9616] Graf, p. 108; Meregazzi, Inf. 3.72-73
9618] Cf. Inf. 3.72-75 (Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 32)
9623] Cf. Inf. 2.88-90, Beatrice to Virgil
9626] This is the figure to the left of the illumination below, with bow and arrows in a quiver at his waist. Naked figures are visible in the water under the boat also.
9627] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 35): enjus

9629] tre si grant: this is the first appearance of this word order in Huon. It also appears in vv. 19781 (de tre si dur) and 11630 (tres si grant). Thus we do not emend, though it would not be French word order. The construction also appears in GdA,v. I.VI. 235, “por tre si grant vertuz” and I. VI. 672, "por tre si grant valor."
9641] See Scattolini vv. 786-88 for a discussion of the differences between versions here ("Ricerche," p. 366).
9652] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 37): et [da] dragon
9653] Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia,"Inf. 3.109-11; cf. Graf, p. 108
9655] There is no abbreviation at all on the word 'etres'. The illumination shows Charon with an oar, not a sail; in T 9314: remo, 'oar'.
9657] Compare Inf. 8.17; 8.24 where Phlegyas (Flegïas) and Filippo Argenti appear.
9658] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 37): (de)sor
9659] The first three words of the line were scratched out and then replaced.
9661] For confés, see Mainone (Laut, p. 24).
9662] Graf. p. 108, for these three lines. Inf. 3.88-89
9664] Toi toy: toi from "togliere" or "tolir," to take (DELI, 'levare, rimuovere, spostare', Dante 1313-19), Lat. TŎLLERE, '(sol)levare'

9670] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 38): n'oit [ni]; otherwise line is 4'+ 5 (p. 81); for flés see Mainone (Laut, p. 24), 'Lust, Neigung' [desire, inclination], but also Morlino, "Nuovi contributi," p. 409, where he approaches it to It 'fiato' [breath]. Here, the idea of 'inclination' or 'desire' as proposed by Mainone makes perfect sense; however, being out of breath is also possible, though not particularly supported by the context as in AdB. The verb forms from enfler, here, on the contrary, are clearly related; see note, v. 2315.

9672] There does not seem to be a tradition of Charon being driven from the heavens. It is possible that there is a confusion between Acheron and Charon; Natale Conti in his early sixteenth century Mythologiae has a story about Acheron being an outcast from Olympus before becoming a river in the underworld. Conti's sources are not all known, and there is controversy about his accuracy. The similarity of the two names— Acheron and Charon— and furthermore the author's confusion with Chiron here as well (the sagitaire, unnamed, v. 9675)— suggests the possibility of such confusions (we thank Dr. Aaron Palmer for this information April 2022).
9675] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 38): entoisés; entorsés from IN+*TŎRQUERE became *TŎRCERE, to bend (DELI)

9680] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 38): [tot] rüés; this line is problematic for syllable count; one or more syllables are missing. In his corrections, Stengel adds, "b[etter]: Le espir[i]t and emend [tot]."
9681] Scattolini: aplantés
9684] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 38): assés
9695] Cf. Inf. 12.13-20, Virgil to the Minotaur

9696] Diomedes was one of Chiron's students. Dante places him with Ulysses in Inf. 26, with the evil counsellors. It's not clear why Aeneas wishes to send the (here unnamed) archer to posture before Diomedes, except perhaps because a "mixed" origin was unnatural.
9697] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 39): Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Que... partì; Scattolini: que
9713] Dares the Phrygian. See note in the translation.
9716] Scattolini: ques sont en l'escur aire
9717] Scattolini: fi sclaire
9719] Cf. Dante, Inf. 12.65-138, where Chiron has Nessus carry Dante on his back through the river of blood.
9733.1] See Mainone (Formen, p. 45); estieç is a form of the present here.
9733.2] Scattolini: ert ros
9741] aseios (Mainone Laut, p. 38): "durstig," 'thirsty'
9744] dei: preposition "de" + plural masculine article in the Italian form
9746] Scattolini: [l]amenta. See line 498 and note.
9749] MS: Si fist .hue . a ·Wll'me·; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 42): Si fist [a] Hue (a) ·Wll'me·; T 9405: cosỳ feze Guielmo a Ugo [...]; the names seem to be reversed here; see translation note.
9750] sclavine: type of mantle or cloak. Cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 307, with incomplete definition), but Matsumura, "esclavine," "manteau d'origine slave," 'cloak of Slavic origin'.
9752] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 42): ni soit
9755] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 42): voit [b[etter]: c. soit], following the other three versions
9756] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 42): (plus) plaisir, which he corrects then to "l. [read]: que plus plaisir le soit Form 5'+ 6"(p. 81).
9764] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 42): a (saint)
9765] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 43): il (et) puis; as Scattolini points out, the verb "bere" [to drink] present in Br and T, is missing here.
9777] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 43): Suscitarent(!)
9781] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," pp. 81-82): glorios is clearly bisyllabic with a silent caesura ending [5'+7] (p. 81-82).
9782] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 42): li bon jors
9784] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 42): compagne (de) deu
9785] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 44): puisque (as always; not further remarked); Scattolini: en le contraire (missing initial "E")
9787] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 44): 'n avra
9792] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 44): (Or) Insons...ça

9797] Scattolini: pechieç le mostra (MS: lē); T 9453 reads "mainere." mainere appears 23 times in this text, and mainer, mineres, each once; but the complete word would make the B line 5 (or 5')+6. Main has quite a variety of extended meanings and thus we have not emended, electing a non-literal understanding of it (cf. Godefroy, 'espèce, condition'; T-L main2, col. 813, 814: 'Besitz; Volk' [domain; person]; main3, col. 828: 'Wohnung' [dwelling]), suggesting either multiple places with different sins or multiple individuals with different sins..

9798] MS: qe ia cont ni ensera; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 44), Scattolini: qe ja cont ni en sera; however, only T also has this line and there conter is in the infinitive form dependent on a form of the modal *potere; T 9454: e de gran pene de che zà [con]tar non se porà [and great punishments that truly one cannot recount]. Perhaps the redactor was thinking [of the great pain from which [the] count would never leave], since ensera is written together; it's not clear what Stengel intended as the meaning. However, either way, one syllable is added.
9800] Scattolini: que numerable

9801] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 44), Scattolini: acorcer; that reading would mean "to shorten," but the MS clearly reads acoreer. Such an error is quite possible e/c are difficult to distinguish in some scripts. "Acorées" appears in AdB, and he defines it "muni, équipé"; Wunderli suggests that it is based on the Italian corredato with lenition of the -d- and the frequent F-I prefix a- (AdB, vol. 3, p. 235); conreer appears in OF as 'préparer, apprêter' [prepare, get ready] (Matsumura), cf. T-L 714.
9804] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 44): Ugon (b[etter]: U. ch., G.). This laisse is problematic in many lines, in part because of the unusual rhyme.

9806] s'aonde: Mainone is unsure and suggests "s'aüne" (Laut, p. 36). T 9462: El bon Troian apresso lor chamina [The good Trojan walked near them/with them].
