T-L has a question mark (col. 412, line 14), and Matsumura suggests 'commander'; EE includes several forms of "aonter" but these seem to be based on ad+ honte, 'to shame' (e.g., aonter, vv. 1579, 2563, 2951). However, aüner (Matsumura) or äuner (T-L col 678), means 'to join' and appears in other F-I texts (Roman d'Alexandre, Bataille d'Aliscans, Foucon de Candie, Chevalier Errant, etc. [ RIALFrI, 'auner; 'aunent' etc., consulted 24 January 2021])), so we will follow these. See also note in the translation.

9808] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 45), Scattolini: nasconde; that is the opposite of the meaning, as T demonstrates, T 9464: e de tuto l'esere lo vero li dize e no[n] l'asconde. In B, the negative precedes the verb; cf. 5398, ascondre. From Latin ABSCONDERE (see DEAFél; FEW 24,49b, consulted 29 Mar 2021, https://deaf-server.adw.uni-heidelberg.de/lemme/ascondre#ascondre).
9812] 'oscura valle', Inf. 29.65

9814] aponde: Mainone, Laut, p. 36: "identisch mit sponde [...], altfrz. esponde, indem e vortonig oft a wird" [identical with sponde [ 9824 ...], OF esponde, where pretonic e frequently becomes a]. The Dantean influence makes one think of "shores," but could it be from the verb apondre? T-L col. 461 suggests something like "weighing in" when used of a conversation. The term is a hapax here; T 9470 piena d'anime tuta a dolorosy guaie [full of souls, all with sorrowful woes], does not help.
9818] fergonde: Mainone, Laut, p. 36, metathesis from FREQUENTAT
9819] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 45), Scattolini: val a fonde; TLIO, "affondo": 'Giù, in profondità; all'interno di qsa' [below, in the depths; inside of something], with a date of 1338.
9821] prevonde = "prevoire" (Mainone, Laut, p. 36)

9825] aubre: see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 211), 'tree'. However, "au" reflects "o," as 'ovra'. T 9481: anzé adovrono tuto el male e lor ovre si afonda [on the contrary, they do all evil and thus torpedo their (own) works], which demonstrates that the original varied in some way from what we have here. We can compare aubré (v. 5602), which means 'worked', and is therefore related. Si n'afronde: MS sin afronde. This is another hapax, however the words are divided. Fronde is a version of fonde, 'slingshot', 'catapult'; fonder is the verb, here with an a- prefix; cf. Italian affondare (DELI, 1252-58 CE). See also the translation note. This is a difficult passage.

9826] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 45): desor par [ce] que sconde; Scattolini: par que sconde; des or appears frequently in this text, and not only are the two words written separately, but the contrast of then vs. now is clear. T obviously understood the two as one word, however: 9482... desopra sì s'asconde. The singular verb is logical for the original subject, Le grant clergé, 'the great clergy' though for the English it must appear in the plural.
9827] tu is is written over a scraped-out spot in the MS.
9834] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 46): adroit
9837] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 46): devant
9838] There is a dot on the line after noisse in the MS.

9840] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 46): Com(e); however, in his notes and corrections, he says "read: Come, form 5'+ 6"(p. 82). Hand and ink are different here; tighter writing and the ink smears a bit black.

9841] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 46), Scattolini: heité; herté: cf. GF, line 6289; critics have been divided between "charity" and "hatred." The source however would be unclear. It cannot be "inheritance" or "heir" here. Mainone (Laut, p. 18 n1) says this doubtless is confused with "deshaitier," 'to be be sad, lament, grieve', so the past participle is 'sad, woeful'.

9842] empuit: seems to derive from emplir "to fill," with the vocalisation of the l (perhaps by false analogy); this is a hapaxlegomenon as far as RIALFrI and other resources are concerned. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 46), Scattolini: em puit
9844] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 46), Scattolini: mal aguré
9850] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 47): l'engombre (pas)
9851] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 82): read 'n ay
9853] Scattolini: ascemble
9857] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 47): ensont(!)
9864] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 47): dïent
9866] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 47): cest(uy); but he changes his mind in the notes: "read: cestuy, with obscuriment elided" (p. 82).

9869] Cf. Inf. 4.31-42. Dante, however, does not have inhabitants in agony, but "sanza speme vivemo in disio" [without hope we live in desire] (Durling and Martinez, pp. 72-73). T has Huon asking Aeneas if he thinks he will leave, more similarly to Dante asking Virgil (vv. 9524-25).

9871] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 48): for qu' "El plaisist a diex omnipotent!"; Scattolini: for "qu'el plaisist a Diex omnipotent"; Stengel's quotes seem to be misplaced; he has them around "E ge" on the previous line, and then before the El here, where they should also open before non respont. The two editors seem to be separating a quote within a quote, but if that is the case, where it begins is not clear. See the translation for an alternative.
9874] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 48): enspoir
9884] The Harrowing of Hell is here narrated first person by Aeneas, in answer to Huon's question, starting with the next line. Cf. Inf. 4.52 ff. haïe: OF 'hait', T-L "Lust," 'desire'

9890] MS: se nest devie; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 49): se 'n est; devie and encolorie seem to refer to "substance" which is feminine, though the noun for God is usually masculine. Our interpretation is based on Scattolini (Ricerche, p. 325).

9898] MS: de boin iluech; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 49): de boin iluech[es] mie; Scattolini: de loin iluech mie; T 9554: Nesun no[n] remase dy bony y[n] quel locho nemicho [no one good remained in that inimical place (that is, hell)]; no other version has this line. A missing abbreviation over the "o" of "boin" seems the most reasonable explanation. Remist: from "remanoir" (T-L col. 704).
9900] Scattolini: ne crie
9905] Scattolini: il

9906] Cf. T 9562: a un castelo che no[n] fo un tanto belo al mondo [to a castle such that there wasn't such a beautiful one in the world]. Since the following word is mont, it would seem that there was a saut du même au même. Turin also however also seem to have not quite understood.
9913] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 50): Ja pas not(e) nosiront

9915.1] The illumination at the bottom of this page is of a city with five towers visible, a figure in red (with head covering) at the top of the first gate on the left, nearest the three visitors who are at the far left. The gate figure holds a book with black dots on it. "The figure on the tower will be Tholomé; what he is holding looks like an unbound book, or possibly a single sheet; possibly a map of the heavens; on the left side the half-circle showing may be part of a representation of the course of the stars; on the right the dots all round the edge of the page may represent stars in the center of which is something that looks like an astronomical instrument (part of an astrolabe?)" (PEB). Note that the tower is square, suggesting that reont refers to something else. Charere (line 9915) means both 'chair' (cattedra in MSI) and 'highway' in this text, as confirmed by other F-I texts. In fact, the gateway is rounded and the human figure is at the highest point. Since this is a scholar with a book, it makes the most sense for him to be in a chair or seat. The portion remaining in the Turin MS (folio 146R) shows a loggia with rounded openings to the left of the illumination, with the three travellers outside to the left. One figure inside (with a fancy headdress) is on a chair with a baldacchino in a polygonal shape (not quite a circle, but circular) above. Since the walls in the Berlin MS illumination reach outside the frame, there is nothing above the figure who is on top of the gate there. It is unclear therefore whether the Turin version is a variation of meaning, but in any case, it is one possible explanation of reont.
9915.2] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 50): chaiere
9919] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 50): studïer; not necessary, fu a are two syllables, since broken between hemistichs.

9921] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 50): n'isiront; while it is difficult to distinguish the links between downstrokes, "insir"/ "ensir" is the standard form in this text and the second two strokes seem more closely linked than the first and the second.
9930] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 51): crïer; not necessary, by counting the final -e at the end of the first hemistich.

9935.1] There are several historical figures by the name Nicomachus to whom this may refer. Aristotle's father and son were both so named; the Nicomachean Ethics, a compendium of Aristotle's notes (or Aristotle's notes plus Nichomachus's comments on them) may have been dedicated to the son. Nicomachus of Gerasa, who lived in the first century AD, was a mathematician about whom little is known. His work on the magical properties of numbers and a manual on harmonics, an early discussion of musical theory and pitch. Various other works of his were lost. Since there are references to necromacy in this section, the second identity seems more likely.

9935.2] blastemer: for the form, see Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 325-26). In these four lines of B, the subject is not quite clear; we are presuming that the subject is as in T 9590 el comenza Nichomachus a comandare [he began to comand Nicomacus], and we have punctuated to follow that; for an alternative possibility, see the translation.
9944] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 51): Et [en] aillons

9945] As Scattolini points out, this version may be inaccurate, since it would be odd for the door opening to be named "Nicomacus"; T 9600-9611 gives "anbasadore" instead of "pertus" (see her note for her lines 1067-66 [sic], p. 366).

9947] T 9602: Un nome scrisse sopra la porta de sussa; see Scattolini, this section is complicated (p. 368, vv. 1068-69). Following T, if "hom" here were a scribal error for "nom" then the line would mean something like 'a name was written at the top of the gate'.
9948] Scattolini discusses the confusion of this line and the following in the four different versions (note for her lines 1068-69, p. 366). As she notes, it argues for T not deriving from B.
9949] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 52): Le sainct [espirt]; a l'eperdus: Guillaume speaks to Huon and Aeneas.

9950] Farabus: Abu Nasr al-Farabi, a great Arabic philosopher, known as Alpharabius in the West, viewed as the "second master" after Aristotle. He lived in the 9th-10th centuries and was known for scientific (which include mathematical and musical works) and philosophical writings.
9951] See translation for a delineation of speakers in this exchange.
9952] Scattolini: que vos ert
9964] Scattolini: dialetiche [e] l'autre
9971] Scattolini: ni avoir (see introduction on distinguishing pronouns); see translation for a possible alternative.
9972] The final letter of cert is smeared in the center. This line is missing from T; it would fall between 9626 and 9627.
9977] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p.. 53): tretot [com] fou
9982] sagurament: cf. Ital. "sciagura"; sagure (Aquilon vol. 3, p. 310), "malheur, accident"; Scattolini: dasa sagurament
9983] Scattolini: queens
9986] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 54): trove(ro)nt
9989] In the ending of the final word, an o is changed to e with a line at the bottom of the letter.
9994] Scattolini: Forte est
9999] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 54): Les dras
10002] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 54): [Et] le mastre

10003] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 55) places four dots at the end of this line; he notes, "the lines lost after 10160 [10003] in B are kept in P, but also missing in T. However the gap is concealed here, while T reads 10161 vs. BP: Dize lo conte a Eneas chy lo mena. That truly demonstrates that the precedent of P sometimes follows the original more closely than the BT family" (p. 82, trans. LZM). Note that in Br this is a "carte de Iometrie" (v. 1113) followed directly by Huon's question to Aeneas, here v. 10005. Scattolini suggests that there seems to be an entire line missing following this one: this one is exactly parallel to the Br reading followed by "Llo bon conte U[gon] abraça et aplaine" which would obviate the need for presuming a blank in the middle of the following line ('The good count Huon embraced and caressed [aplanir] with his two arms Aeneas who led him'). But see the next line and note.

10004] The line is complete, but something is clearly missing for the sense here; cf. T 9658: Dize lo [con]te a Eneas, chy lo mena [The count asks Aeneas, who leads him]. Br similarly reads Dist li quens Ugues ad Eneas qi lo maine (v. 1117). See note for preceding line. Scattolini suggests that a line is missing here, present in T; rather, it would seem that two lines are combined in B rather haphazardly, though it does almost make sense, and is 10 syllables.

10014] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 55) and Scattolini divide the conversation differently, rebeginning the quote with this line. The Italian "straniare" would be 'to distance', "straniarsi", 'to escape, lose touch, estrange' (DELI, "allontanare" vs "estraniarsi"), but in GdA and Pharsale we find two verbs: "straindre" as 'stringere, unire, serrare, dominare', and "strainer," 'trascinare, condurre'.We understand straine as from the verb estreindre.
10021] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 55): D'Achile(s)
10025] Scattolini: outre pasé
10029 ] e is above the line with caret below.
10033] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 33): cont[e]; note however that if oïr is pronounced as one syllable, the total line count could be even.
10037] This could be either "fit il" or "fit, 'il n'est'" without a difference in meaning.
10043] Scattolini skips this section with French epic heroes, to pick up later, at line 10315.
10045] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 57): ni a

10050] de mur: in this MS, "mur" appears (8 times) as 'walls'; "mure" (1 time) also as 'wall'; "demore" is only a verb, 'to stay, remain'; "demor" is a delay, respite; and "more" is a verb form (from "mourir"); but already in 1321 Dante uses dimora as 'a place in which one lives' (DELI, sub voce). The meaning is a logical extension of 'to stay, remain' to 'to live, inhabit', which in fact seems to appear in several of the verb appearances (e.g., 4521, 5202, 8529, 5092, 4362, 7911, etc.). T 9703 poses a similar issue, with "demure." Matsumura's definition 'faire demore, faire séjour' (cf. T-L, col. 1382), resolves the difficulty, and so we translate. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Cum[e]
10051] pure below the line into the edge of the page
10053] (e) is in the binding. MS: oscüe
10057] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 57): ni porte
10058] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 57): Si doit
10059] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 57): (Que) De
10062] MS: sc[r](i)pture: i above the line as abbreviation
10067] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 57): qu[e] il soy vengast

10070] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 57): desoremès... chat[iv]ure; the line as it stands is 12 syllables; chature may be an adaptation of "chastiier, chastoiier" ('blâmer') with the noun ending -ura/e instead of -ment or -oi (T-L chastiier, chastïement, chastoi); cf. Holtus, Lexikalische (pp. 114-117, where one example is specifically valure, the rhyme-word in the following line).

10071] In this manuscript there are two forms: par poy (2 appearances) and por poy (one appearance), but only por appears with val and its derivatives. Mixed lists are not unknown, so we have resolved thus here.
10075] MS: cu[m] The abbreviation mark here is in the form of a vertical "z"; cf. Vieillard, Conseils, Vol. 1, p. 28, # 11.
10079] Stengel ("Höllenfahr," p. 57): se 'n aïs la valore; the umlaut is not necessary, line is 7+7 since the caesura is after justisse.
10083] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 58): des spir[i]t
10087] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 58): salirent cum
10088] Stengel ("Höllenfahr," 58): mer(a)veilosse

10091] Or: "Eneas," quiert, "que...; note T 9744, where a preposition begins the line: a Enea domanda, "Che zente sono queste tante?" Note that the classical figure is asked and responds, unlike in Dante's Comedy, where the classical figure (Virgil) typically speaks to his contemporaries, and Dante to his.

10093] These are all Saracens from Aspremont: Agolant is the ruler of the Saracens, father of Helmont, and killed by Girard's nephew Claire. Uliens is one of Agolant's judges, an important Saracen in the second half of the poem, killed by Richier, grandson of Duke Berengier.
10096] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 58): cristin(i)té

10101] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 58): atant; see introduction for explanation of word division here. T 9754: e che (le) lor anime àno de le pene tante [and their souls have many agonies/much suffering]. Here in B it is unclear whether arme refers to souls or to arms, since the term can refer to either.
10096] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt, p. 58): E che dou; this line is parallel to the preceding, where ou is the neuter demonstrative pronoun "o" (T-L cols. 929-930)

10105] This does not follow the French version of Aspremont; Roland killed Eaumont (=Helmont=Almonte). There is nothing about Helmont sleeping. See laisses 286-87 in Suard's edition. The sleeping recalls the episode of Roland killing Ferragu in the EE, where Ferragu took a nap using a rock as a pillow, and Roland was tempted to kill him with a stone (vv. 3535-3555).

10108] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt, p. 58) here proposes the emendation (homes) after .jj. to follow the plot of Aspremont, where Roland kills Eaumont on the second day of the battle. However, jors seems more appropriate for that reason. Cf. Suard, ed., Aspremont, vv. 3897-5545.
10096] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt, " p. 58): quant (il) estoit
10119] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p.): je quit; quit: for "cuit," from "cuidier" [croire]
10127] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 59): respondi (b[etter]: respont)
10135] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 60): cortois (b[etter]: C. fu a.)
10142] canter has a mark above the 'c', like an apostrophe; the meaning is unclear, but it is definitely ink and not a defect in the parchment. T: cercare.
10144] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 60): poy [pas] converser

10148] "Death by chessboard" is a chanson de geste motif: in the GF, Ogier the Dane kills Charlot, Charlemagne's son, with a chessboard; in Renaut de Montauban, Bertholet has died thus also, and further incidents appear in the Batârd de Bouillon and in Parise la duchesse, but there is no known incident relating to Thibaut killing his brother-in-law Folco in the East. On chess in the Middle Ages and its uses, see Adams, Power Play: The Literature and Politics of Chess in the Late Middle Ages; and Perkins, ed., Medieval Romance and Material Culture. An Italian novella, in fact, insists on Thibaut's family relationship to Guillaume through Folco (married to Anfelise, Thibaut's sister, niece of Desramé), I Conti di antichi cavalieri, ed. del Monte, pp. 118-22.

10158] The illumination at the bottom of this page, 70V, has three parts. Starting at the left, the three men travelling through hell, Guillaume in front and frontal; Huon to his left and side view; and Aeneas barely visible behind Guillaume's right. In the middle is a lady, side view, in a fancy purple dress with gold decorations; and to the right is a crowned man on a white horse with his sword raised to strike. His trappings are all gold- spurs, saddle, bit.
10163] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 61): mon dru (b[etter]: M. d., b. v.)
10174] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 62): Glorïete
10177] MS: este followed by expunctuated -e: dots both below and above. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 62): Que 'stoie

10182] Guilla[u]me: there is an abbreviation apostrophe after the two ll's, so though the name is usually spelled Guillame in the text we have added the u here. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 62): Guillame (s)en veit
10185] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 62): por (la) voge

10189] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 63): veurent...neü; the MS clearly reads venrent. This seems to be a sort of passive, literally, 'they had never come to be born of...'; see Rohlfs ¶ 735 for the use and development of venire, particularly in the north; for the form, see Wunderli, AdB vol. 3, p. 181 ("vinirent") and RIALFrI, which attests 22 forms precisely of "vinrent" though none in this structure (consulted 4 April 2021).

10194] guerere: Mainone, Laut, lists this as "nom sing." (p. 23), but that label is not the only possibility; in the GdA, the term appears as "warriors" (v. I. XIII, 1660, et al.), though it also looks singular.

10195] T 9849 A un balchon vite unn-omo chy à el suo viso chiaro [At a balcony he saw a man who from his clear face/from his face, clearly...]. The original of this segment evidently caused confusion.

10196] This is the first part of the illumination at the foot of 71R: three men are outside a city wall, within which (center) is a knight without a head covering, but a beard and long haïr, in flames. He wears armor covered by a yellow tunic decorated with black G's. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 63): (Mout) Si fait
10198] Nuls part: cf. Ménard, p. 261 (¶ 295 2° for the use of nul as positive.
10201] si cuide bien tenser: se tenser, 'se défendre' (T-L, Col. 232; Matsumura, sub voce)

10203] This is the second part of the illumination on 71R, to the right. Inside the city wall, devils are pushing that same figure (in yellow with black G's) into a cave opening (Hell, one presumes). Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 63): respont (b[etter]: R. E.)
10204] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 63): tot[e] part

10206] Girardo au Fraite [de Vienne] is a chanson de geste character, lord of Burgundy, Milon's brother, father of Rainier, grandfather of Oliver according to the GF. He revolted against Charlemagne, refusing to aid him in Aspremont. René Louis, De l'histoire à la légende, proposes various theories about the multiple Girards in chansons de geste. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 63): d'Afraite
10208] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 64): cuide (de)sor
10210] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 64): humilïere

10214] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 64): posse; but that form appears nowhere else; Mainone suggests that it is first person present subjunctive (Formen, p. 31), but it is not clear how that would work. Cfr. also T 9868 "Ay, Dio," dize Ugo[n], "yo te poso rengraziare! ["Oh, God," said Huon, "I can thank you!"]
10215] This line recalls Dante's Inf. 14, 6, "di giustizia orribil arte" [horrible art of justice (Durling and Martinez, p. 279)], as well as numerous other references to marvelous justice.
10217] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 64): (Nuls) Major
10224] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 64): ni son
10225] After laig, letter scratched out; again looks like white-out over the spot. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 65): ie son

10233] We are assuming that camperon comes from the verb campare; cf. OF 'eschamper'. Compare T 9887: O tu, da quel capiron [oh you, in that hooded cape], which would seem to indicate some difficulty in the source since it is so different.
10234] MS: seit hon; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 65): cum de fi le seit hom; but cf. seinté v. 802; and T che devenisse armito, com feze ly santy omeny [because you became a hermit, as holy men do]
10237] Aquillon: cf v. 9320, "le aquilenois", and EE, ' le ciel'
10240] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 65): nasïon
10234] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 65): un(e solet) boton

10243] There are no other forms of this as noun or as adjective. However, the suffix -borg does appear, where -urg does not. "The Burgundian" is Girard, lord of Vienne, known not only for his pride but his fierce fighting against the Saracens.

10246] non vaut si is written over a scratch-out. Attributed to Solomon are the biblical books of Proverbs, Ecclesiastes and the Song of Solomon, plus an apocryphal Wisdom of Solomon. Various vernacular versions of the Proverbs exist in Old French.
10247] The bone is very hard to read because of a black smear at the top of the folio that almost completely covers it.
10255] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 66): cont atant
10258] The original could have read "por voir et por semblant"; cf. 2912, 3930, etc. ("por voir") and 2450, 10258, etc. ("por semblant"), something like "truly and seemingly."

10260] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 66): [Et] ·W'· li; in Turin, the second hemistich is negative: T 9915 Guielmo ben lo sa, perzò no·l va reprendando [William knew it well, and for this reason didn't rebuke him].
10261] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p.): qu[e] il poit le chaçe(nt)

10263] MS: S a paser. This is a problematic section; see T 9918 -19: Se la penserò, e·l se mese questo chi l'atende; el comandò: "Dovite y[n]sire de pene tante gra[n]de [...] [He (William) thought it, and he put this to the one (Huon) who awaited him / he commanded: "You must leave very great pain].Two alternatives seem possible here in B: either s'aparler [he began to discuss/talk with those whom he met], which would require emending two letters; or, to follow Turin, as does Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 66): S'a pa[n]ser
10264] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 66): tant[e] grant
10270] alas: this is the imperfect subjunctive, first person for "aler": literally, "if I went telling..." .
10271] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 66): qui li va
10280] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 66): fu (b[etter]: Fu en g. a.)

10287] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 67): qui en lor preu si fie; why it is resolved this way is unclear. There is no equivalent word in T 9942 : per y[n]ganare altruy che y[n] lor se fidava [in order to trick others who trusted in them]; and no such word appears in the entire text.
10288] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," 67): Le vangelle
10297] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 67): De nul[e]s

10305] po[est]és: cf. forms of "e[st]" and four other forms of poeste(s). T 9959: per fare a luy dalmazo, si aveseno posanza [in order to do him damage, if they were able]. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 67): n'aüsent ponés

10309] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 67): s'en aperciut; since this is a perfect form, -ui- is expected, and there does seem to be a link at the bottom between the first two downstrokes; cf. Pope, ¶ 1065.

10310] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 67): A lor, 'to them'. Either reading is possible; all initials in the MS are slightly spaced away from the first word. Since this is a sequence– Huon realizes that they cannot hurt him– and we find T 9964: alora cridò, "Com my no[n] guadagnarite!" [then cried, "You won't win with me!"], we interpret here Alor.
10316] Scattolini recommences transcription here.

10317] This line is missing from T, where "butà" takes the place of gités, understood as the speech that follows in the next line (T 9971). Here we seem to have literally, [...] who had thrown to them of them (cf. Matsumura, "bombarder qn de qch" p. 1986; cf. DELI, gettare: "scagliare un oggetto lontano da sé" 'throw an object far from oneself', various examples in the early fourteenth century).
10321] Cf. Inf. 8.43-45, where Virgil embraces and kisses Dante for reacting strongly to Filippo Argenti. While Dante does not show Virgil laughing, strong positive emotion is present in both.
10327] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 68), Scattolini: alt[r]e terre (presumably on the basis of T 9980), and "autretel/alltretal" in Br and B. However, this does make sense, so we do not emend.

10329] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 68), Scattolini: Otisiaus. Tisiaus: Tisias is reported to have been the first theoretician of rhetoric in ancient Greece. It is taken that he was the student of one Corax, who has left no written work. Tradition has it that, after the fall of the monarchy in Sicily in the 5th c. BCE, the rise of democracy occasioned a need for persuasive speech (command no longer being accepted). One successful Sicilian practitioner was Gorgias who went to Athens in 427 BCE, where he became a major figure among the Sophists. In the Gorgias, Plato accused rhetoricians of favoring opinion over truth, success in the moment over enduring verities. (See also Phaedrus 267a-b.) Thus, in the history of rhetoric, Tisias would stand in the same relationship to rhetoric as the Sophists to sophistry. Support for this view comes in the theory that Corax was not a separate person, but that the word, which means "crow" is actually a derogatory nickname for Tisias himself. Rhetoric received a higher standing with Aristotle, fascinated with how things break down into their component parts, who wrote his Rhetoric as an analytical guide to, and practical manual for, the art—but he distinguished it from logic (dialectic). In the later Middle Ages, therefore, Tisias may be taken as a mythical founder, an archetype for all who indulge in untruth for emotional effect. Whatever his reputation in antiquity, in this passage, Berlin, lines 10324-10351, Tisias seems to represent all seven liberal arts (10328). The reference to his singing includes another of the seven: grammar, logic, rhetoric, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, and music. Major, "Epicharmus"; Hinks, "Tisias and Corax" (AEB). Scattolini mentions that he was part of the Sicilian School, and that the first treatise on rhetoric is attributed to him, giving the equivalents in other versions of Huon (Ricerche sulla tradizione, p. 174 n57).
10332] Scattolini: canter la usance

10335.1] This scene may refer to the beginning of the mass; at that era, the "introit involves the singing of a Psalm, which by this period would have been sung alternatingly by two choir bodies." It may be like improvisory practice where "one singer or group of singers would sing the original chant tune, and the other voices might improvise or sing composed counterpoint above it" and "vocal polyphony was used during mass, often with a low line carrying the chant tune, and upper voices providing countermelodies, improvised or otherwise." Where and when it was done and if the celebrant was involved would be difficult to verify since the specific origin of this story is not known. We thank Remi Chiu (Fine Arts (Music), LUM) his collaboration. We also thank Francesca Gambino (Filologia romanza, Dipartimento di Studi Linguistici e Letterari (DISSL), U. of Padova), who points out that "abis" as an adverb could reflect the verb "abesse" ("abaisser") in line 10333, "low(er)." "bis" in its modern sense first appears in the nineteenth century according to DEAF. See also P, vv. 4795-99. There the poem compares the priest beginning the mass speaking low, and when he finishes, the clergy pick up, just as Tisias does.
10335.2] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 68): biscant [...] sovr(e)avance; Scattolini: biscant [...] sovreavance

10338] There appears to have been a saut du même au même in an original text here, since both B and T repeat the same word in rhyme in two lines in a row. The second would be more likely be "habitance," similar to T 9992: Sono lor danaty y[n] scura abitanzia? [Are they damned in the dark abode?] The expression appears 8 times elsewhere in the MS, even below in 10345. See note in translation for the alternate meaning.
10340] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 69): la mance; here there are two possibilities. L'amance = 'love' (T-L, col. 323); porter la mance (manche) = 'to wear the sleeve (of someone), be a favorite'
10341] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 69): söe costumance
10342] E 'l = et + il
10344] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 69): grant (b[etter]: grande)
10345] Scure appears twice in the text; obscure or oscure in various forms, 7 times. There are no forms with an a- prefix.
10351] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 69), Scattolini: maint [et] en

10353] The identity of these devils is not positive, but Dante's Flegias appears in Inf. 8; Classical Phlegyas tried to burn down Apollo's temple at Delphi and thus Apollo condemned him to suffer in the afterlife; Ajax committed suicide in shame; Brugier may be the distortion of another noun, such as "bougre", 'heretic' (PEB), or "burgier", 'plunderer'. Moisan cites only "diable" in this version of Huon (vol. 1 p. 263).

10357] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 69): A la cité, Scattolini: a la cité; this line is missing from Turin. However, Br has "la cités de l'enfers non paeroient mas" and P has "a l'inferno no passeraveno mais," so the context is quite different.
10361] a tas: T 10113: a tanto. The B MS form is "atas" (a + tant), 'at this point' (tant, T-L col 85, lines 36-36).

10363] ras: Turin 10015 reads "rasy" [shorn], but in OF "ras" can also mean "guilty." That (guilt) however would not be immediately visible to the bystander (T-L col. 1187, ll. 49ff: reüs, res). "ras" (T-L rés, col. 977), meaning 'full, overflowing' might make sense if modifying the place, but not the people. Given the frequent negative descriptions of clergy, this would seem to be another anti-clerical judgement, since the clergy would be tonsured.

10368] rige:there is no word similar to this in the F-I lexicon (RIALFrI, 11 April 2021). P reads "Non tegnia riga ni canto che son ingual," where the other two Huon MSS do not have a similar reading; Br and T mention a "gallo," a 'cock', at the end of the line. Clearly there was a misapprehension. Riga normally refers to a line, either literal (ruled on paper) or metaphorical (a series of persons in a row, a physical ruling tool), DELI Dante, 1313-1319. It also refers to a musical staff on which notes are written, but the first attestation seems to be the 19th century (DELI). Given that constraint, the usage in P seems to mean a line, perhaps of prose writing contrasted with poetry (verso). For the interpretation here, see the note in translation.
10373] jornal: T-L jornel, col 1798 "Stündlein" [time; last/final hour]
10374] The construction of this line is somewhat unclear: croie is clear in the MS; in T the line is also problematic. Cf. line 420, cro ge. Stengler ("Höllenfahrt," p. 71), Scattolini: croie

10376] Bestiaries suggest that the nightingale warms her eggs 24 hours a day and that she sings at night to help "cherish her young and warm the eggs, [...] not less by her sweet tones than by the heat of her body" (White, ed., The Book of Beasts, pp. 139-40). That is on earth, so mortal, unlike here in hell. The oriole itself is not included in betiaries or in aviaries; see for example, the Aberdeen Bestiary (https://www.abdn.ac.uk/bestiary/ms24 , consulted 28 Jan 2021), especially ff. 25R - 63R. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 71): doriol
10379] Scattolini ends a quote here, but the beginning is not clear.
10380] hoeç is written over a scratch out.
10382] End of Scattolini's transcription.
10384] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 71): ne le [tres] grant

10385] Illumination at the bottom of 72R illustrates this scene; at the left the three travellers through Hell, Huon, St. William and Aeneas, led by Huon. To the right, naked figures are lifted by a devil with fire around (v. 10396); below, in a pool of blue, other naked figures with a dragon and little fires. Above the devil at top in middle, the initial 'R' in white on the blue upper portion, for Roger (v. 10401).
10387] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 71): puor.. .troblïere
10394] Cf. the devils in pitch of Inf. 21-22, esp. 22.131, 'falcon [...]' .

10402] stoit appears 37 times; and only one other time might there be istoit, line 2684 (see note at that line). Thus we interpret here as "qui stoit." Cf. Turin 10054,"Ora me conta ch'è stà lo tuo pecato" [Now tell me what was your sin]
10406] See Meregazzi, p. 34.
10407] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 71): moy (l') aler
10411] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 72): poisquil vois
10416] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 72): le fi (plevir et)
10417] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 72): Qu(e)'a

10433] plaisir: in this text appears specifically as a noun; cf. plaisir (10 including this), plaisire (1), pleisir (3); plesire (1); plasir (1), and thus "a Karllon" refers to both nouns. See also the translation note for this line.
10438] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 73): strucïon
10444] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 73): regïon
10449] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 73): obeïr
10456] MS: toe. This is oddly formed; it looks like 'tor' since final letter partially behind second. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 73): maleiçon
10460] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 73): Après de autre
10468] avrent; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 73): s'aurent veüe; since forms of avoir using the -v- were current into the late sixteenth century (Pope ¶ 976), we transcribe thus; see introduction.
10469] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 73): ague; here it is always three syllables, so with dieresis; not further remarked.
10472] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 74): Hay
10474] en ces leu: cf. T-L col 431, l. 14

10476] This is the subject of the illumination at the bottom of 72V. To the left are our three travelling figures, with Aeneas at the front this time; in the middle is a king on horseback, with gold crown and leggings, completely covered with armor and decorations; his horse is also covered with a blue cloth decorated with two lions rampant. The king holds a lance inclined up. To the right are two naked figures with bloody holes. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 74): qui
10477] A spot on the MS here is over the last letter; it looks like a round candle wax spot scraped off (it does not go through the folio). Stengel ("Höllenfahrt." p. 74): traison

10478] The Roman d'Alexandre (Alexander Romance) is quite important in Huon for its voyages into the East and for its moral commentary. Alexander tried to rule the world and the air and seas, which was frequently construed as overreaching. For a summary of the story and information about the various versions, the basic reference work is Cary's The Medieval Alexander. A more recent compendium is Zuwiyya's A Companion to Alexander Literature in the Middle Ages. For specific influences, see Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia"; for further bibliography, see also Morgan, "Le Roman d'Alexandre."
10480] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 74): s'argue
10483] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 74): iert
10486] fou: in OF fo 'beech-wood' (T-L), as well as 'fire', which the other seven appearances here signify; elsewhere in the text here, we find fous (8 times) as adjective for 'mad' or 'madman'.
10493] hon: T-L 1092, line 42; with a negative, 'no one' (kein Mensch)
10501.1] vv. 10501-10103 are reproduced and translated in Vidossi (Origini pp. 1214-1215), without capitals except at the beginning of sentences.
10501.2] Note the assonance in this laisse, as opposed to rhyme generally found.

10509] estandre: Holtus in Aliscans defines "estandre" as Italian 'estendere', which means 'to extend, stretch', and in his Lexikalische (p. 278) equates it with 'destendre', meaning 'to kill' among other things. Here, as a noun, il means 'extended stay', perhaps in combination with stare for the vowel. Cf. T 10161 standre.

10511] alâ vendre: "alla a vendre": in Italian, "andare" is constructed with the preposition before an infinitive. It is not clear whether or not that preposition would be present here. The few forms followed by an infinitive are split between its presence and its absence, and a number are like this case here, where the infinitive also starts with an "a." .

10513] In the Oxford Chanson de Roland, Ganelon is torn apart by four horses while his thirty oath-swearers are hanged. Here apendre seems to refer to Ganelon being tied (suspended) from horses' tails. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 75): coe de cival... (a)pandre
10516] This statement fits with the Dantean configuration of hell, where Lucifer and other traitors are at the deepest point, furthest from heaven.
10519] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 75): cruël
10521] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 75): L'autre Chaain... Stengel does not separate the verb in this list in the following line either. For Ham, see Genesis 9:20–27.

10525] The MS hand is slightly different here: abbreviation lines are shorter, writing tighter through the end of this column. Last reference to Aeneas is in this line. Vidossi and Aresi reproduce and translate into Italian (Origini pp. 1214- 1218, even-numbered pages).

10526] This is the scene of the illumination at the bottom of 73. Three men to the left, led this time by St. Guillaume, with Aeneas standing to the back, in front of a hairy devil on a bench. The devil is in chains crossed across his chest and holding his legs together; he holds a crown in his right hand and a ring in his left. There are other similar devils behind him holding spears and pastoral cruxes (like the papal one).

10528] MS: sensfrage, s'ensfrage: this form is unrecorded in other texts. It could be a scribal error for "s'enrage" (OF), for example, as it is here translated. However, there is also an Italian form "frangere," 'to break', recorded from the thirteenth century (DELI), like OF esfraindre; this seems to be the reading of T 10179: De la paura de luy tuta la tera se franze [For fear of him the whole earth breaks apart']. However, -ge- is a typical alternative for -i- (cf. the conditional forms in -oge; Wunderli, AdB, vol. 1 (1982), p. liv ).
10529] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 75): seür[e]mant
10539] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 75): a moy [tot] ce
10540] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 76): e (b[etter]: Q. m. K. M. je) son
10541] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 76): (qar) fol [et] cruël; not necessary, since this is a direct address, and the line is 4+6 syllables.
10544] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 76): tu (la) retendras
10546] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 76): Mande [a] luy
10550] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 76): [Il] dist
10553] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 76): [Et] Lucifer respont

10554] There is a problem here in transmission; T 10205 reads, "ty et luy quỳ ben t'acordaremo [you and he we will agree with]. The construction "Tot [et] a luy" is odd- either an initial "A" is missing or the "[et]" is superfluous.
10555] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 76): cum a vos (si) converon
10568] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 76): len vait

10574] Vidossi: l'en feise "se così facessi, molto agirei malamente" = 'if I did that, I would act very badly'. The verb ending -as can be explained as the "sigmatic" conditional based on the imperfect subjunctive (Rohlfs ¶ 598; Mascitelli, La Geste Francor, pp. 312-313); cf. here v. 10610, moy ponsas for "that I rest." Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 76): Si confeise
10581] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 77): esciant

10582] Note that this is the one of the three gifts comprising the tribute that is not illustrated in the illumination on 73R. "Cum" here is Modern French "comme" which is why we here translate it "litter" in comparison to 7673 and 9409, in rhyme, where "letiere" clearly means "bed" or "pallet."
10585] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 77): soëf (not necessary: 6+4 without dieresis)

10588] PE Bennett notes the parallel here in what Lucifer offers Carlo Martello with what Carlo Martello offers Ynide: a bed (like the litter), a crown (of France for her) and a ring (for Ynide, for the wedding).
10590] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 77): to[s]t [et]; not necessary: the line is 5+5 as it stands.
10594] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 77): estes, (e) bien; not necessary: the line is 5+7.
10596] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 77): e(n)l(e) doy met

10597] ferais: Mainone (Formen, p. 14, p. 27), lists this as an example of a first-person singular future with the ending formed by analogy with second-person endings (his line count follows that of Stengel, off by 157 lines as an allowance for the missing siege of Auvergne). Yet in the following paragraph on p. 14 he also says that the future ending for the second-person singular is often in -ais. All six appearances of ferais here in B are second-person singular. Turin 10248 instead understands "No[n] farazo my," dize lo [con]te, "tal comandame[n]to" as [I will never obey [lit. do] such an order], and the my [MSI 'mica'] is perhaps what led Mainone astray.
10599] End of Vidossi and Arese's transcription and translation. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 77): lasel(i)

10606] MS: paus: a hapaxlegomenon here, in other F-I texts, 'stick(s)' (palo) or 'a little' (peu). T reads "pasy", 'passes'. Perhaps a saut du même au même, seeing crueus afterward; T-L sends to "poi" (cols. 2059-2076), then "pui" (col. 3076), whence our interpretation 'hills, mountains'.
10607] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 77): a nos
10609] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 77): [si] ha
10619] la ci: this is an unusual construction, appearing nowhere else in the MS. It would seem to be direct object (referring to food) plus adverbial 'there'.
10620] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 78): oit veue
10626] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 78): benecïon (not necessary, if Diex is two syllables)
10628] MS: maier, there is no abbreviation in the MS; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 78): ma[n]jer
10629] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 78): töe (not necessary: line is 5+5 as it stands)
10630] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 78): feis... terre (b[etter]: qe de ta t. tu feïs)
10635] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 78): söe (not necessary, 5+5 as it stands)

10652] faigé : this may be a lenited form of "fatigué": intervocalic t>d>ø. It is not found in RIALFrI (14.IV.19). Cf. lines 1965, 11142, faigeç (equivalents in T: fadigà; afinato [afiné = 'épuisé', Matsumura]).
10657] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 79): dapart
10664] The first part of illumination, 74R, bottom: a hairy devil is carrying Huon at table through the air. Huon is sleeping on the table that has various things on it.
10665] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt," p. 79): Soëf (not necessary: as line stands, it is 4+6 syllables)
10670] End of Stengel's "Höllenfahrt," p. 79, his v. 10827.
10671] Begin Stengel's "Karl Martel's Enführung" (p. 873), his v. 10828.

10679] la vie longe a: here the verb "a" acts as modern 'il y a', 'there is the long road'; T10330 no[n] vollio più demorare, che la via siè longa [I don't want to wait any longer, for the road is long], uses "to be" in a slightly different construction.

10681] quasa: a word in this particular form does not seem to appear in other F-I texts or in commentary about Huon. It appears to be a variant spelling of FM "casser," here in the reflexive form. Matsumura documents both the abstract sense (WatrS, quasse) and the reflexive, but not together (as does T-L). Other appearances in F-I, while spelled with the same initial form, generally refer to physical combat (RIALFrI). T-L: REW quassare.However, there is a typical etymologically related F-I verb that is reflexive: squassare, 'to shake up, to shake violently'; cf. AdB, vol. 3, p. 321, and entries in RIALFrI for "squaserent" (all "soi" or "se squaserent").
10686] This section is somewhat comic, showing Huon as a naïf, not unlike Charlemagne in the GF, who marvels that someone (in that case, an angel) managed to get into the royal tent.
10699] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 874), emends to [tres]tot; he emends to relate to Rajna's transcription of T. It would increase the syllable count to 12.

10706] fron: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 331). In F-I, fron is feminine, under influence of Ital. "fronte." This and the one in v. 8886 are the only examples of six appearances where it might construed as feminine.

10715] In the second part of the illumination below, Huon is inside a house by a window with grey outside, and his head is still on table, sleeping. Food items are on the table, including a partially-full glass, a flask of liquid, rolls and various containers.
10723] A fold in the MS runs through these three lines, across "moiller," "encontrer," "Nul."
10729] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 875): non [la] leisast. This would add an extra syllable where the line is already 5+5.
10731] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 875): mès (si) fa
10739] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 875): Desor[e]

10743] MS: sa moitist. There is no lexical item like this elsewhere in this text. The closest possibility in OF dictionaries seems to be "amoistir," to dampen, thus our word division. Looking elsewhere in the text we find "moit" (v. 7121) from "to move"; Matsumura lists "amovoir" but not reflexive form; T-L lists a possibly reflexive "movoir." If this were the case, it would signify "to gesticulate" as the text suggests already when he begs for pardon (v. 10730). The following tears and frequent expressions elsewhere about his dampening himself with tears make dampening seem more attractive as a possibility. An equivalent line is missing from Turin. RIALFrI includes two forms, "amoistir" (refering to preparing of meat to cook, Brunetto Latini) and "amoistist" (speaking of milk moistening the body; Aldobrandino da Siena). We thank our consultants for their assistance here.
10747] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 875): Stengel ("Entführung," p. 875): le [le]ira

10750] Note that the first hemistich here is very similar to line 10756, and the term used, desfigureç, only appears in one other verse, 8108, where the animals around Noah's Ark are described as being different from the usual because they are not hostile or ferocious. The term seems to therefore relate to difference, not being the expected; in line 10756 that might also mean changed or altered, since it is Ynide seeming to recognize her long-lost spouse, whereas here it is not clear if Ynide's recognition is dawning or whether the redactor is offering us a clue– or if it is merely a saut du même au même. Both lines appear in Turin, but the form is slightly different in the two, not exactly the same as here.
10755] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 875): mo[n] signor
10758] The "que" or other conjunction seems to be missing here; cf. T 10413: el no[n] pare ch'el sapia parlare [...] [it doesn't seem that he knows how to speak].

10762] MS: aspë; T 10417: aspeto. There is no form "asper" or "aspre" as a noun; however, see v. 9352, sper, so we are interpreting this as a form of "esper" (cf. T-L "esperer," "esperance"; Matsumura "espoire, espere" fem., F-I, "esperance," EE), but T's interpretation seems more likely. The frequency of errors between r and t in this version also renders that explanation most likely (see introduction).

10763] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 876): Bien [le] conuit; note that the MS reading is a common formula; Bien conuit appears four times in addition to here (2478, 3013, 7475, 11726), with a pronoun inserted in four other lines.
10765] Cf. v. 1591, when Huon recalls knowing Sanson's father at Carcassonne.
10768] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 876): Or(e), to reduce syllable count to 12.
10776] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 876): Lor le (re)cort
10781] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 876): [au]tresi

10790] This is a problematic line; ator; DEAF 'condition, état'; T-L: 'Stand, Zustand ; Matsumura: 'condition; caractère; équipement; entourage; parure'. Cf. v. 12049. The meaning here is unclear, as is the word division; the MS reads a separation la tor; T 10446 reads similarly in the MS, la tore. However, the verb, T-L atorner, 'etw. oder jem. richten' (col. 647) [to straighten something or someone out], would seem to correspond to the sense here. Again, we thank our consultants for assisting with this line.

10796] Stengel ("Entfurhung," p. 876): Qu(ant)' a; but see T 10452 che a salvamento m'à [con]duto et a onore [who to safety and to honor led me; or perhaps, who led me honorably and safely]: notice the additional "and."

10797] MS: ay che; Stengel ("Entführung," p. 876): Ce (n)est [de] l'enfer che je ay che[rché] segnor (T 10453: zò siè da l'enferno che yo azo cerchà, signore) [That is Hell which I have searched, lord]. We keept the "cer-" initial form to keep in line with other forms in this MS. Since the line is 10 syllables, it can be considered as a possibility. Stengel seems to have the right idea for the second hemistich (there are three forms of "che[r]re" in our text for "to seek") but removing an n as in the first hemistich is unusual. Looking at Turin to help, the n can be a partitive pronoun (FM en, MSI ne). Cf. v. 11123, "Que a l'enfer fui; grant part n'ai ge cercheç" [That I was in hell; I went through a large part of it], so we accept Stengel's emendation of the second hemistich but not of the first.

10800] MS: conseler; Stengel ("Entführung," p. 876): Conseler [vos] devéç; T 10456: Consolar vuy ora; the subject seems to be missing in B, and a conjugated verb in T, unless in T the infinitive acts as imperative, which it can.
10807] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 877): [nul] autre
10819] See lines 8975 and 10944.
10833] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 877): (le) respont
10839] emprendre = 'apprendre'; , an expansion on 'to begin; to undertake' (cf. T-L col. 132-133; Matsumura, emprendre3).
10844] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 878): Parler [ge] voil
10854] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 878): Par(mi)
10856] MS: se smoue. Forms of smou appear 4 times, esmou 3 times. Since the two are here separated in the MS and there is no overwhelming evidence either way, we print here in two words.
10857] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 878): qui (qu')
10863] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 878): "[que] soit ..."
10864] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 878): chier[e]
10871] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 878): furent [il]
10872] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 878): main [ont] tenue
10893] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 879): l'afer[e]
10903]el = et + il

10907] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 879): [e]n avray; this line is short or long a syllable; the other three times poor appears it must be two syllables (lines 698, 8798, 9093) in order to have a 10-syllable line or a 12-syllable line; here, it would be 9-syllable if "pöor."
10914] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 879): De [ce] qu'il dit non [le] croit il nïent
10920] This line is a bit confusing, and T does not help; it seems to be "that you come out underneath" literally; the same is true for T 10571. Stengel ("Entführung," p. 880): Or(e) que
10922] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 880): Cuides [tu]
10938] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 880): Va [tost]
10939] (i) above the line with caret below.

10941] This is the scene illustrated in the illumination of 75V: At Charles's court (from left to right), the devil in the form of a pilgrim and Huon (with a red beard and lots of hair) extend a red cloth with golden birds on it. The king sits on a dais, crowned under a backdrop of white with red at the top. Several armed soldiers are at the far right beside the throne. Here the litiere appears to be a decorated cloth, similar to the definition of bedclothes that one finds on a bed.
10944] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 880): Nus ni p[o]oit; see lines 8975 and 10819 for afaitement.

10953] Scharselle mosnere: see escarcele, 'bourse attachée à la ceinture' (Matsumura; FEW; cf. RIALFrI, Inventario dei beni di Guy d’Ibelin, 1367, Cipro, I, 4, "item une santure de cuir et une scarcelle de cuir, vendue den. 30"); for mosnere, see GdA I, IX, 171, 'borsa', where it also appears as mesnere, there defined 'borsa'. Here it appears as mosnere 7 times. Holtus explains the lack of initial vowel coming from T-L "ausmoniere" through the deconcretization of the article, l'a- becoming la and cites FEW, DEI forms (Holtus Lexikon, p. 377, sub voce "monieres"). Though Holtus does not mention it, there seems to be a link with "monoie," 'money' (T-L, cols. 215-216), an association confirmed by the FEW "bone mousnie" for 'monnaie conforme aux normes légales' (1297), FEW 6/3, p. 76 col. 1 (https://lecteur-few.atilf.fr/index.php/page/lire/e/173926, consulted 22 March 2022); perhaps that was merely popular etymology.

10954] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 880) concludes this line with (!?) enoy: from enoillier (Matsumura, "lorgner"); cf. Ital. adocchiare (DELI, bef. 1321, Dante). Matsumura's only example is from the fifteenth century; this seems to be an unusually early occurrence in this text, possibly under the Italian influence. El: 'in it'
10958] Again a spot at the end of this line, circular perhaps originally a drop of wax now removed?
10968] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 881): [Si] tost

10969] This is the scene of the illumination here on 76R: At Charles Martel's court still with Huon in bourgeois clothes to the left with some soldiers, to the right other soldiers with another bourgeois, and in the middle above Charles Martel on the red cloth decorated with gold birds, held up by haïry devils some red and some blue-gray. Crown is the same as in previous illumination, and the ring is not in presence either.
10971] Note the parallel here to Huon's table and the devil being carried off at the beginning of the poem, vv. 976-78, just before Huon's departure to seek hell.
10994] MS sorjugie; seems to be a scribal error for "forjugie"; cf. line 8212.
11001] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 882): Cest[uy]
11003] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 882): (en)ça, le autre (en) la
11004] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 882): nos (il) doit
11009] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 882): por (nulle) rien que sie
11031] Perhaps to be emended to "Jusqu'un anç"?
11032] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 882) : Iloch (il) sera

11041] MS: redue. Cf. duire (T-L), and Ital ridurre, past participle ridotto; GdA, redu = "reso" (p. 446), which would imply rendere as the original verb, but would not much alter the meaning or translation: 'rendered' or 'put into', in any case, 'documented'.

11044] MS: en region; this line is quite different in T 10695: ch'el aza fama nel tenire razone [that he is reputed to be a good speaker]. Here, the line seems to be negative in format, that he isn't married and that he isn't something else. One possibility might be 'insane, unreasoned' for in+ rage + the rhyme syllable (cf. ragne v. 6450 for "regne"; ragine v. 3819 vs. "regn(e)" and "regine"). We thank PEB for this suggested emendation, which we accept: with fame at the caesura, the line counts 4'+6 syllables.
11057] As usual, the "or" is written above the roman numeral.
11064] a tent = "a tens": 'en temps utile' (Matsumura) [soon, without delay]
11069] Initial 'D' of this line the reverse of spot mentioned on 76R. The left side of the a is scraped or light. It would appear to be candle wax: the parchment page is thin and one can see through.

11072] MS: laë, the two vowels are written as a ligature sharing the right side of the a and the left side of the e; it seems to be a correction. Since the reference is to a choice, a process— ovrement–we write le.
11073] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 884): s'[il] avront feit
11077] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 884): vos dir[e] m'oëç
11086] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 884): fust [tot] doneç
11096] The word order in prose would be "fist comant que fust aporteç la table Que [...]"
11109] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 884): p[o]oit
11125] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 885): [a vos] par moy

11130] MS: fëçay: cf. frecent (v. 8100) and freça (v. 4431), also attested in the GdA (v. 1058) (RIALFrI). DELI's first attestation of 'affrettare' is 1614, it notes that the DEI lists 13th century, which must be an error. Our text demonstrates that, in fact, the form "frettare" exists in 1341. 'Fretta' appears in 1213 according to the TLIO (s.v.). It appears frequently in texts where "fretta" is used as comparison of speed, which also suggests a relationship with arrows, not just cleaning a ship as mentioned in DELI for the etymology.
11140] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 885): tot[e]
11147] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 885): vit, (puis) merveille

11164] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 886): [a]gusté. This may be an evocation of Biblical loaves and fishes stories (Matthew 14, 13-21; Mark 6, 31-44; Luke 9, 12-17; John 6, 1-14, as well as Matthew 15, 32-39 and Mark 8, 1-9) , where the food expands to satisfy all; it is also, of course, a reflection of the eucharist, as well as fairy tales where there may be a bag that produces as much food as is needed.

11177] The end of this line is problematic. Whom or what does he know or recognize as being from God? Turin instead, lines 11086-87, speaks of supplies ("vetuvaria", MSI vettovaglia) rather than adventure. The MS has a space between "da" and "lor"; alternatively the text could read "tot le conuit d'alor," "he recognized it all from then on" or something similar. However, Huon has been recognizant of God throughout, so though "lor" is etymologically plural, the mixing is frequent here (and if Huon/author thinks of the Trinity, even logical).
11178] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 886): Stengel ("Entführung," p. 886): Or est venus

11180] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 886): nuls qi s'en fent; nuls qi s'enfent: this could be an Italian structure of negation without the preceding "ne" that is typical of French and Old French negation before the verb. T 10830 de s[er]vire no[n]n-è n(e)sun che se'nfenzia [there is no one who doesn't .. (no record of the form for the final expression)] attempts to resolve the specific meaning here. Mainone includes fent with no comment or explanation (p. 21). fendere (DELI, before 1294 'spaccare trasversalmente') and its reflexive (DELI before 1348, Villani 'screpolarsi, aprirsi, spaccarsi') both appear in DELI; fingere (bef. 1294 'suppore, figurarsi, immaginare') and fingersi (1516, Ariosto Orlando 'farsi credere, mostrarsi, atteggiarsi') also appear, as does infingersi, an intransitive pronominal verb, 'simulare' (DELI 1304). None of these seem to make a lot of sense. However, in Enanchet appears the noun "enfinziment," which Fiebig defines as 'Faulheit', 'laziness, idleness' (p. 131); Morlino (Enanchet) defines the same (anfançiment) as 'sosta', 'delay', citing another source with Old Northern Italian examples (p. 516). See the corresponding note in translation. So the line would literally mean 'there was no one who gave himself rest in serving [the count].'
11191] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 887): [re]grace
11193] aremanent: see note to v. 4727.
11196] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 887): [de] tot
11204] aquent: "alquanto," 'some'

11207] This column is one line shorter than usual columns, possibly because the next column begins with a large initial and extensive decoration. That may have been planned for, giving more space in the margin at the top, thus with one line short here.

11208] This folio, though a verso, is highly decorated; with the laisse "Segnor, seeç en pais..." it is like the beginning of a new chanson de geste, with a large and gilded capital, along with marginal color in red, green, blue, and gold.

11213] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 887): sauç; the MS reads clearly sanç, but the first letter has some sort of marking (similar to the abbreviation with p). The Turin MS differs; it has an equivalent to 11212, T 10864: De zò no[n] sapete nolsa e po' l'avè descop[er]reto [He didn't know (Rajna: stete) anything and then he had discovered it].
11216] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 887): christï[e]ntie
11220] His brothers-in-law, Ynide's brothers, are Baudouin and Thomas of Flanders, as we recall from v. 93-94.
11223] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 887): miller [que]'n
11224] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 887): Paris[e]
11226] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 887): il (i) vent ... barnie
11227] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 887): demorent (et) a
11230] There is an 'x' marked between this verse and the next in the right margin.

11235] ie = "there" Roman d'Alexandre; cf. Aspremont (Trento), GdA (see RIALFrI). "asentie": cf. GdA; Bovo d'Antona laurenziano, etc. for "asent-" as 'to sit', RIALFrI, consulted 29 October 2020 (inter alia, thus defined in the Glossary of GdA, p. 379). Note that this same form assentir (T-L 582) in OF is 'to consent', and thus the line could be interpreted either way.

11237] balaor: listed by Holtus under bailir, "donner," bailior, "conducteur" (Lexikalische, 227-28), but see GdA, "baleor: palco, balcone" and EE, "baucons: balcone." T reads "baladore" in lines 10886, 10887.
11241] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 888): [oit] parlee
11243] Note that this one form is not in sight rhyme in this laisse.
11249] Line after al and before balaor.
11260] Capital 'D' with a face drawn in it
11262] bufoy: cf. GdA
11270] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 889): Jer(u)salem
11274] See note for line 1643.
11275] s'arequoy: from "recoillir, recueillir" (Matsumura) as a reflexive form, with the prefix a-, frequent in Franco-Italian; cf. recoillir (DEAFél)
11284] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 889): (elle) venoit
11287] r above the line with no caret below, but it seems to be the same handwriting.
11289] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 889): un(e) jor
11305] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 889): (di)finimant; difinima[n]t: TLIO "definimento," s.m. www.tlio.ovi.cnr.it/voci/013417.htm consulted October 29, 2020. Cf. T-L 1286, line 21.
11310] garpu: cf. "guerpir," 'to abandon' (T-L); EE; Niccolò da Verona, ed. Di Ninni.
11315] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 890): [e]lecion
11317] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 890): s'[è] moüe; cf. T 10963: siè mouda

11336] There is clearly a problem with this poetic line; perhaps it is two lines run together. Half of one line seems to be missing, with a conjugated verb on which conostre depends; after ten syllables ending in "lignage" there is no rhyme, and six more syllables follow. The verb is missing from Turin 10982: zò era la soma d'alto legnazo e più grande [that was the sum of high and greatest lineage]. The equivalent would be "Ço ert la some da haut lignage plus g[ra]nt." The line here is quite long and runs into the following column; furthermore there is a light slashed line (typical of those that divide hemistichs) following lignage. It would seem to be an example of an infinitive complement of a verb (cf. Ménard, ¶ 167): 'he read to know'
11349] MS: une sol; trovâ tant = trova + atant
11352] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 891): tot[e] jant
11354] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 891): doneor (de) convoitisse

11359] The -en- of Veneç is in a circular brown spot, which does not seem to be wax (it does not go through the parchment). This section is illustrated in the illumination here on 78V: to the left are Huon in his recognizable yellow outfit, together with a group of men; in the center is a raised platform made of wood (with balustrade around above like the supports below), with two scenes also. In the first, the archbishop (distinguished by his red robes and typical white ... hat with a red cross) crowns the king (William), who is bearded and long-haïred; in the second, to the right, William marries Belisor—they are holding hands and she is accompanied by other women. Below the raised platform, on the right, are other men, two bearded, two not.

11361] Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 227-28) gives baleor here and in v. 11238 as related to "bailior," "conducteur," or 'administrator' (T-L), related to the English 'baillif'. This is possible here, though the T 11006 "baladore" seems to suggest "ballatoio," a type of balcony, and the illumination suggests that. Matsumura, "celui qui remet qch à qn." The following line has him being presented to the pope, and thus seems to have been understood as 'dais'.

11362] Te deum laudamus: the first words of the so-called Ambrosian hymn at the end of Matins. It can be traced back as far as the sixth century, when those initial words are cited in volumes of rules for monks. It is a traditional hymn of celebration, as at papal elections.
11367] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 891): tot[e] celle
11368] empoisa: we are presuming this is from "empeser"; cf. Godefroy's and Matsumura's citation of Anticlaudianus, defined, "appuyer fortement." It appears as one word in the MS.
11373] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 891): oit (a) non

11377] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 891): pristrent [il] congié, end of article, v. 11534. Begin Stengel's "Roms Befreiung", v. 11535, which he transcribes through to the end. He notes that he uses Pio Rajna's transcription of Turin to add annotations and make corrections (p. 267 n1), so we will not note these. Again, we will not note differences in trascription policy (e.g., word division if it makes no difference in sense; punctuation; u/v; etc.) .
11379] Stengel ("Roms," p. 267): Por
11390] scorceront: scorcher, EE: "écorcher", 'to skin alive'; T-L escorchier.
11392] Stengel ("Roms," p. 268): esillé. But cf. the preceding line: [...] asige, [...] prendront, where there are both a singular and plural verb.
11393] Stengel ("Roms," p. 268): fuiç ont
11394] Stengel ("Roms," p. 268), note "pietà" for plait
11395] gardenaus: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 335-36), "cardinal"; T-L gardinal -> chardinal.
11399] Stengel ("Roms," p. 268), .II. for "de"; he understands here as "two messengers" modelling upon T. 11041.

11409] The form adesie here is problematic. In Italian,"adire" means specifically "to go to [legal means], to sue"; thus this seems to imply some legal application. It could be "desirer" with the added prefix "a." adeser: to touch, reach, approach. In any case, the meaning seems to be something about what the ambassadors wish.

11412] This is a problematic line; there is clearly an error of some kind. T 11055: alora a soa zente dona e demena bona vita [so he gives to his people and leads a good life]. Perhaps the second half of the first line and first half of the second are missing due to a saut? Since the line is so different in T and not present in Andrea da Barberino's version, the only other version including the election of a new French king and emperor (vol. 2, Capitolo VIII, pp. 215-218), we interpret it as reading "De doner a lor jans et a mener belle vie" or possibly "A doner a lor jans et a mener belle vie."
11416] This is not the usual sight rhyme.

11420] pogie: this is a hapax legomenon in this text. The second hemistich here makes little sense– the king placing a letter on his head (sor cef pogie) would not seem logical. A missing abbreviation line (for the final word) and/or erroneous readings— of "s" for "f"– or a missing abbreviation– might be likely. The Turin line cannot however reflect what is here; *soi cef 'his leaders' or *pognie 'held in his fist' exclude each other. We propose emending the s of sor to f; misreading these for each other is a frequent scribal error. Note that the following line is missing from Turin, so that MS tradition also had difficulty with these lines. If "pogie" is understood as missing an abbreviation mark for "porgie" (DELI porgere, attested 1250), the line might have a similar meaning to that of T [then he energetically/rapidly handed it to (others) so that they could see it]. However, there are no similar forms in this MS, whereas forms of poier/poggiare are frequent.
11421] Stengel ("Roms," p. 268): –E[n]segne est de bone compagnie–
11431] Stengel ("Roms," p. 269) notes, "e ly" (the reading of T line 11073) for ol

11434] antie: clearly not "old" as elsewhere in this MS, but rather a past participle.T 11076: in altorio [as help], TLIO (http://tlio.ovi.cnr.it/voci/r02201.htm). See corresponding note in translation for alternative meanings.

11438] As Stengel ("Roms," p. 269 n3) notes, 11462-11463 should go here, not where they appear: their rhyme would be appropriate to that previous laisse, and the sense fits as well. We have therefore placed them here.

11439] This line and the next are out in the margin in line with the capital below (after line 11463 by this numbering). To the left is a large parenthesis around the two with a cross in the margin to the left of it. The lines clearly do not rhyme with the following laisse, by which they are written; Stengel notes that they should instead go with this laisse (with which they do rhyme), rather than the following.
11441] oit could be either from "to have" or from "to hear"; since this is rhyme position, there is no dieresis, whichever meaning it holds. Turin uses a form of "to hear."
11463] See note for line 11439, above.
11472] -ç of sanç was changed from 't'.
11481] Stengel ("Roms," p. 270): adex en
11492] Stengel ("Roms," p. 270): Ançois
11496] m above the roman numeral 'iiii' as usual.
11498] Stengel ("Roms," p. 270): reciut (see also v. 10309)
11522] Stengel ("Suche,"p. 53) notes that remas = "remest" from 'remanoir' as we do translate it.
11540] Stengel ("Roms," p.272): v'erent
11546] The only full forms of this name are Willame, but there are two similar appearances of Guilla[u]me. We resolve the abbreviation W'ill'ame here like those.
11547] despacer: cf. 8091, despaiç (cf. Wünderli, AdB, vol. 3, p. 268). The beginning of the quote is unclear; it could possibly begin with this line and follow to the next.
11549] Stengel: contralïent, which would take the line to 12 syllables.
11556] Stengel ("Roms," p. 272): en promis
11565] Compare T 11201 E s'el no[n] fose per pezore dotanza che yo azo [And if it weren't for worse fear that I have]: note the difference in subject with B, each clearly stated.

11569] deruer in OF is listed as transitive (Matsumura; T-L), and is transitive in the GdA, "precipitare." Compared with T, that reads dimora, derua seems here instead to be a parallel phrase, so it is not clear what the relative clause modifies, the angels or God, so it is unclear whether the verb is transitive or intransitive.
11570] ên = et + en

11577] parare rifl: 'presentarsi, opporsi'; 'abbigliarsi con paramenti'; 'difendersi, schermirsi'.There are three other appearances of parra in this MS, 2022, 3894, 7618. The first two are clearly from "parere," modern Italian 'to appear' with the future form 'parrà'; the third from 'parere', to want (DELI, "volere") as in "come ti pare" 'as you will'. Vonront: this is a hapax; it is unclear whether it is from 'venire' or 'volere'; even the forms of 'venire' (venron, venront) are hapaxes, and only appear in rhyme position.
11580] MS, Stengel ("Roms," p. 273): lay; MS: lay
11583] D(i)ex: the i above the line (with no caret below) was clearly intended, but same ink and nib.

11584] The illumination at the bottom of 80R relates to the fighting in the streets of Rome. The entire scene is within city walls, with a siege engine off to the extreme left (evident by its wood supporting structure in contrast to the continuous city walls). In the center is a religious figure in clerical garb giving a blessing with his right hand raised, two fingers out; he faces his right (our left). There are no recognizable figures in the fighting, all are in Western armor garb, with faces / necks covered (so no beards evident) and in armor, with no distinguishable armor covers. Some horses are also present.

11586] MS: mërent. The two dots normally stand for an r plus a vowel, but here an r is already present. T 11222: Allor despeto li metono [Then they showed them their annoyance], followed by a description of broken trunks and clothes thrown out. Stengel ("Roms," p. 273): merrent .
11599] Stengel ("Roms," p. 273): feit é a escïent
11601] Stengel ("Roms," p. 273): mil[ler]
11611] trepas de vent: Cf. Dante's Purg. 11.100-102: "Non è il mondan romore altro ch'un fiato/ di vento, ch'or vien quinci e or vien quindi,/ e muta nome perché muta lato."
11623] Stengel ("Roms," p. 274): Fetes
11627] Stengel ("Roms," p. 274): que [non] feront asé
11631] Cf. T 11267 com era l'onore de lo y[m]perio che yo li azo donà [as was the honor of the Empire that I have given them]; thus our interpretation of Com here.
11640] Âlemans: a + Alemans
11645] Stengel ("Roms," p. 274): Cuide [lor] fer
11648] esmagié is from "esmaiier" (*EXMAGIARE; see DEAF, specifically cites HdA), 'to dismay, frighten, terrify'

11653] A la nom: note the feminine article here, as in v. 7182; the reason is unclear. The formula "a nom de" or "a le nom de" is relatively frequent, and there seems to be no motivation for a different structure here.
11660.1] deivent: the MS minim links cannot be clearly distinguished; there are many forms in doiv-, and none in deiv- for "devoir" we interpret thus.
11660.2] Stengel ("Roms," p. 275): devïent
11663] Stengel ("Roms," p. 275): mil[le]
11668] Stengel ("Roms," p. 275): cinque cent. Note the use of the long-n type abbreviation after "cq" in "cīncq" for "ue."

11670] Stengel ("Roms," p. 275): l'un [fu] rois; he adds another line after this, based on Turin: [E l'autre fu le rois de Lombardie gent]; it is clearly based on T 11306: e l'altro fo lo re de Lombardia zentile [and the other was the noble king of Lombardy].
11674] Stengel ("Roms," p. 275): et [il] lor
11681] Stengel ("Roms," p. 275): ben voilent
11689] Stengel ("Roms," p. 276): A(le)

11701] Stengel ("Roms," p. 276): mill(er) [bel et fer]– emended based on Turin. Emendation is not necessary, if the numbers are pronounced in Italian, totally four syllables instead of two in French, thus bringing the line total to ten syllables.
11712] qi inserted with caret at line level; very tiny writing.

11714] Cf. T 11349 Dio si ama ly nostre e bene apare quel zorno [God so loved our (men) and it showed clearly that day]; in this B MS we have 5'+7 syllables, so the caesura is before bien. There are no lines between hemistichs on this folio to indicate any other interpretation.
11772] bufer: T-L bofer, bufer, 'schnauben' [snort] ; DELI "buffare": 'sbuffare' [snort], 14th century; "buffare", 'to blow hard', perhaps here in a metaphorical sense.
11731] In the left margin is a small x in front of this line.
11734] The c is above the roman numeral, as usual.
11760] Stengel ("Roms" p. 277): A celuy [pont]

11763] The illumination at the bottom of 81V shows the battle outside the city, with the city walls to the left and two groups confronting each other on horseback. On the center left, there is a brown horse with a red cover, gold lions on it; to the right is a white horse with a green blanket covered with a flowered design. Above this, a man's head (with reddish-brown beard) is upside-down, presumably cut off. It is interesting that though foot-soldiers and archers are mentioned with each group none are illustrated. The upside-down cut-off head is very detailed and in a different style from that of the rest of the MS.
11765] Stengel ("Roms" p. 278): gard(e)
11774] a inserted above the line with caret below.
11780] Stengel ("Roms," p. 278): et il [fu] quart
11796] el = et + el; chataille (Mainone, Laut, p. 14): "catagne, cataine (capitaneus)?"
11808] See v. 11846, which clarifies that these are indeed also pagans.
11809.1] Stengel ("Roms," p. 279): Ugon [li] ançoner

11809.2] ançoner:while the meaning to the term seems clear, locating a specific origin is difficult. In the GF one finds "ançioner," which Mussafia, in the phrase "non sia ançoner" interprets "non sia tenuto in onore" [not held in honor], deriving it from ancien, so literally here, "the most senior." Another alternative is that it might be derived from "ancone" : in T-L this is a banner with the Virgin Mary on it ( from Greek eikon); ançoner would be the banner-carrier, the leader (cf. Matsumura, "ancoine"). Or finally, it could derive from ainçois, ançois for "first," here with a suffix, so the first, the leader (ainz takes numerous combinations and -er is a typical Franco-Italian suffix, particularly for a person; cf. Holtus, Lexikalische p. 99, p. 115). Bergo, in his edition of "Macario," gives it as a variant of ancioner (from ANTE, FEW) also "held in honor" (p. 261).
11810] emper: empire, empere = 'pouvoir' [power] (Matsumura); T-L empire, empere, col. 107: 'Herrschaft' = 'control'
11811]MS: escuç: this may be a copyist error; perhas emend to esluç? Cf. T 11446: era sopra tuty aleto, 'he was elected above everyone'
11814] host âsauter= "host a asauter"

11842] Stengel ("Roms," p. 280): [et] si
