11848] (t) above the line with caret below.
11853] Stengel ("Roms," p. 280): Mout [il] li regreta
11860] le is followed by an expunctuated s.
11862] The abbreviation mark above the p seems more like a random ink spot.

11867] âl cor = "a al cor," 'he has/they have in his/their heart/s'; this may be a reference to the common trope of Charlemagne and his mourning for lost men; cf. Chanson de Rolandlaisse 291, where Charlemagne 'Pluret des oilz, sa barbe blanche tiret' [Wept from his eyes, pulled at his white beard] for sorrow when summoned to further battle (Ed. Segre, trans. Tyssens, 2003, p. 297).
11872] Stengel ("Roms," p. 280): a lor
11873] Stengel ("Roms," p. 280): (de)robant
11880] Stengel ("Roms," p. 281): Cit ait
11885] l inserted before hostel in the reddish-purple ink of the rubrication, with a caret below in the same.

11895] escont: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 309), on the difficulty of distinguishing "escondre," 'to hide', from "escondire," 'to refuse.' We are interpreting it here as from 'escondire' (with thanks to PEB).
11901] At the top of the upstroke of the h in Franchois is a wormhole.
11905] Stengel ("Roms," p. 281): mil [homes]; the addition not necessary, if the number is read in the Italian form "venti mille" then the line is twelve syllables long.
11906] mont: note the replacement of assonance here ('mout' or 'molt') by sight rhyme; cf. Matsumura, T-L, "molt"

11911] The illumination at the bottom of this 82V shows the confrontation of the pope. The pope is in red in the middle, with his right hand raised. He is on a throne. To his right (viewer's left) is a very short king in a crown dressed in blue, with his arms crossed and men behind him, swords drawn. To the right (pope's left) are other men, also with swords, the second one with his half-way out of the sheath.

11913] Stengel ("Roms" p. 281): [A] cestuy; we presume that cestuy is a dative form, much like the OI cui (cf. Rohlfs ¶¶ 483, 485); Old Tuscan also used colui as a possessive before a noun, and questui appears in Old Venetian and Milanese (¶ 492). Similarly, cestui in OF was object case (Pope, ¶ 845; Kibler, ¶ 20). Kibler points out that it was more frequent in the fourteenth century as a pronoun. That the form was in common to both areas in oblique usages argues that the preposition may have been understood here.
11918] faice: Mainone lists this as a present subjunctive (Formen, p. 27), and the other three forms are, so Huon is speaking in the third person; see note in translation.
11920]Stengel ("Roms" p. 282): bien [com] la
11923] Stengel ("Roms" p. 282): et [tot] le pople
11927] Note the Italianate construction: "Mout el g'en ere" = "Molti ce n'erano"; the line is missing from Turin.
11929] This line is so long that the final -r is in the initial L of the second column.
11930] Stengel ("Roms" p. 282): tant ge[nt]; emendation is unnecessary. "ge" is like the Italian 'ci': c'erano (see introduction)
11956] Âlemans= a Alemans
11958] Stengel ("Roms," p. 283): lor [gent]
11964.1] i expunctuated between o and s of Apostoille.
11964.2] Stengel ("Roms," p. 283): Laison ester
11968] Stengel ("Roms," p. 283): qu(a)' avons
11969] Stengel ("Roms," p. 283): voudro ge; for voudroge as conditional, see Mainone (Formen, p. 34).
11971] Stengel ("Roms," p. 283): ques(i) poit

11973] Stengel ("Roms," p. 283): jons. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 355), gives this as a form of "joindre" meaning "venir," 'to come,' that appears in Franco-Italian. T gives "zonse", "to join" (cf. MSI 'giunse'). However, with two syllables (as in i ons) the line is a decasyllable, and i appears frequently as 'there' in this text. There is no connection between the i and the o: compare ior and several other combinations in the column to the left.
11979] chantons: cf. OF "chant; canton" (T-L), MSI "canto; accanto"
11984] T 10166 reads differently: De. c.iii. milia, .lx. no te conoseno [10 from among the ... don't know you or recognize you]
11986] Stengel ("Roms," p. 283): ci en sons; the MS writes ensons together in one word
11990] Stengel ("Roms," p. 283): deu por reclamoit
11991] Stengel ("Roms," p. 284): que la voit; alternatively, this could read "que l'avoit" = 'that there were/were there', but with the following lighted voice, the verb "to hear" is more contextual.
11993] Stengel ("Roms," p. 284): cristinté

11995] This line and the preceeding are difficult to parse; T 11626-27 are quite different: "Hay, Dio padre, vostra bontà adoncha li sia / mostrate verso coluy chy mantene. Li alta miraclo mostrate" [Oh, God, Father, may your goodness then be show toward him who upholds (it). Show him a great miracle (?)]. The general idea is clear: Huon prays that God reveal a way out of the political impasse to him.
11998] lugor: cf. EE, GdA, "light, brightness"; see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 366).
12000] toit here for "tout"; also in 12007 below. Cf. AdB, vol. 3 (Glossary).
12009] Stengel ("Roms," p. 284): saçe bien avant: Si por

12015] This line and the preceding one are not present in Turin; the criticism there is thus levelled only at the pope, not at the king of France as well. Or perhaps the meaning was unclear in that tradition, so excluded: to whom does the l' refer? See also note in the translation. Note the choice of smaroit in the previous line, an immediate reference to Dante (Inf. 1.3, "la diretta via era smarrita").

12017] Stengel ("Roms," p. 284): v'avendroit. The two downstrokes seem more linked at the top than the bottom. In either case, the meaning is not that different: "would come to you all" vs. "would come from it." .
12023] Stengel ("Roms," p. 284): [El] trove

12026] MS: viāt. This could be an equivalent to "vivant," 'living,' or to "voyant," 'seeing' from voir, so before as witnesses; however, here it seems to be a form of "vient," 'comes' spelled with an a for the rhyme.
12040] laus we are understanding as a form of "louer" / "lodare" ('to praise')
12041] Stengel ("Roms," p. 285): teaçon

12056] Stengel ("Roms," p. 285): pap' e empereor; êmpereror here = "e empereor." It could be understood, "that the emperor have nothing to do with the pope" (without the conjunction), but Turin leads us to believe that it was understood at the time as being neither one nor the other: T 11687: che niente non aza a fare com papa né [con] y[m]peradore [that he/it have nothing to do with pope or with emperor].

12057]s'esforce: impersonal construction with si(cf. Ménard ¶ 126 d, pp. 126-127; Rohlf s ¶ 481, vol. 2 (Morfologia), p. 186); in the Peninsula, it was already frequent in Dante's time, though Ménard notes that it was rare in OF.
12064] Stengel ("Roms," p. 285): moire (et) li
12075] Stengel ("Roms," p. 285): Da (la) part ... (fu) .iiii.
12079] Stengel ("Roms" p 286): fu l'un, son
12084] Stengel ("Roms" p. 286): part (le) fu

12089] firant: according to Mainone (Formen, p. 27), this is a perfect form of the verb "faire." It is the only form of "faire" in the text with an -ant ending, but is also in rhyme. There are 28 appearances of firent. It would seem, however. that since this is an event in the future, it might be an analogical (and rhyme) form of the future or a conditional, which both have other endings with an a.
12094] Stengel ("Roms," p. 286): doviant
12096] Stengel ("Roms," p. 286): respondrent: « Si er lor ovremant»
12097] Stengel ("Roms," p. 286): veiseç

12104.1] The illumination here on 83V is the ordalie, the judicial combat: inside a palisade, two groups are fighting. To the left is the pope with two other clerics, one in white and one in red. To the right is a stylized tree (outside the palisade enclosure).

12104.2]stange: cf. DELI stanga, 'long, wooden pole' used for the two sides of a cart to place horses, or to divide stalls in a barn (med. Lat in Bologna, 1253; Boccaccio 1348-53), GF, poles used to hit others. In Turin, sbare v. 11735 = "sbarra," a pole used to block the entrance, so when combattants entered into an enclosure, someone lifted a bar. (Modern Italian, spranga, a locking mechanism with a bar; from the end of the eighteenth century, a partition that separates the accused from the judges in a courtroom (DELI).)
12106] This is the hair side of the parchment and in this section, the pores are visible and make reading more difficult.

12107] T 11738: Combatre deno y[n]semele; de bon gra li prende [They had to fight together; they took to it with great pleasure]. Ms: pnat, an initial abbreviation line over the p and then one also over the a.
12108] Stengel ("Roms," p. 287): [se] saigne (soy)
12121] Stengel ("Roms," p. 287): i sofer; T 11752: entrate no[n] fono molto, mé y[n]tra tute fereno
12124] Stengel ("Roms," p. 287): vient (a) l'encontrer
12127] The final word here is in the margin; cō is readable, but the t with the r above is inside the binding and only visible in person.
12131] Stengel ("Roms," p. 287): gracïer
12136] Stengel ("Roms," p. 287): li guerer
12137] Stengel ("Roms," p. 287): söe
12151] Stengel ("Roms," p. 288): preu [a]complirons
12155] çambeler: champeler = combattre, 'to fight' (Matsumura); cf. T-L champel, champal
12158] emplaier: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 297), 'couvrir de plaies' [to cover with wounds]

12167] The illumination at the bottom of 84R shows the end of the combat: in the same palisade, the pope and various other men (not the clerks in 83V) are in the middle, with one armed man lying to the left and one to the right, on piles of armor/men. To the viewer's left is a man in a red surcoat with a golden lion; his eyes are closed. To the viewer's right lies a man with a yellow surcoat over his armor; it has black imperial eagles on it. His eyes are open.
12176] Stengel ("Roms," p. 288): navré, amor diex a lor

12178] MS: douēt, douent from "dotere, doër/douër," 'pouvoir d'un bien, d'une qualité' [to endow]. T 11807: de zò che sentenziare posano la yustizia [of that which justice can condemn/sentence], seems to indicate that the source was there interpreted as "d'où vent la justisse" [whence comes justice], which could also be the case here, though it is written as one word and thus our interpretation.
12183] Stengel ("Roms," p. 289): cum poit
12186] joïsse: Cf . Holtus (Lexikalische pp. 356-57), 'jugement'
12196] Under pde, above cristenté, a wormhole in the MS.

12198] It is unclear whom the poet might have in mind for reconquering the Empire from the Germans in 100 years (Turin gives 400 years). Villani's Nuova Cronica (ed. Porta), which dates to the beginning of the fourteenth century, mentions various rulers named "Carlo Martello," and it is a recurring name in the Anjou family. The Cronica notes that Charlemagne's family ceased ruling at the time of Ugo Ciapetta, Duca d'Orliensa. It also speaks of a Carlo Martello in the 1280's (pp. 200 ff), who, by his actions in the southern portion of the Italian peninsula and Sicily, seems to refer to the Charles Martel who lived 1271-95. The Anjou family in the peninsula in any case was very important, so either this reference or that of Turin may be linked to the French royal family in the peninsula at the time of the poem. See Morgan, "First Franco-Italian," and "Charlemagne, Ideal Progenitor."
12209] Tobler includes these lines to the end (p. 606). Stengel ("Roms," p. 289): (I)ci
12210] Tobler: perdon
12213.1] A large blot on this line, from -vre a- that also goes down to the following line onto the top of the date.
12213.2] Stengel ("Roms," p. 289): D'escrivre. Which St. Martin the writer might have in mind is unclear. There were several possibilities; see the introduction.
12214] Tobler: ans (omits abbreviation)
12216] MS: Julli (capitalized in the MS)
12221]Could the name be a play on words? There is a tradition in OF poetry of such jokes. See Additional Note, PEB, "Playing Games with Names in Medieval French Literature: Authors and Scribes."
12224] There is a blank line before the 'Amen' s that starts in 2.5 cm from the normal left margin.
